He also helped them plant 15 mango trees so they could sell fruit in the market.'b'I asked Ms. Jean how her chicken eggs tasted, and she looked scandalized. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to eat these eggs,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to use them to raise more chicks.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ms. Hastings beamed when she heard that. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s getting in the habit of reinvesting, which is good.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In exchange for the help they receive, participants like Ms. Jean must show that they can save money and invest it wisely to grow their businesses. Participants also must send children to school and adopt family planning.'b'To reduce malnutrition, participants are obliged to feed their children at least two hot meals a day. My kids were with me on this trip to Haiti, and they looked with interest at Ms. Jean\xe2\x80\x99s list of obligations posted on her door.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDad,\xe2\x80\x9d my 16-year-old son pointed out, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t always get two hot meals a day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Whether in America or Haiti, poverty is sometimes linked to self-destructive behaviors that lock families into unending cycles of penury. Caseworkers shatter those cycles, partly by ensuring that earnings go to education rather than  alcohol.'b'Mr. Joseph, the caseworker, explained: \xe2\x80\x9cI say, \xe2\x80\x98Every day you go out and drink and smoke, that\xe2\x80\x99s another day that your child can\xe2\x80\x99t go to school or eat.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Granted, things don\xe2\x80\x99t always work smoothly. In a different village, I met a 20-year-old single mother in the program who had let baby goats die of negligence, and who celebrated her first earnings by buying a makeup kit. The same is true of the move by South Korean garment companies to open factories in Haiti.'b'I strongly believe that we have a moral obligation to address extreme poverty around the world. The trouble isn\xe2\x80\x99t merely adulterating Twain\xe2\x80\x99s text. It\xe2\x80\x99s also adulterating social, economic and linguistic history. Substituting the word \xe2\x80\x9cslave\xe2\x80\x9d makes it sound as though all the offense lies in the \xe2\x80\x9cn-word\xe2\x80\x9d and has nothing to do with the institution of slavery. Worse, it suggests that understanding the truth of the past corrupts modern readers, when, in fact, this new edition is busy corrupting the past.'b'When \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d was published, Mark Twain appended a note on his effort to reproduce \xe2\x80\x9cpainstakingly\xe2\x80\x9d the dialects in the book, including several backwoods dialects and \xe2\x80\x9cthe Missouri negro dialect.\xe2\x80\x9d What makes \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d so important in American literature isn\xe2\x80\x99t just the story, it\xe2\x80\x99s the richness, the detail, the unprecedented accuracy of its spoken language. Daitz'b'\nNew York, Jan. 3, 2011'b''b'To the Editor:'b'Your Dec. 28 editorial \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Temple to Justice'b'\xe2\x80\x9d is correct in noting that the current Supreme Court does not now fully function as \xe2\x80\x9ca moral force in American life.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed, were Cass Gilbert designing the building now, he might have the inscription over the entrance read \xe2\x80\x9cEqual Justice for All Corporations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We seem to be moving toward the condition that Chief Justice Earl Warren decried in the 1956 case Griffin v. Illinois \xe2\x80\x94  that we have \xe2\x80\x9cone rule for rich and one for poor.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'John H. Geerken'b' Claremont, Calif., Dec. 28, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is emeritus professor of history at Scripps College.'b''b'Princeton, N.J.'b'NOW that the holidays are over, many disappointed gift-recipients are heading to the mall to return their useless, unattractive or thoughtless presents. Next year, why not spare them the trouble, and give cash instead?'b'It makes economic sense \xe2\x80\x94 many economists see cash as the most efficient gift, because it allows recipients to choose exactly what they want.'b'But this horrifies traditionalists, who see giving cash for Christmas as the ultimate commodification of a sacred ritual. Money is acceptable for charitable donations or bonuses, but certainly not for friends or family.'b'It turns out that both the economic realists who give money as presents and the traditionalists have history on their side, because this is a debate that began back in the early 20th century. As the consumer society expanded and Americans began giving more Christmas presents to more people, money emerged as an acceptable gift. Christmas money, according to a 1912 issue of Ladies\xe2\x80\x99 Home Journal, \xe2\x80\x9csupplies dearly cherished wishes, adds small luxuries, prevents worriment and gives opportunities for helpfulness as no other gift does.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But how was a recipient to know that a dollar was a gift dollar? That something made of the same legal tender used to buy the daily newspaper, tip waiters and bribe politicians was in fact a gift expressing personal affection?'b'The challenges of giving money were captured by this 1920s vaudeville act:'b''b'HE'b' It\xe2\x80\x99s bad form for a person to leave the price mark on a gift, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?'b''b'SHE'b' Yes, and I knew a woman who was so absent-minded that when she gave a $50 bill for a Christmas gift, she tried to rub the price mark off of it. ... She was giving the $50 bill to her married daughter, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t want her to know how much it was worth.'b''b'HE'b' And what did her married daughter do with the $50 bill, when she got it?'b''b'SHE'b' She took the money, and paid the grocer what she owed him.'b''b'HE'b' And what did her mother do?'b''b'SHE'b' Her mother cried, and said, although she loved to give a Christmas present, there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t much fun in paying her son-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s grocery bill.'b'The key to the problem, early 20th-century gift-givers found, was to camouflage money inside a traditional gift. This took effort and it had nothing to do with efficiency, but it enabled people to elevate the gift of cash.'b'In the December 1909 Ladies\xe2\x80\x99 Home Journal, for instance, the writer Lou Eleanor Colby said she had found a way to \xe2\x80\x9cdisguise the money so that it would not seem just like a commercial transaction.\xe2\x80\x9d    She explained how she had incorporated $10 for her mother into artwork. She inserted dollar bills into two posters; one showed five sad bills not knowing where to go, and the other depicted the happy ending: \xe2\x80\x9cfive little dollars speeding joyfully\xe2\x80\x9d toward her mother\xe2\x80\x99s purse.'b'Housewives hid gold coins in cookies and boxes of candies; dollar bills could decorate belt-buckles or picture frames. Women boasted when the recipient failed to realize that the actual present was money. Men also disguised the money they gave to their wives as gifts, to distinguish it from their allowances. If you give her a check, The Ladies\xe2\x80\x99 Home Journal advised, \xe2\x80\x9cput it in an embroidered purse, or a leather sewing basket or a jewel box which will be a little gift in itself.\xe2\x80\x9d The better the disguise, the more successful the gift.'b'Then, in 1910, American Express began advertising money orders as an \xe2\x80\x9cacceptable Christmas gift.\xe2\x80\x9d Western Union improved on the idea by creating distinctive telegrams for sending money for special occasions,  while greeting card companies started selling decorative money holders for birthdays and holidays.'b'After 1905, department stores even designed a new currency: gift certificates. Also called merchandise coupons or gift bonds, these were for a specific sum of money to be spent either on a designated type of merchandise \xe2\x80\x94 gloves and shoes were popular items \xe2\x80\x94 or, as today, on anything at all at a particular store.'b'We can\xe2\x80\x99t all be as clever as Lou Eleanor Colby, but buying a gift card that restricts what the money can be used for is just another way of distinguishing gift money from regular money, and a way for givers to demonstrate their intimate knowledge of what the recipient likes and cares about.'b'Nostalgic traditionalists and hard-nosed realists both get it wrong. For over a century, Americans have been demonstrating remarkable ingenuity in turning money into meaningful personal gifts. Let\xe2\x80\x99s keep it up. Next year, perhaps take a lesson from the pages of The Ladies\xe2\x80\x99 Home Journal and hide cash in a gift of your own creation.'b'The health care reform law was signed 10 months ago, and what\xe2\x80\x99s striking now is how vulnerable it looks. Several threats have emerged \xe2\x80\x94 some of them scarcely discussed before passage \xe2\x80\x94 that together or alone could seriously endanger the new system. These include:'b''b'The courts.'b' So far, one judge has struck down the individual mandate, the plan\xe2\x80\x99s centerpiece. Future decisions are likely to break down on partisan lines. Given the makeup of the Supreme Court, this should concern the law\xe2\x80\x99s defenders.'b''b'False projections.'b' The new system is based on a series of expert projections on how people will behave. In the first test case, these projections were absurdly off base. According to the Medicare actuary, 375,000 people should have already signed up for the new high-risk pools for the uninsured, but only 8,000 have.'b'More seriously, cost projections are way off. For example, New Hampshire\xe2\x80\x99s plan has only about 80 members, but the state has already burned through nearly double the $650,000 that the federal government allotted to help run the program. If other projections are off by this much, the results will be disastrous.'b''b'Employee dumping.'b' This is the most serious threat. Companies and unions across America are running the numbers and discovering they would be better off if, after 2014, they induced poorer and sicker employees to move to public insurance exchanges, where subsidies are much higher.'b'The number of people in those exchanges could thus skyrocket, especially as startup companies undermine their competitors with uninsured employees and lower costs. The Congressional Budget Office projects that 19 million people will move to the exchanges at a cost of $450 billion between 2014 and 2019. But according to the economists Douglas Holtz-Eakin and James C. Capretta, costs could soar to $1.4 trillion if those who would be better off in the exchanges actually moved to them. The price of the health care law could double. 'b'C. Eugene Steuerle of the Urban Institute'b', who has been among those raising the alarms about this, calls the law\xe2\x80\x99s structure \xe2\x80\x9cunworkable and unfair.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Health care oligarchy.'b' Since the law passed, there has been a frenzy of mergers and acquisitions, as hospitals, clinics and doctor groups have joined together into bigger and bigger entities. The drafters encourage this, believing large outfits would be more efficient. The downside to this economic concentration is there could be less competition and cost control. In many places, the political power of these quasi-monopolies would be huge, with unforeseeable results. The law bans doctors from starting up hospitals to increase competition.'b''b'Public hostility.'b' Right now about 53 percent of Americans oppose the health care law and 43 percent support it, according to an average of the recent polls. Complaints are especially high among doctors. According to a survey by the Physicians Foundation, 60 percent of private practice doctors say the law will force them to close their practices or to restrict them to certain categories of patients.'b'Given this level of unhappiness, people will blame the Obama law for everything they hate about the health care system. Political opposition was fierce last November, and it could easily shape the 2012 election and lead to changes or repeal.'b'Over all, there is a strong likelihood that the current health care law will face an existential threat over the next five years. Each party should be preparing contingency plans.'b'When the crisis comes, Democrats will face an interesting choice \xe2\x80\x94 to patch the Obama system or try to replace it with something bigger. The administration may want a patch, but by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1, according to a CNN poll, Democratic voters would prefer a more ambitious law. Liberals could logically say that the mistake was trying to create a hybrid system, rather than moving straight to a single-payer one.'b'Republicans are going to have to move beyond their current \xe2\x80\x9cRepeal!\xe2\x80\x9d posture and cohere behind a positive alternative. One approach, which Tyler Cowen of George Mason University has written about, is to allow more state experimentation. Another approach, championed by Capretta, 'b'Yuval Levin'b' of National Affairs and 'b'Thomas P. Miller'b' of the American Enterprise Institute, revolves around the words \xe2\x80\x9cdefined contribution.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Under this approach, Republicans would say that the federal government has a role in subsidizing health insurance \xe2\x80\x94 a generous role, but not unlimited. The government would provide needy citizens with a predefined amount of money to spend on insurance and allow them to shop in a transparent, regulated, but not micromanaged marketplace.'b'After the trauma of the last two years, many people wish the issue would go away. But it\xe2\x80\x99s not going away, especially since costs will continue to rise.'b'Some Congresses achieve health care; members of this Congress or the next one will have health care thrust upon them.'b'New Haven'b'FIFTY years ago this week, President Dwight D. Eisenhower\xe2\x80\x99s administration 'b'broke off diplomatic relations'b' with Fidel Castro\xe2\x80\x99s government, placing Cuba in the middle of the cold war and changing my life, and that of many of my fellow Cubans, forever.'b'By January 1961, I had spent a year and a half in Tampa, Fla., where relatives of mine had lived since the 1930s, and where my parents had settled us in 1959, planning to spend as much time as it took for life to return to normal in Cuba, or perhaps to stay.'b'I was 17 and had gone back to the island about six times. This was because I had left behind my girlfriend, Mercy, and also because I could not get used to American life, particularly teenage mores, which I found silly. (\xe2\x80\x9cTeenager\xe2\x80\x9d did not exist as a role in Cuban culture.) I saved every penny from my various jobs as dishwasher and bag-boy to buy those plane tickets.'b'But with the diplomatic rupture, my travels were over. Though I did not know it at the time, Eisenhower\xe2\x80\x99s decision turned me into an exile. I would not set foot on Cuba again for 18 years, when I went with a committee of exiles to discuss the release of political prisoners.'b'Though many Cubans in circumstances similar to mine became American citizens at the first opportunity, wisely aware that their displacement was permanent, I refused to do so because I na\xc3\xafvely associated citizenship and nationality. I clung to my Cuban citizenship, though my Cuban passport soon expired, and as a \xe2\x80\x9cpermanent resident\xe2\x80\x9d of the United States had to travel abroad using a re-entry permit, an awkward document that gave proof, among other things, that I had paid my taxes. Travel through Europe and Latin America required an assortment of visas, but I thought the difficulties were worth it because they allowed me to preserve my identity.'b'I also latched on to my native culture by making the study of Spanish and Latin American literature my life\xe2\x80\x99s work, and in a sense I relived my traumatic acquisition of English as a teenager by learning French and Italian at the University of South Florida with pathological zeal. When I spoke those languages I assumed new personae; they were shields against an American culture I still could not quite absorb. Instead of freezing me into a role, the 1961 break in relations between my two countries transformed me into a man with several voices within my own head, a perspective that has informed my literary criticism, I believe.'b'Now I am safely far from what I derisively call (to tease my American children and grandchildren) \xe2\x80\x9cteenagehood in America.\xe2\x80\x9d I am a citizen of the United States, rejoicing in this country\xe2\x80\x99s democracy which, for all its faults, is the best form of government to which we can aspire. Fifty years after the break in relations, while Cuba is still ruled by a male, white, militaristic, totalitarian gerontocracy, Barack Obama is the president of the United States and Hillary Clinton the secretary of state. Which of my two countries is the revolutionary one?'b'In that half-century, Fidel and Ra\xc3\xbal Castro have managed to run into the ground what was a prosperous country, to drive a million and a half of its citizens into exile and to fill the jails with political and common prisoners. Recent changes in the Cuban economy, conciliatory gestures toward the church and the release and deportation of some political prisoners show that the Castros are aware of the instability of their system \xe2\x80\x94 which Fidel Castro not long ago 'b'blurted out'b' does not even work in Cuba.'b'The one change that they have not dared to make, however, is to remove fear from Cuban life, because it is the glue that holds together their government. Fear of being accused by a neighbor who belongs to one of the vigilante Committees for the Defense of the Revolution; fear that the secret police will find something to incriminate you; fear that you will be jailed without charges for months or even years; fear that the government-sponsored mobs called Rapid Response Brigades will stage a violent rejection rally in front of your house (as has happened to the mother of Orlando Zapata Tamayo, 'b'the dissident who died during his prison hunger strike'b' last February); fear that you will be denied your request to travel abroad; fear that you will lose your job; fear, in short, that the long arm of power will reach down to you and smite you.'b'I am very happy to be here, free from all of those fears and hoping against reason that the next historical break in Cuba will not be a violent one, and that it will bring about a future of peace, prosperity and democracy.'b'With no more flights to Havana, and having met other girls, I wrote Mercy a letter in 1961 breaking up. I still feel shame for having done this. She came to Miami with her family shortly thereafter and we had an emotional meeting in Tampa when they visited us. But it was over. I have been told that this delicate, petite piano player who wanted to be a kindergarten teacher married a pilot, learned to fly a plane (coincidentally, so did I) and even does sky diving (I would never).'b'It is a constant of history: political decisions affect ordinary lives in unexpected and often permanent ways.'b'These are tough times for state governments. Huge deficits loom almost everywhere, from California to New York, from New Jersey to Texas.'b'Wait  \xe2\x80\x94 Texas? Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Texas supposed to be thriving even as the rest of America suffered? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t its governor declare, during his re-election campaign, that \xe2\x80\x9cwe have billions in surplus\xe2\x80\x9d? Yes, it was, and yes, he did. But reality has now intruded, in the form of a deficit expected to run as high as $25 billion over the next two years.'b'And that reality has implications for the nation as a whole. For Texas is where the modern conservative theory of budgeting  \xe2\x80\x94 the belief that you should never raise taxes under any circumstances, that you can always balance the budget by cutting wasteful spending  \xe2\x80\x94 has been implemented most completely. If the theory can\xe2\x80\x99t make it there, it can\xe2\x80\x99t make it anywhere.'b'How bad is the Texas deficit? Comparing budget crises among states is tricky, for technical reasons. Still, data from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities suggest that the Texas budget gap is worse than New York\xe2\x80\x99s, about as bad as California\xe2\x80\x99s, but not quite up to New Jersey levels.'b'The point, however, is that just the other day Texas was being touted as a role model (and still is by commentators who haven\xe2\x80\x99t been keeping up with the news). It was the state the recession supposedly passed by, thanks to its low taxes and business-friendly policies. Its governor boasted that its budget was in good shape thanks to his \xe2\x80\x9ctough conservative decisions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Oh, and at a time when there\xe2\x80\x99s a full-court press on to demonize public-sector unions as the source of all our woes, Texas is nearly demon-free: less than 20 percent of public-sector workers there are covered by union contracts, compared with almost 75 percent in New York.'b'So what happened to the \xe2\x80\x9cTexas miracle\xe2\x80\x9d many people were talking about even a few months ago?'b'Part of the answer is that reports of a recession-proof state were greatly exaggerated. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that Texas job losses haven\xe2\x80\x99t been as severe as those in the nation as a whole since the recession began in 2007. But Texas has a rapidly growing population \xe2\x80\x94 largely, suggests Harvard\xe2\x80\x99s Edward Glaeser, because its liberal land-use and zoning policies have kept housing cheap. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong with that; but given that rising population, Texas needs to create jobs more rapidly than the rest of the country just to keep up with a growing work force.'b'And when you look at unemployment, Texas doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem particularly special: its unemployment rate is below the national average, thanks in part to high oil prices, but it\xe2\x80\x99s about the same as the unemployment rate in New York or Massachusetts.'b'What about the budget? The truth is that the Texas state government has relied for years on smoke and mirrors to create the illusion of sound finances in the face of a serious \xe2\x80\x9cstructural\xe2\x80\x9d budget deficit \xe2\x80\x94 that is, a deficit that persists even when the economy is doing well. When the recession struck, hitting revenue in Texas just as it did everywhere else, that illusion was bound to collapse.'b'The only thing that let Gov. Rick Perry get away, temporarily, with claims of a surplus was the fact that Texas enacts budgets only once every two years, and the last budget was put in place before the depth of the economic downturn was clear. Now the next budget must be passed \xe2\x80\x94 and Texas may have a $25 billion hole to fill. Now what?'b'Given the complete dominance of conservative ideology in Texas politics, tax increases are out of the question. So it has to be spending cuts.'b'Yet Mr. Perry wasn\xe2\x80\x99t lying about those \xe2\x80\x9ctough conservative decisions\xe2\x80\x9d: Texas has indeed taken a hard, you might say brutal, line toward its most vulnerable citizens. Among the states, Texas ranks near the bottom in education spending per pupil, while leading the nation in the percentage of residents without health insurance. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine what will happen if the state tries to eliminate its huge deficit purely through further cuts.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how the mess in Texas will end up being resolved. But the signs don\xe2\x80\x99t look good, either for the state or for the nation.'b'Right now, triumphant conservatives in Washington are declaring that they can cut taxes and still balance the budget by slashing spending. Yet they haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to do that even in Texas, which is willing both to impose great pain (by its stinginess on health care) and to shortchange the future (by neglecting education). How are they supposed to pull it off nationally, especially when the incoming Republicans have declared Medicare, Social Security and defense off limits?'b'People used to say that the future happens first in California, but these days what happens in Texas is probably a better omen. And what we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing right now is a future that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work.'b'Members of the House might have thought they were bringing the Constitution alive by reading it aloud on Thursday. But they made a crucial error by excising its history. When they chose to deliberately drop the sections that became obsolete or offensive, and which were later amended, they missed a chance to demonstrate that this document is not nailed to the door of the past. It remains vital precisely because it can be reimagined.'b'Having decided to spend their first moments in power proclaiming their devotion to the Constitution, Republican leaders might at least have read the whole thing. The part, for instance, where slaves \xe2\x80\x9cbound to service\xe2\x80\x9d are counted as three-fifths of a person. The part where fugitive slaves cannot gain their freedom by escaping to a free state. Or the part where ordinary citizens do not  actually get a direct vote for their senator.'b'All these provisions were written by a group of men that many in the Tea Party and elsewhere seem to consider infallible and nearly divine. The Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s words are a stirring proclamation of freedom across the ages. But some passages are artifacts of their time.'b'Incensed by this rewriting of history, Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., Democrat of Illinois, arose just before the reading to remind the House of what it was redacting. African-Americans and women struggled for decades to be granted the right to vote, he said, and those struggles are clearly reflected in the text. \xe2\x80\x9cMany of us don\xe2\x80\x99t want that to be lost upon the reading of our sacred document,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'But imperfection and change were not the point. The reading was conceived so that Republicans could demonstrate their fidelity to the document and make it seem as though Democrats had abandoned it. After protests, the leadership invited Democrats to join them, and many of them did. It was a stirring moment when John Lewis of Georgia, an icon of the civil rights movement, read to great applause the 13th Amendment, abolishing slavery.'b'That was about all that was stirring. Because so many members wanted a piece of the action, the text\xe2\x80\x99s momentum was broken up by an endless parade of flat, one-sentence recitations, and many lawmakers later returned to their BlackBerrys or left the chamber.'b'The Constitution deserves better than this airless exercise. It was a work of political genius, largely because its authors handed its interpretation to the open minds of posterity. The effect of Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s reading, in case anyone was actually paying attention, was to wrongly suggest that the document was seamless and perfect, as if carved in marble rather than stained with sweat and American blood.'b'Gov. Andrew Cuomo struck just the right tone on both adult prison reform and juvenile justice reform in his first State of the State address on Wednesday. He said that New York could no longer afford to keep hugely expensive but unneeded facilities open to serve as \xe2\x80\x9can employment program\xe2\x80\x9d for upstate residents.'b'To get the Legislature to agree to shut these facilities, Mr. Cuomo will have to push back hard against the corrections workers\xe2\x80\x99 unions that have thwarted sound closure proposals from all three of his predecessors.'b'The case for closures is laid out in a new analysis by the Correctional Association of New York, a nonprofit group. New York\xe2\x80\x99s prison population has dropped from about 71,500 at its peak in 1999 to around 56,000 today. This has left more than 8,000 empty beds, meaning that the state could close or significantly downsize eight to 10 of the 67 units in the system and still have ample room to handle any unexpected spike in the population. The savings would be $220 million in the first year.'b'The state could also save money by reversing misguided criminal-justice policies. In 1995, Gov. George Pataki prohibited people convicted of violent crimes from participating in work-release programs. That order cut the number of participants from nearly 28,000 in 1994 to about 2,500 in 2007, the most recent year for which the association has data.'b'The point of Mr. Pataki\xe2\x80\x99s order was to protect the public from violent offenders, but it may well have had the opposite effect. Once they had done their time, inmates were dumped onto the streets without any chance to reacclimate and find their place in the community. Work-release programs cost about $7,500 per participant annually, as opposed to about $55,000 to keep one person behind bars. Increasing the number of participants to  just 5,000 would save more than $80 million a year.'b'The state also needs to reform a parole system that returns as many as 8,000 inmates a year to prison for technical violations like breaking curfew. Other states have shown that they can keep the prison count down, at no risk to the public, by increasing supervision of violators instead of reflexively bouncing them back to jail.'b'These will be tough political fights. But for the sake of both fiscal sanity and sound public policy, they are ones that Governor Cuomo needs to fight and win.'b'MORRIS, the name of the online catalog of the Yale Law School Library, is not an acronym. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tribute to Morris Cohen, the school\xe2\x80\x99s longtime librarian and law professor, who died in December at 83 and was one of America\xe2\x80\x99s great scholarly librarians.'b'In its whimsy and pithiness \xe2\x80\x94 and as a link to a powerful tool of legal research \xe2\x80\x94 the name conveys his core values. He became a librarian after seven not very satisfying years as a lawyer. The late start led to an insistent focus on law librarianship as a service to legal practice and scholarship, and an insistence on providing that service his own way.'b'One of his most creative efforts was his collection of children\xe2\x80\x99s books related to law. What began in the 1960s as a hobby for Professor Cohen and his young son would eventually become the Yale Law Library\xe2\x80\x99s noteworthy collection of 200 publications described as \xe2\x80\x9cjuvenile jurisprudence.\xe2\x80\x9d It includes a noirish Classics Illustrated comic book of Dostoevsky\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCrime and Punishment\xe2\x80\x9d;  engrossing stories about pirates combining terror and adventure; and beautifully illustrated, moralizing accounts of trials conducted by animals, like \xe2\x80\x9cWho Killed Cock Robin?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Professor Cohen saw law, its study and its practice, as a bountiful, all-encompassing, humanistic field. As the librarians he trained explain, he was delighted by nearly all legal writings because they contain important codes to be deciphered about how different eras and societies viewed the role of law.'b'Professor Cohen\xe2\x80\x99s other extraordinary contribution is his magnum opus, the \xe2\x80\x9cBibliography of Early American Law,\xe2\x80\x9d which took him and a large team three decades to compile. Seven volumes, and breathtakingly rigorous, it allows users to find virtually any of the 15,000 or so law texts published in America before 1860. Along with statutes and court opinions, it includes ballads, sermons and fiction as well as children\xe2\x80\x99s books, underscoring Professor Cohen\xe2\x80\x99s conviction that law is transmitted through channels far outside the law.'b'In an age when the Internet, including MORRIS, gives many the illusion they are scholarly detectives, the meticulous, old-fashioned research he put into the bibliography is almost unfathomable. It yielded a resource that is matchless, brilliant and of eternal value.'b'To the Editor:'b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Giving Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s Patients Their Way, Even Doses of Chocolate'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Vanishing Mind\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Jan. 1) is both heartening and maddening.'b'It is heartening to know that attention is being paid to the most fundamental ways to make the lives of Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s patients in nursing homes less anxiety-filled and stressful.'b'It is maddening because everything the Beatitudes nursing home in Phoenix is doing has been required by federal law since 1990: allowing residents to eat, sleep and bathe on their own schedules; keeping people out of diapers; minimizing the use of physical and chemical restraints and offering activities that relate to the individual\xe2\x80\x99s past life interests.'b'The reduction in use of antipsychotic drugs is particularly noteworthy: nearly 40 percent of nursing home residents with dementia and behavior issues are given antipsychotic drugs with no diagnosis appropriate to their use. Zietman'b'\nFairfax, Va., Dec. 29, 2010'b''b''b'The writer, a radiation oncologist, is chairman of the American Society for Radiation Oncology.'b''b'The document released Wednesday by the presidential commission investigating last spring\xe2\x80\x99s oil blowout in the Gulf of Mexico is a riveting and chilling indictment of \xe2\x80\x9csystemic failures\xe2\x80\x9d throughout the oil business and of the federal agencies that allowed themselves to be captured by the people they were supposed to regulate.'b'The commission will offer specific recommendations for reform in its full report next Tuesday. But the chapter it decided to release early is, by itself, a powerful summons to the Obama administration to press rapidly forward with stronger regulations, and to the industry as a whole to behave far more responsibly than it has.'b'Another tragedy like the one in the Gulf of Mexico could well occur, the report suggests, unless there is \xe2\x80\x9csignificant reform in both industry practices and government policies.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The panel traced the blowout to three main factors:'b''b''b'MANAGERIAL FOUL-UPS:'b''b' The most significant failure and \xe2\x80\x9croot cause\xe2\x80\x9d of the blowout was a seemingly endless series of fateful missteps and oversights by BP and its partners \xe2\x80\x94 Transocean and Halliburton \xe2\x80\x94 that, in retrospect, could have been avoided. These decisions included not installing enough devices to stabilize the well, not waiting for the results of tests on the foam used to seal the well, and ignoring the results of an important  pressure test. Taken together, these and other blunders allowed gases to enter the well and rise with explosive and ultimately disastrous force to the drilling rig.'b''b''b'SYSTEMIC FAILURE:'b''b' Though BP in particular has been accused of putting profit before safety, the report avoided linking any individual decision to cost considerations. Even so, BP and its partners repeatedly chose the riskier, speedier course instead of a slower and safer alternative. As Bob Graham, the commission co-chairman, noted in a separate statement, \xe2\x80\x9cThis disaster likely would not have happened had the companies involved been guided by an unrelenting commitment to safety first.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The report further asserted that this risk-taking was not unique to BP or its partners in the well, that the blowout was \xe2\x80\x9cnot the product of a series of aberrational decisions\xe2\x80\x9d made by a rogue company, but, instead, reflected an industrywide proclivity for risky behavior. \xe2\x80\x9cDo we have a single company, BP, that blundered with fatal consequences,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the other co-chairman, William Reilly, \xe2\x80\x9cor a more pervasive problem of a complacent industry?\xe2\x80\x9d Sadly, Mr. Reilly said, it is the latter.'b''b''b'REGULATORY WEAKNESS:'b''b' As expected, the panel took federal regulators in the old Minerals Management Service to task for a range of mistakes, like rubber-stamping drilling permits and failing to oversee operations on the rig. These failures are hardly new. For years, the service has had neither the will nor the resources to police the industry.'b'Since the blowout, the Obama administration has reorganized the regulatory apparatus to give it greater independence. It has also issued and is now enforcing specific safety regulations and increased surveillance on individual rigs. All this is welcome, but the administration has a long way to go. What is at issue here is nothing less than remaking the culture of an entire industry.'b'On Sunday, southern Sudan is expected to vote to secede from Sudan, creating two states. The referendum is part of a 2005 agreement, which ended two decades of fighting between the Arab Muslim north and the largely Christian south that killed two million people.'b'International activists were so concerned that the referendum could set off a new war that they posted a live satellite feed of Sudan on the Internet so the world can see if troops begin massing. Their fears are understandable, especially with Omar Hassan al-Bashir \xe2\x80\x94 the author of the murderous war in Darfur \xe2\x80\x94 still Sudan\xe2\x80\x99s president. But months of mediation by the Obama administration and African leaders seem to have persuaded Mr. Bashir to forgo confrontation, for now. The United States and others must stay involved to ensure that the difficult post-referendum transition remains peaceful.'b'More than 3.5 million southerners have registered to vote and a United Nations panel has endorsed the process. This week, Mr. Bashir visited Juba, the south\xe2\x80\x99s capital, to espouse peace. \xe2\x80\x9cWe cannot deny the desire and the choice of the people of the south,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Southern Sudan has 75 percent of the oil, but needs the north\xe2\x80\x99s pipeline to get it to market.'b'The two sides failed to resolve an impasse over the oil-rich border region of Abyei, so another referendum that had been set for Sunday \xe2\x80\x94 on whether it should join the south or stay with the north \xe2\x80\x94  has been delayed. There is now talk of trying to settle things through negotiations. What is most important is that leaders in the north and south explain to their citizens what is happening and work toward a swift, sustainable solution.'b'The United States, the United Nations and the African Union will have to remain deeply engaged, prodding both states to compromise on these difficult issues. United Nations peacekeepers, sent to Sudan in 2005, should stay in southern Sudan temporarily to maintain security.'b'Washington has tough sanctions on Sudan, as a result of its early harboring of Osama bin Laden and then Mr. Bashir\xe2\x80\x99s genocidal war in Darfur. The governor is presenting this as an \xe2\x80\x9cunavoidable\xe2\x80\x9d consequence of \xe2\x80\x9cdire fiscal circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d but it is in fact a matter of choice. Chris Christie chose not to do that.'b'The Education Law Center has shown how the shortfall has reduced teaching, learning and, in some schools, safety, because of cutbacks in security. It means the state cannot provide \xe2\x80\x9ca constitutional education to all public school students.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The center took the issue back to the court. The right decision is clear. The shortfall in money and other defaults amount to \xe2\x80\x9cdeficiencies of a constitutional dimension,\xe2\x80\x9d which the court had warned would lead it to step in again. The justices should order the state to fully finance education as it committed to do.'b'In 1975, the court seemed to anticipate today\xe2\x80\x99s financing challenge. It found that any \xe2\x80\x9ctheoretical conflict\xe2\x80\x9d in the state Constitution between \xe2\x80\x9cthe strictures of the Appropriations Clause and the mandate of the Education Clause\xe2\x80\x9d must be resolved in education\xe2\x80\x99s favor. When the state failed to finance education at the level required, the court cut off state financing altogether.'b'The court now faces a politically charged decision. As bombastically as he seems to do everything, Mr. Christie is waging a battle against the court and what he calls its activism. (That has nothing to do with actual activism, but applies only to judges who rule in ways Republicans don\xe2\x80\x99t like.) If the governor were a student of the court instead of its heckler, he would know the court\xe2\x80\x99s role here is judicially modest.'b'The state set the education standards that students must meet. The state decided how much money was needed to give each student the chance to meet them. The court\xe2\x80\x99s role is simply to assess whether, by those measures, current financing is adequate.'b'It would be natural for the justices to seek a unanimous ruling in a case this important, to underscore that the decision is being made by a coequal branch of government. The appeal of a unanimous ruling is most likely greater because of the governor\xe2\x80\x99s attack on the court. But the best reason for a unanimous ruling is the law. The court should order the state to solve this problem.'b'To keep the Defense Department running, President Obama was forced to sign a spending bill on Friday with a particularly harmful provision that bars spending to transfer detainees at Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, Cuba, to the United States for trial. As wrongheaded as this prohibition is, the president was right not to declare his intention to defy it'b' in an accompanying statement'b'. By doing so, he demonstrated a greater respect for the law than did President George W. Bush.'b'The defense bill passed in the final hours of last year\xe2\x80\x99s lame-duck Congressional session with little objection from most Democrats. Many seemed to have bought into the irrational fear that trying Guant\xc3\xa1namo prisoners in the United States is somehow more dangerous than trying other mass murderers, like the scores of terrorists already convicted by the federal courts.'b'Much of the public and most politicians seem to feel that as long as these suspects are held out of sight on the island of Cuba, they can be held indefinitely without trial, in violation of basic constitutional protections and international treaties.'b'President Obama could have pushed harder on this issue, but he has at least vowed to close the Guant\xc3\xa1namo camp and try some of its inmates in federal courts. In the signing statement, Mr. Obama called the ban \xe2\x80\x9ca dangerous and unprecedented challenge\xe2\x80\x9d to the executive branch\xe2\x80\x99s authority to decide when and where to prosecute detainees. It could undermine counterterrorism efforts and harm national security, he said.'b'Despite his objections, Mr. Obama did not say he would defy the law and try to transfer prisoners anyway. That was the right position. As a candidate, he often objected to Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s cavalier use of signing statements to assert that his interpretation of the law trumped that of Congress and the courts. Mr. Bush routinely and contemptuously disregarded laws that he himself signed, most famously stating that he was not bound by the ban on torturing prisoners.'b'The 'b'American Civil Liberties Union argues'b' that the bill only restricts the use of Defense Department money for transferring prisoners to the United States. The administration, it argues, is free to use funds from other departments. But such a cramped reading of the law would be seen by most Americans as a defiance of Congressional intent. Taking the high ground puts President Obama in a better position to argue for the rule of law.'b'The new year is barely a week old, but the nation has already recorded its first deadly school shooting.'b'On Wednesday, a 17-year-old student opened fire at Millard South High School in Omaha, sending students rushing to the kitchen to seek safety. According to the report, the unaffiliated (atheists, agnostics, the unchurched, uncommitted, etc.), at 16.1 percent of the population, is the largest religious group in America without representation in Congress. (Six members, about 1 percent, did not specify a religious category.)'b'For perspective, there are almost two-thirds as many unaffiliated people as there are Catholics in this country and nearly as many as there are Baptists. Their number is  more than twice that of Methodists, and more than nine times the numbers of Jews or Mormons. Yet, no unaffiliated representation. Why?'b'First, let me get this out of the way: I don\xe2\x80\x99t for a second believe that all those members are religious. I believe some are trapped in the religious closet of American politics where nonbelief is a nonstarter. It\xe2\x80\x99s not only seen as unholy, it\xe2\x80\x99s also seen as un-American. (Although Pete Stark, a California Democrat and a Unitarian, has said that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t believe in a Supreme Being. One out!)'b'Second, and perhaps more important, the unaffiliated are simply not unified. They have few advocacy groups or high-profile faces. They don\xe2\x80\x99t congregate, organize or petition like members of organized religions. Politicians don\xe2\x80\x99t feel the need to court them, let alone identify as one of them. Part of the problem is that the unaffiliated are a jumbled lot. Only about a fourth are atheists or agnostics. Many of the others feel strongly connected to religion, but choose not to participate. It\xe2\x80\x99s like a protest vote.'b'Whether they are organized, cohesive or disgruntled, the unaffiliated are the fastest-growing religious category in America. Nonaffiliation is not un-American. Increasingly, it is America. Eventually, our politics will have to catch up.'b'Next week the House Republicans are going to vote to repeal the health care reform law. And that, of course, is the only thing that really matters.'b'WHEN the new House of Representatives convened on Thursday, the Republican leadership kept its promise to start the session 'b'by reading the text of the Constitution aloud.'b' This break from Congressional tradition had a polemical purpose: Representative Robert Goodlatte, the Virginia Republican who came up with the idea, remarked that \xe2\x80\x9clots of my constituents have said that Congress has gone beyond its powers granted in the Constitution.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If the reading was meant to be a win for originalism, however, it stumbled out of the gate, over the text of Article I, Section 2. This deals with the apportionment of House seats among the states, which is said to be based on \xe2\x80\x9cthe whole number of free persons\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthree-fifths of all other persons.\xe2\x80\x9d Rather than draw attention to this infamous euphemism for slaves, the Congressional readers decided to omit those portions, on the grounds that they had been superseded by the 14th Amendment.'b'It just so happened this conspicuous omission came days after a small publisher, NewSouth Books, announced 'b'a new edition of Mark Twain\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d'b' that will replace its uses of the word \xe2\x80\x9cnigger\xe2\x80\x9d with \xe2\x80\x9cslave.\xe2\x80\x9d Here, again, was a historic text clashing with contemporary sensibilities, and forced to submit.'b'Taken together, the two cases show the comedy of euphemism: trying to distract us from something ugly only makes the ugliness harder to miss. To the book\xe2\x80\x99s new editor, the Twain scholar Alan Gribben, \xe2\x80\x9cslave\xe2\x80\x9d is less offensive than \xe2\x80\x9cnigger\xe2\x80\x9d; to the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s drafters, \xe2\x80\x9call other persons\xe2\x80\x9d was less offensive than \xe2\x80\x9cslave.\xe2\x80\x9d By refusing to utter even that legalism, the House showed that euphemism can end only in embarrassed silence.'b'The censored edition of \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d has been loudly condemned. Certainly, as a writer, I see the strength of all the arguments against tinkering with the original, not least because it would be a terrible precedent \xe2\x80\x94 start eliminating everything offensive in literary history, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll have little left. But once I returned to the actual novel, I began to feel torn, because I could imagine the effect that its deluge of epithets would have on a young reader, especially a young black reader. (Open the book to the passage in the second chapter that begins, \xe2\x80\x9cStrange niggers would stand with their mouths open,\xe2\x80\x9d and see if you would be able to read it to a room full of ninth graders.)'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d was intended, of course, as an attack on racism. In its most famous scene, Huck hides the runaway slave Jim from a party of slave-hunters, and then feels guilty for having done so. \xe2\x80\x9cI knowed very well I had done wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, though the reader, and Twain, know he has done right. It\xe2\x80\x99s a searching demonstration of the way conscience is not just innate but also learned, and how confusing it can be to do right in a society dedicated to wrong \xe2\x80\x94 the same kinds of questions that bedeviled Hannah Arendt at the Eichmann trial.'b'Yet all those racial epithets are a reminder that, when Twain wrote it, the audience he had in mind \xe2\x80\x94 the America for which he wrote \xe2\x80\x94 was segregated. He did not worry about constantly writing \xe2\x80\x9cnigger,\xe2\x80\x9d because he was writing about blacks, not for them. And for many readers, encountering classic literature means sometimes finding yourself excluded, or insulted, in this way. For blacks reading Twain, certainly, but also for Jews reading Shakespeare or Dickens, and for women reading, say, Plato (among countless others).'b'But the books we cherish, which deserve the name of classics, feel essentially humane to us, despite their limitations, even their bigotry. \xe2\x80\x9cI sit with Shakespeare and he winces not,\xe2\x80\x9d W. E. B. DuBois said. We feel that the exclusion of whole classes of humanity from the author\xe2\x80\x99s imagined audience \xe2\x80\x94 which means, from his idea of the fully human \xe2\x80\x94 is due to ignorance or carelessness; that if he were to think and feel more freely, more deeply, he would acknowledge that all people are equally human.'b'This is also the promise of American history, and above all of the Constitution. Unlike Twain\xe2\x80\x99s novel, that classic American text was written in the expectation that it would be corrected. And it needed correction, or amendment, for the same essential reason: the framers\xe2\x80\x99 imagination of the people they led was not full enough. It took a devastating civil war, whose sesquicentennial we are now observing, to revise the Constitution in the direction of justice. When the House readers decided to skip the parts of the Constitution that reveal its original limitations, they were minimizing that history, pretending that our founding document was flawless from the beginning.'b'No, Congress may not go \xe2\x80\x9cbeyond its powers granted in the Constitution,\xe2\x80\x9d as Representative Goodlatte insisted. But to believe that American institutions were ever perfect makes it too easy to believe that they are perfect now. Both assumptions, one might say, are sins against the true spirit of the Constitution, which demands that we keep reimagining our way to a more perfect union.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Families Bear Brunt of Deployment Strains'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cA Year at War\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Dec. 31):'b'The pattern of multiple deployments imposed on a small segment of enlistment-age individuals in the United States is inequitable and discriminatory. Yet today \xe2\x80\x94 after 50 years of civil wars that have killed two million people and turned millions more into refugees \xe2\x80\x94 this is the opportunity before the people of southern Sudan.'b'Over the next week, 'b'millions of southern Sudanese will vote'b' on whether to remain part of Sudan or to form their own independent nation.  This process \xe2\x80\x94 and the actions of Sudanese leaders \xe2\x80\x94 will help determine whether people who have known so much suffering will move toward peace and prosperity, or slide backward into bloodshed. It will have consequences not only for Sudan, but also for sub-Saharan Africa and the world.'b'The historic vote is an exercise in self-determination long in the making, and it is a key part of the 2005 peace agreement that ended the civil war in Sudan. Yet just months ago, with preparations behind schedule, it was uncertain whether this referendum would take place at all. It is for this reason that 'b'I gathered with leaders from Sudan'b' and around the world in September to make it clear that the international community was united in its belief that this referendum had to take place and that the will of the people of southern Sudan had to be respected, regardless of the outcome.'b'In an important step forward, leaders from both northern and southern Sudan \xe2\x80\x94 backed by more than 40 nations and international organizations \xe2\x80\x94 agreed to work together to ensure that the voting would be  timely, peaceful, free and credible and would reflect the will of the Sudanese people. The fact that the voting appears to be starting on time is a tribute to those in Sudan who fulfilled their commitments. Most recently, the government of Sudan said that it would be the first to recognize the south if it voted for independence.'b'Now, the world is watching, united in its determination to make sure that all parties in Sudan live up to their obligations. As the referendum proceeds, voters must be allowed access to polling stations; they must be able to cast their ballots free from intimidation and coercion. All sides should refrain from inflammatory rhetoric or provocative actions that could raise tensions or prevent voters from expressing their will.'b'As the ballots are counted, all sides must resist prejudging the outcome. For the results to be credible, the commission that is overseeing the referendum must be free from pressure and interference. In the days ahead, leaders from north and south will need to work together to prevent violence and ensure that isolated incidents do not spiral into wider instability. Under no circumstance should any side use proxy forces in an effort to gain an advantage while we wait for the final results.'b'A successful vote will be cause for celebration and an inspiring step forward in Africa\xe2\x80\x99s long journey toward democracy and justice. Still, lasting peace in Sudan will demand far more than a credible referendum.'b'The 2005 peace agreement must be fully implemented \xe2\x80\x94 a goal that will require compromise. Border disputes, and the status of the Abyei region, which straddles north and south,  need to be resolved peacefully. The safety and citizenship of all Sudanese, especially minorities \xe2\x80\x94 southerners in the north and northerners in the south \xe2\x80\x94 have to be protected. Arrangements must be made for the transparent distribution of oil revenues, which can contribute to development. The return of refugees needs to be managed with extraordinary care to prevent another humanitarian catastrophe.'b'If the south chooses independence, the international community, including the United States, will have an interest in ensuring that the two nations that emerge succeed as stable and economically viable neighbors, because their fortunes are linked. Southern Sudan, in particular, will need partners in the long-term task of fulfilling the political and economic aspirations of its people.'b'Finally, there can be no lasting peace in Sudan without lasting peace in the western Sudan region of Darfur. The deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent Darfuris \xe2\x80\x94 and the plight of refugees like those I met in a camp in neighboring Chad five years ago \xe2\x80\x94 must never be forgotten.  Here, too, the world is watching. The government of Sudan must live up to its international obligations. Attacks on civilians must stop. United Nations peacekeepers and aid workers must be free to reach those in need.'b'As I told Sudanese leaders in September, the United States will not abandon the people of Darfur. We will continue our diplomatic efforts to end the crisis there once and for all. Other nations must use their influence to bring all parties to the table and ensure they negotiate in good faith. And we will continue to insist that lasting peace in Darfur include accountability for crimes that have been committed, including genocide.'b'Along with our international partners, the United States will continue to play a leadership role in helping all the Sudanese people realize the peace and progress they deserve. Today, I am repeating my offer to Sudan\xe2\x80\x99s leaders \xe2\x80\x94 if you fulfill your obligations and choose peace, there is a path to normal relations with the United States, including the lifting of economic sanctions and beginning the process, in accordance with United States law, of removing Sudan from the list of states that sponsor terrorism. In contrast, those who flout their international obligations will face more pressure and isolation.'b'Millions of Sudanese are making their way to the polls to determine their destiny. So was the unemployment rate ('b'10.4 percent'b' vs. our current 'b'9.4 percent'b') as Americans struggled to recover from what was 'b'then'b' the deepest economic downturn since the Great Depression.'b'My poll-crunching Times colleague 'b'Nate Silver has already poured cold water'b' on the fantasy that history is fated to repeat itself in 2012. His numbers show zero correlation between presidents\xe2\x80\x99 post-midterms popularity and their fates two years later. But if Obama actually read Cannon, his comeback could have legs. It\xe2\x80\x99s full of leadership lessons that will be particularly useful in outfoxing political adversaries who seem not to have consulted so much as a picture book about the president they claim as their patron saint.'b'The right\xe2\x80\x99s Stepford fetishization of Reagan reached a farcical apotheosis last week when a moderator of 'b'a  debate for the Republican National Committee chairmanship'b' tried to curtail the ritualistic bloviation by asking aspirants to name their political hero \xe2\x80\x9c'b'aside'b' from President Reagan.\xe2\x80\x9d This trick question so nonplussed one candidate that he coughed up \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Ludwig von Mises of FreedomWorks'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d  Another flustered respondent chose Margaret Thatcher, perhaps fearing it would be politically incorrect to venture an answer more than one degree of separation from the big Gipper.'b'The present-day radicals donning Reagan drag, led by Sarah Palin, seem not to know, as Cannon writes, that their hero lurched \xe2\x80\x9cfrom excessive tax cuts to corrective tax increases disguised as tax reform\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csubmitted eight unbalanced budgets to Congress in succession.\xe2\x80\x9d Reagan made no promise whatsoever of a balanced budget in the document that codified Reaganomics, his White House\xe2\x80\x99s 281-page message to Congress in February 1981. The historian Gil Troy has calculated that spending on entitlement programs more than doubled on Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s watch. America slid into debtor-nation status, and Americans \xe2\x80\x9cwent from owing 16 cents for every dollar in national income in 1981\xe2\x80\x9d to owing 44 cents per dollar in 1988.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also likely that Reagan would have drifted off \xe2\x80\x94 like most Americans \xe2\x80\x94 during the pretentious recitation of the Constitution in the House. He prided himself on serving as a true citizen-politician and, as Cannon writes, saw no problem in being \xe2\x80\x9ccompletely ignorant of even civics-book information about how bills were passed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What Reagan did know was how to deliver a message, even if that message belied his policies or actions or the facts. While perhaps no politician can ever duplicate Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s  brand of sunny and homespun (if Hollywood-honed) geniality, Obama has his own radiance when he wants to turn it on \xe2\x80\x94 a quality Reagan opponents like Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale lacked and that is beyond the imagination of frothing-at-the-mouth Tea Partiers. But Obama is less adept at keeping his messages simple, consistent and crystal-clear.'b'In a particularly instructive passage, Cannon tells of Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s habit of endlessly recycling an inspirational World War II anecdote that, as the press discovered, was a movie-spawned fiction. His White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, was only half-joking when he deflected critics with the old saw \xe2\x80\x9cif you tell the same story five times, it\xe2\x80\x99s true.\xe2\x80\x9d Unlike Reagan, Obama doesn\xe2\x80\x99t invent or fantasize. But he has trouble telling even some true stories five times \xe2\x80\x94 and telling them well \xe2\x80\x94 which is why he now has to 'b'resell the health care bill'b' more than nine months after he signed it.'b'Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s talents also included an ability to pick adversaries and hammer them relentlessly  \xe2\x80\x94  without losing his cool  \xe2\x80\x94  whether air-traffic controllers or the \xe2\x80\x9cevil empire.\xe2\x80\x9d Though Obama ultimately stopped vilifying the Bush administration  for the economic disaster he  inherited, Reagan never backed off bashing the Democrats and the 30-year Great Society \xe2\x80\x9cbinge\xe2\x80\x9d for the fiscal woes of his America. A former Democrat, after all, he wisely chose F.D.R. as his political model.'b'That pitch-perfect showmanship, timing and salesmanship (his father was a salesman) were in Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s r\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 and bones. Obama doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have that training, but he was a great communicator when it came to selling his own story in the campaign, heaven knows. His recent Congressional victories should not obscure the reality that, the tax-cut deal notwithstanding, he still disappeared at key moments when he should have led the charge.'b'Nowhere was he more AWOL than in the battle over aiding 9/11 emergency workers poisoned  by the toxic debris at ground zero. Yet Republicans in Congress 'b'caricatured it'b' as a \xe2\x80\x9cslush fund\xe2\x80\x9d inviting \xe2\x80\x9cabuse, fraud and waste\xe2\x80\x9d (Lamar Smith of Texas, the incoming chairman of the House Judiciary Committee) and \xe2\x80\x9c'b'an expansive new health care entitlement program'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma). But rather than lead this easily winnable battle from uncontestable high ground, the White House remained largely silent, 'b'releasing only a written statement of support for the bill'b'. The president never spoke publicly about it at all.'b'Obama didn\xe2\x80\x99t have to demagogue the issue. But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine a more clear-cut teaching moment for a president to explain how intransigent right-wing ideology can violate fundamental American values of fairness and sacrifice. A \xe2\x80\x9cthere you go again\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94  or two or three or four  \xe2\x80\x94  will come in handy when mocking antigovernment zealots like the newly elected Representative Vicky Hartzler of Missouri, who last week 'b'repeatedly ducked Diane Sawyer\xe2\x80\x99s simple inquiry'b' as to whether she would end federal farm subsidies (her family farm has collected some $775,000) now that she\xe2\x80\x99s in Washington.'b'In the 1984 election, 'b'The Times\xe2\x80\x99s exit poll found'b' that by far the single biggest factor in Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s landslide was the perception that the economy had turned around and that unemployment, though still high (7.2 percent), was falling rapidly. Without it, the miracle of his Christmas resurrection could be over by Easter.'b'BEIJING'b'If there\xe2\x80\x99s a human face on Rising China, it belongs not to some Politburo chief, not to an Internet tycoon, but to a quiet, mild-mannered teenage girl named Hou Yifan.'b'Ms. Hou (whose name is pronounced Ho Ee-fahn) is an astonishing phenomenon: at 16, she is the new women\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'world chess champion'b', the youngest person, male or female, ever to win a world championship. And she reflects the way China  \xe2\x80\x94 by investing heavily in education and human capital, particularly in young women  \xe2\x80\x94 is increasingly having an outsize impact on every aspect of the world.'b'Napoleon is famously said to have declared, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen China wakes, it will shake the world.\xe2\x80\x9d That is becoming true even in spheres that China historically has had little connection with, like chess, basketball, rare earth minerals, cyber warfare, space exploration and nuclear research.'b'This is a process that Miss Hou exemplifies. Only about 1 percent of Chinese play chess, and China has never been a chess power. But since 1991, China has produced four women\xe2\x80\x99s world chess champions, and Ms. Hou is the one with by far the most promise.'b'At this point, I have to put my sensitive male ego aside. You see, Ms. Hou gamely agreed to play me after I interviewed her. She had just flown into Beijing after winning the world championship, and she was exhausted  \xe2\x80\x94 and she shredded me in 21 moves.'b'Most dispiriting, when I was teetering at the abyss near the end of the game, her coach nudged her and suggested mischievously that we should switch sides. Ms. Hou would inherit my impossible position  \xe2\x80\x94 and the gleam in her coach\xe2\x80\x99s eye suggested that she would still win.'b'I protested that I could survive being beaten on the chess board by a schoolgirl. But to be toyed with, like a mouse by a cat  \xe2\x80\x94 that would be too much. Ms. Hou nodded compassionately and checkmated me a few moves later.'b'At 14 she became the youngest female grandmaster ever. She\xe2\x80\x99s still so young that it\xe2\x80\x99s unclear just how remarkable she will become.'b'Women in general haven\xe2\x80\x99t been nearly as good at chess as men, and the world\xe2\x80\x99s top women are mostly ranked well below the top men  \xe2\x80\x94 but Ms. Hou could be an exception. She is the only female chess player today considered to have a shot at becoming one of the top few players in the world, male or female.'b'Cynics sometimes suggest that China\xe2\x80\x99s rise as a world power is largely a matter of government manipulation of currency rates and trade rules, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt that there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of rigging or cheating going on in every sphere. But China has also done an extraordinarily good job of investing in its people and in spreading opportunity across the country. Moreover, perhaps as a legacy of Confucianism, its citizens have shown a passion for education and self-improvement  \xe2\x80\x94 along with remarkable capacity for discipline and hard work, what the Chinese call \xe2\x80\x9cchi ku,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ceating bitterness.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ms. Hou dined on plenty of bitterness in working her way up to champion.  She grew up in the boondocks, in a county town in Jiangsu Province, and her parents did not play chess. But they lavished attention on her and spoiled her, as parents of only children (\xe2\x80\x9clittle emperors\xe2\x80\x9d) routinely do in China.'b'China used to be one of the most sexist societies in the world  \xe2\x80\x94 with female infanticide, foot binding, and concubinage  \xe2\x80\x94 but it turned a corner and now is remarkably good at giving opportunities to girls as well as boys. When Ms. Hou\xe2\x80\x99s parents noticed her interest in a chess board at a store, they promptly bought her a chess set  \xe2\x80\x94 and then hired a chess tutor for her.'b'Ye Jiangchuan, the chief coach of the national men\xe2\x80\x99s and women\xe2\x80\x99s teams, told me that he played Ms. Hou when she was 9 years old  \xe2\x80\x94 and was stunned. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw that this kid was special,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me, and he invited her to move to Beijing to play with the national teams. Three years later she was the youngest girl ever to compete in the world chess championships.'b'It will be many, many decades before China can challenge the United States as the overall \xe2\x80\x9cNo. 1\xe2\x80\x9d in the world, for we have a huge lead and China still must show that it can transition to a more open and democratic society.
