China\xe2\x80\x99s national commitment to education, opportunity and eating bitterness  \xe2\x80\x94 those are qualities that we in the West might emulate as well. As you know after you\xe2\x80\x99ve been checkmated by Hou Yifan.'b'It has been four months since John Boehner, now speaker of the House, first proposed to cut $100 billion from this year\xe2\x80\x99s budget, an idea that was later elevated to a \xe2\x80\x9cpledge to America\xe2\x80\x9d in the 2010 campaign. Last week, Mr. Boehner finally specified his first actual cut:  $35 million from House lawmakers\xe2\x80\x99 office budgets.'b'Precisely because it is puny and painless, the cut passed the House with broad support, showing once again that the path to bipartisanship in Washington is paved with giveaways (like deficit-increasing tax cuts) and grandstanding (like trivial spending cuts dressed up as deficit reduction).'b'The road to fiscal responsibility is a harder one. Even as Republican leaders tout the $100 billion goal, aides have said it will be $50 billion to $60 billion, to adjust for the fact that the fiscal year is already under way. Whatever the sum, the public needs to know from Mr. Boehner what specific programs and services Republicans are willing to cut. The question is pressing, but not because the cuts are pressing. On the contrary, cutting billions would be foolish at a time when joblessness is high and the recovery needs stimulus, not tightening.'b'The question is important because without specifics, there can be no real debate on the best ways to reduce the deficit. Spending cuts need not and should not start today, but the nation needs to put a credible plan in place now to reduce the deficit as the economy recovers.'b'Campaigning is not the same as governing, and this prolonged state of political posture invites budget gimmicks and, worse, portends dangerous deadline-driven showdowns over who seems most willing to cut spending. This spring, for instance, Republicans could try to attach a demand for unspecified, across-the-board cuts to must-pass legislation to raise the nation\xe2\x80\x99s debt limit.'b'If successful, that would allow them to take credit for spending reductions without ever having to explain what, specifically, they want to cut, or defend those decisions. Why the reluctance to specify?'b'While House Republican leaders have not said what they would cut, they have said what they would spare: defense. They have also pledged to shield seniors from spending cuts, apparently to please recipients of entitlements like Medicare and Social Security. They also zealously defend the huge sums the country spends to give tax breaks to people who do not need them.'b'That leaves programs totaling $477 billion \xe2\x80\x94 14 percent of the $3.5 trillion federal budget \xe2\x80\x94 to absorb the promised cuts, including education, environment, transportation, diplomacy, disease control, scientific research, investor protection, and all other basic government programs on which the quality of American life depends.'b'Spread evenly, the cuts would come to more than 20 percent in each broad category. Cuts that deep in a single year have occurred only once, from 2009 to 2010, when the temporary increase from the stimulus reverted to more normal levels. Otherwise they are unprecedented, and no wonder. A 20 percent cut in education, for instance, would take some $8 billion out of federal money for schools, deepening the teacher layoffs and other cutbacks already enacted by states.'b'And for what? Cutting any arbitrary amount \xe2\x80\x94 like $100 billion \xe2\x80\x94 from discretionary spending will not result in meaningful long-term deficit reduction because deficits are not driven by discretionary spending. They are driven by rising health care costs and chronic tax shortfalls. Such cuts are even unlikely to result in near-term deficit reduction, because lawmakers would have to vote each year to keep spending at the newly depressed levels, an unlikely \xe2\x80\x94 and undesirable \xe2\x80\x94 prospect.'b'House Republicans claim that voters elected them in November to cut spending. Let\xe2\x80\x99s hear the specifics, and then see what the people want.'b'Handing the Pentagon blank checks backed with borrowed money never impressed us as wise. So we applaud Defense Secretary Robert Gates for making clear last week that those profligate days are over. The $78 billion, five-year reduction in projected spending plans he proposed is the biggest dose of austerity to hit the Pentagon since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.'b'It is especially striking that Mr. Gates is ready to cut, since far less responsible Republicans on Capitol Hill are putting the defense budget off limits for political reasons. But in overall budget terms, it is not big enough.'b'Mr. Gates has managed to contain further real growth in his baseline budget by eliminating costly and unworkable weapons like the Expeditionary Fighting Vehicle, cutting future troop strength for the Army and the Marines, increasing health insurance payments for working-age military retirees, and squeezing out bloat and inefficiency across the board. (This does not include combat operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, which are funded separately.)'b'That will still leave next year\xe2\x80\x99s nonwar military spending at $553 billion, higher in real terms than at the cold war\xe2\x80\x99s peak. And, under Mr. Gates\xe2\x80\x99s plan, it will inch upward for two more years after that before flattening out in fiscal 2015.'b'Even that slowed rate of increase, which depends on uncertain Congressional approval, is fiscally unsustainable. Military spending consumes more than 50 cents of every dollar of federal government discretionary spending.  And the Pentagon spends those dollars with more waste and less economic bang for the buck than other federal departments.'b'President Obama exempted the Pentagon from his announced freeze on most other discretionary spending. His bipartisan budget committee rightly called for ending that exemption. The Pentagon budget has more fat than any other area of federal spending. Mr. Obama must recognize that shielding that fat means savaging vital domestic programs to make up the difference.'b'Mr. Gates has been the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s best fiscal manager in decades. He brought some discipline to a procurement process notorious for fudging strategic choices and not matching weapons to combat needs. It overspent on fanciful air and sea weapons irrelevant to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, while neglecting desperately needed basics like defensive armor and drones.'b'The Expeditionary Fighting Vehicle that Mr. Gates now wants to eliminate is a $14.4 billion beach-storming amphibious tank dangerously vulnerable to improved anti-ship weapons. Some procurement savings will be shifted to more vital weapons programs, like a new long-range bomber. The rest will be used to slow the growth rate of future military spending.'b'To start chipping into the deficit, the Pentagon must come up with far deeper procurement cuts \xe2\x80\x94 like slashing orders for thousands of new short-range tactical fighters in favor of the new Air Force bomber and unpiloted long-range naval strike aircraft. Tactical fighters are not designed for fighting Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Longer-range aircraft are a smarter response to China\xe2\x80\x99s new emphasis on submarines and anti-ship missiles.'b'Significant budget savings can eventually be reaped from further negotiated nuclear arms reductions with Russia, provided Congressional Republicans do not insist on squandering the money on new nuclear weapons and fantasy-based missile defense shields.'b'The Army and Marine troop cuts, of 27,000 and 20,000, would still leave both forces larger than at the start of Mr. Gates\xe2\x80\x99s tenure four years ago. They are timed to phase in starting in 2015, when the administration presumes that the need for outside military forces in Afghanistan will be significantly reduced. But ground force needs are hard to predict, and an all-volunteer force is hard to build up quickly in wartime. The projected personnel cuts will have to be revisited annually.'b'The only certainty is that nonwar military spending will have to be drastically reduced to leave room for unexpected military missions and to make deficit reduction realistic. If Congressional Republicans are serious about lowering the deficit, they cannot exempt the Pentagon.'b'Lahore, Pakistan'b'TWENTY-SEVEN. That\xe2\x80\x99s the number of bullets a police guard fired into my father before surrendering himself with a sinister smile to the policemen around him. Salmaan Taseer, governor of Punjab, Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s most populous province, 'b'was assassinated on Tuesday'b' \xe2\x80\x94 my brother Shehryar\xe2\x80\x99s 25th birthday \xe2\x80\x94 outside a market near our family home in Islamabad.'b'The guard accused of the killing, Mumtaz Qadri, was assigned that morning to protect my father while he was in the federal capital. According to officials, around 4:15 p.m., as my father was about to step into his car after lunch, Mr. Qadri opened fire.'b'Mr. Qadri and his supporters may have felled a great oak that day, but they are sadly mistaken if they think they have succeeded in silencing my father\xe2\x80\x99s voice or the voices of millions like him who believe in the secular vision of Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s founder, Muhammad Ali Jinnah.'b'My father\xe2\x80\x99s life was one of struggle. He was a self-made man, who made and lost and remade his fortune. He was among the first members of the ruling Pakistan Peoples Party when it was founded by Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in the late 1960s. He was an intellectual, a newspaper publisher and a writer; he was jailed and tortured for his belief in democracy and freedom. The vile dictatorship of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq did not take kindly to his pamphleteering for the restoration of democracy.'b'One particularly brutal imprisonment was in a dungeon at Lahore Fort, this city\xe2\x80\x99s Mughal-era citadel. My father was held in solitary confinement for months and was slipped a single meal of half a plate of stewed lentils each day. They told my mother, in her early 20s at the time, that he was dead. She never believed that.'b'Determined, she made friends with the kind man who used to sweep my father\xe2\x80\x99s cell and asked him to pass a note to her husband. My father later told me he swallowed the note, fearing for the sweeper\xe2\x80\x99s life. He scribbled back a reassuring message to my mother: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not made from a wood that burns easily.\xe2\x80\x9d That is the kind of man my father was. He could not be broken.'b'He often quoted verse by his uncle Faiz Ahmed Faiz, one of Urdu\xe2\x80\x99s greatest poets. \xe2\x80\x9cEven if you\xe2\x80\x99ve got shackles on your feet, go. Be fearless and walk. Stand for your cause even if you are martyred,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Faiz. Especially as governor, my father was the first to speak up and stand beside those who had suffered, from the thousands of people displaced by the Kashmir earthquake in 2005 to the family of two teenage brothers who were lynched by a mob last August in Sialkot after a dispute at a cricket match.'b'After 86 members of the Ahmadi sect, considered blasphemous by fundamentalists, were murdered in attacks on two of their mosques in Lahore last May, to the great displeasure of the religious right my father visited the survivors in the hospital. When the floods devastated Pakistan last summer, he was on the go, rallying businessmen for aid, consoling the homeless and building shelters.'b'My father believed that the strict blasphemy laws instituted by General Zia have been frequently misused and ought to be changed. His views were widely misrepresented to give the false impression that he had spoken against Prophet Mohammad. This was untrue, and a criminal abdication of responsibility by his critics, who must now think about what they have caused to happen. According to the authorities, my father\xe2\x80\x99s stand on the blasphemy law was what drove Mr. Qadri to kill him.'b'There are those who say my father\xe2\x80\x99s death was the final nail in the coffin for a tolerant Pakistan. That Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s liberal voices will now be silenced. But we buried a heroic man, not the courage he inspired in others. This week two leading conservative politicians \xe2\x80\x94 former Prime Minister Chaudhry Shujaat Hussain and the cricket-star-turned-politician Imran Khan  \xe2\x80\x94 have taken the same position my father held on the blasphemy laws: they want amendments to prevent misuse.'b'To say that there was a security lapse on Tuesday is an understatement. My father was brutally gunned down by a man hired to protect him. Juvenal once asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWho will guard the guards themselves?\xe2\x80\x9d It is a question all Pakistanis should ask themselves today: If the extremists could get to the governor of the largest province, is anyone safe?'b'It may sound odd, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine my father dying in any other way. Everything he had, he invested in Pakistan, giving livelihoods to tens of thousands, improving the economy. My father believed in our country\xe2\x80\x99s potential. He lived and died for Pakistan. To honor his memory, those who share that belief in Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s future must not stay silent about injustice. We must never be afraid of our enemies. We must never let them win.'b'Sometime in 1611, a new English Bible was published. It was the work of an almost impossibly learned team of men laboring since 1604 under royal mandate. Their purpose, they wrote, was not to make a new translation of the Bible but \xe2\x80\x9cto make a good one better, or out of many good ones, one principal good one.\xe2\x80\x9d What was published, 400 years ago, was indeed one principal good one: the King James Version of the Bible.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s barely possible to overstate the significance of this Bible. Hundreds of millions have been sold. In 1611, it found a critical balance in a world of theological conflict, and it has been beloved since of Protestant churches and congregations of every stripe. By the end of the 17th century it was, simply, the Bible. It has been superseded by translations in more modern English, translations based on sources the King James translators couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have known. But to Christians all around the world, it is still the ancestral language of faith.'b'To modern readers, the English of the King James Version sounds archaic, much as Shakespeare does. But there would have been an archaism for readers even in 1611 because the King James Bible draws heavily from a version of William Tyndale\xe2\x80\x99s New Testament published in 1534 and from translations by Miles Coverdale also published in the 1530s.'b'Tyndale\xe2\x80\x99s aspiration was to make his New Testament accessible to \xe2\x80\x9cthe boy that driveth the plough.\xe2\x80\x9d Though readers often talk about the majesty of the King James Bible, what has made it live is in fact the simplicity of its language.'b'Scholars have often debated just how much the King James Bible has influenced the English language. They count the number of idioms \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthe powers that be,\xe2\x80\x9d for instance \xe2\x80\x94 that entered the language from the Bible. They look at how often it\xe2\x80\x99s cited in the Oxford English Dictionary.'b'T. S. Eliot and C. S. Lewis deplored the idea of considering the secular literary or linguistic influence of the King James Bible. Eliot said it had such a profound effect because it was \xe2\x80\x9cthe Word of God.\xe2\x80\x9d Lewis went further. He argued that the King James Bible had little influence on the rhythms of English and that many of the Bible\xe2\x80\x99s characteristic rhythms were simply \xe2\x80\x9cunavoidable in the English language.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But Lewis missed the point. The King James Bible has had an enormous impact on English for the very reason that it captures and preserves \xe2\x80\x94 and communicates down through the centuries \xe2\x80\x94 the unavoidable rhythms of good English. Its words are almost never Latinate, and its rhythms are never hampered by the literalism that afflicts other translations.'b'It would have been so easy to get that wrong, to let scholarship overwhelm common sense, to let theology engulf plainness. We owe an enormous debt to William Tyndale\xe2\x80\x99s imaginary plowboy. All who speak this wonderful language still speak in the shadow of the King James Bible.'b''b' 'b''b'FOUR months as public editor has given me a working list, perhaps only that, of the challenges The Times faces and the faults readers find in this most important of American newspapers. As a representative of the reader, I\xe2\x80\x99d like to post that list today and invite you to consider it, then add to it as you will.'b'The 'b'blending of opinion with news'b' is a good place to start. Although there is a distinct separation between the Editorial Page operation headed by 'b'Andrew Rosenthal'b' and the news operation headed by 'b'Bill Keller'b', the news pages are laced with analytical and opinion pieces that work against the premise that the news is just the news.'b'The most glaring recent example that drew my eye was the 'b'Dec. 15 front-page column by David Leonhardt analyzing the debate over health care reform.'b' The piece, a day-two follow-up to the news that a federal judge in Virginia had overturned the health care law\xe2\x80\x99s central provision, drew complaints from readers like Sheila R. In my experience, people value boundaries, rely on them and grow uncomfortable when they move.'b'And here\xe2\x80\x99s another form of boundary-slippage that readers complain about, one that is technology-driven. Once upon a time, the final print edition set a final, definitive version of a story and headline, leaving for posterity an immutable document of record, albeit one gathering dust in the newspaper morgue. No more. Now, appearing online, stories often undergo 'b'more frequent updates'b' and 'b'headline changes'b'. The same story often appears under distinctly different headlines in print, on the Web and on the other digital devices the Times feeds.'b'Amy Goldstein, a reader from Princeton, N.J., wrote to me that she found all this versioning problematic. \xe2\x80\x9cHow does the newspaper of record handle this?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, referring to changing versions of 'b'an obituary of the movie director Arthur Penn'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cI read something, and now poof, it\xe2\x80\x99s gone without a trace.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While the requirements of digital publishing sometimes make things go \xe2\x80\x9cpoof,\xe2\x80\x9d in other ways the digital environment commits things to a kind of immortality that itself is sometimes unwelcome.'b'In one case I wrote about, 'b'I argued that the paper had run roughshod in using the names of a 4-year-old and a 5-year-old who were named in a civil suit.'b' But there is no fix for a problem like this after-the-fact. When it comes to the notion of expunging the identities, Times policy is strict: the electronic record is not to be changed. To me, this argues for taking far more care in protecting individuals\xe2\x80\x99 privacy in the first place.'b'Indeed, taking sufficient care on the front end of reporting and publishing is one of the most difficult challenges for The Times as news consumption shifts rapidly to digital venues like the Web, tablets and cellphones. This project was developed with Magen David Adom and the Sheba Medical Center of Israel, the Haitian Red Cross and the German nongovernmental organization LandsAid.'b'One year after the earthquake, the work continues.'b'Steven Schwager'b'\nExecutive Vice President and C.E.O.'b'\nAmerican Jewish Joint'b'\nDistribution Committee'b'\nNew York, Jan. 4, 2011'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b'As ambassador to Lebanon from 2004 to 2008, I was the person whom Al Akhbar\xe2\x80\x99s editorial chairman, Ibrahim al-Amine, hoped to upset every morning with his newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s coverage (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Rarity in the Region, a Lebanese Paper Dares to Provoke'b',\xe2\x80\x9d news article, Dec. 29).'b'Mr. Amine did get my attention, but not in the way he intended. The hilariously erroneous accounts of my activities reported as fact in his newspaper provoked morning belly laughs.'b'While posted to Lebanon, I met with the editorial boards of Lebanon\xe2\x80\x99s lively media, even stridently anti-American ones, for off-the-record, two-way conversations. Toomer'b'\nNew York, Jan. 6, 2011'b''b''b'The writer is the granddaughter of Herbert Hoffman Toomer, Jean Toomer\xe2\x80\x99s son.'b''b''b'The United States economy added 103,000 jobs in December, the Labor Department said Friday \xe2\x80\x94 proving that the recovery still can\xe2\x80\x99t make up for all the jobs lost during the recession. The Op-Ed editors asked four writers to find out what the economy looks like around the country. Here are their third dispatches.\n'b''b'She read the First Amendment on the House floor \xe2\x80\x94 including the guarantee of  \xe2\x80\x9cthe right of the people peaceably to assemble\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and then flew home to Arizona to put those words into practice. But when Gabrielle Giffords tried to meet with her constituents in a Tucson parking lot on Saturday, she came face to face with an environment wholly at odds with that constitutional ideal, and she nearly paid for it with her life.'b'Jared Loughner, the man accused of shooting Ms. Giffords, killing a federal judge and five other people, and wounding 13 others, appears to be mentally ill. His paranoid Internet ravings about government mind control place him well beyond usual ideological categories.'b'But he is very much a part of a widespread squall of fear, anger and intolerance that has produced violent threats against scores of politicians and infected the political mainstream with violent imagery. With easy and legal access to semiautomatic weapons like the one used in the parking lot, those already teetering on the edge of sanity can turn a threat into a nightmare.'b'Last spring, 'b'Capitol security officials'b' said threats against members of Congress had  tripled over the previous year, almost all from opponents of health care reform. An effigy of Representative Frank Kratovil Jr., a Maryland Democrat, was hung from a gallows outside his district office. Ms. Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s  district office door was smashed after the health vote, possibly by a bullet.'b'The federal judge who was killed, John Roll, had received 'b'hundreds of menacing phone calls and death threats'b', especially after he allowed a case to proceed  against a rancher accused of assaulting 16 Mexicans as they tried to cross his land. This rage, stirred by talk-radio hosts, required marshals to give the judge and his family 24-hour protection for a month. Around the nation, threats to federal judges have soared for a decade.'b'It is facile and mistaken to attribute this particular madman\xe2\x80\x99s act directly to Republicans or Tea Party members. But it is legitimate to hold Republicans and particularly their most virulent supporters in the media responsible for the gale of anger that has produced the vast majority of these threats, setting the nation on edge. Many on the right have exploited the arguments of division, reaping political power by demonizing immigrants, or welfare recipients, or bureaucrats. They seem to have persuaded many Americans that the government is not just misguided, but the enemy of the people.'b'That whirlwind has touched down most forcefully in Arizona, which Pima County Sheriff Clarence Dupnik described after the shooting as  the capital of  \xe2\x80\x9cthe anger, the hatred and the bigotry that goes on in this country.\xe2\x80\x9d Anti-immigrant sentiment in the state, firmly opposed by Ms. Giffords, has reached the point where Latino studies programs that advocate ethnic solidarity 'b'have actually been made illegal.'b''b'Its gun laws are'b' among the most lenient'b', allowing even a disturbed man like Mr. Loughner to buy a pistol and carry it concealed without a special permit. That was before the Tucson rampage. Now, having seen first hand the horror of political violence, Arizona should lead the nation in quieting the voices of intolerance, demanding an end to the temptations of bloodshed, and imposing sensible controls on its instruments.'b'When John F. Kennedy visited Dallas in November of 1963, Texas was awash in right-wing anger \xe2\x80\x94 over perceived cold-war betrayals, over desegregation, over the perfidies of liberalism in general. Adlai Stevenson, then ambassador to the U.N., had been spit on during his visit to the city earlier that fall. The week of Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, leaflets circulated in Dallas bearing the president\xe2\x80\x99s photograph and the words \xe2\x80\x9cWanted For Treason.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But Lee Harvey Oswald was not a right-winger, not a John Bircher, not a segregationist. Instead, he was a 'b'Marxist of sorts'b' (albeit one disillusioned by his experiences in Soviet Russia), an activist on behalf of Castro\xe2\x80\x99s Cuba, and a man whose previous plot had been aimed at a far-right ex-general named Edwin Walker. The anti-Kennedy excesses of Texas conservatives were real enough, but the president\xe2\x80\x99s assassin acted on a far more obscure set of motivations.'b'Nine years after Kennedy was killed, George Wallace embarked on his second campaign for the presidency. This was the early 1970s, the high tide of far-left violence  \xe2\x80\x94  the era of the Black Panthers, the Weathermen, the Symbionese Liberation Army  \xe2\x80\x94  and Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s race-baiting politics made him an obvious target for protests. On his final, fateful day of campaigning, he faced  a barrage of coins, oranges, rocks and tomatoes, amid shouts of \xe2\x80\x9cremember Selma!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cHitler for vice president!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But Arthur Bremer, who shot Wallace that afternoon, paralyzing him from the waist down, had only a tenuous connection to left-wing politics. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t care much about Wallace\xe2\x80\x99s views on race: he just wanted to assassinate somebody (Richard Nixon had been his original target), as \xe2\x80\x9ca statement of my manhood for the world to see.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s possible that Jared Lee Loughner, the young man behind Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s rampage in Tucson, will have a more direct connection to partisan politics than an earlier generation\xe2\x80\x99s gunmen did. Indeed, many observers seem to be taking a kind of comfort from that possibility: there\xe2\x80\x99s been a rush to declare this tragedy a teachable moment  \xe2\x80\x94  an opportunity for people to cool their rhetoric, abandon their anger, and renounce the kind of martial imagery that inspired Sarah Palin\xe2\x80\x99s PAC to place a target over Gabrielle Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s district just months before Loughner gunned down the Arizona congresswoman.'b'But chances are that Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s motives will prove as irreducibly complex as those of most of his predecessors in assassination. Violence in American politics tends to bubble up from a world that\xe2\x80\x99s far stranger than any Glenn Beck monologue  \xe2\x80\x94  a murky landscape where worldviews get cobbled together from a host of baroque conspiracy theories, and where the line between ideological extremism and mental illness gets blurry fast.'b'This is the world that gave us Oswald and Bremer. More recently, it\xe2\x80\x99s given us figures like James W. von Brunn, the neo-Nazi who opened fire at  the Holocaust Museum in 2009, and James Lee, who took hostages at the Discovery Channel last summer to express his displeasure over population growth. These are figures better analyzed by novelists than pundits: as Walter Kirn 'b'put it'b' Saturday,  they\xe2\x80\x99re \xe2\x80\x9cself-anointed knights templar of the collective shadow realm, not secular political actors in extremis.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This won\xe2\x80\x99t stop partisans from making hay out of Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s tragedy, of course. The Democratic operative who was quoted in 'b'Politico'b' saying that his party needs \xe2\x80\x9cto deftly pin this on the Tea Partiers\xe2\x80\x9d was just stating the obvious: after a political season rife with overheated rhetoric from conservative \xe2\x80\x9crevolutionaries,\xe2\x80\x9d the attempted murder of a Democratic congresswoman is a potential gift to liberalism.'b'But if overheated rhetoric and martial imagery really led inexorably to murder, then both parties would belong in the dock. (It took conservative bloggers about five minutes to come up with Democratic campaign materials  that employed 'b'targets'b' and 'b'crosshairs'b' against Republican politicians.) When our politicians and media loudmouths act like fools and zealots, they should be held responsible for being fools and zealots. They shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be held responsible for the darkness that always waits to swallow up the unstable and the lost.'b'We should remember, too, that there are places where mainstream political movements really are responsible for violence against their rivals. (Last week\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'assassination'b' of a Pakistani politician who dared to defend a Christian is a stark reminder of what that sort of world can look like.) Not so in America: From the Republican leadership to the Tea Party grass roots, all of Gabrielle Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s political opponents were united in horror at the weekend\xe2\x80\x99s events. There is no faction in American politics that actually wants its opponents dead.'b'That may seem like a small blessing, amid so much tragedy and loss. But it is a blessing worth remembering nonetheless.'b'Brisbane, Australia'b'THERE was cricket in Sydney last week. The crowd wore pink fluorescent wigs and hats cut from watermelons. Shirts were optional. Australians are fun-loving when there is fun to be had. It\xe2\x80\x99s part of our national character. So is our disregard for authority, which we celebrate, while at the same time being one of the most law-abiding nations on earth.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s what the rest of the world sees, and it\xe2\x80\x99s all true. But we want to see something more in ourselves, a hard-working stoicism \xe2\x80\x94 and right now it\xe2\x80\x99s the northeast state of Queensland, where 'b'once-in-a-century flooding'b' has devastated countless communities, that shows it most clearly.'b'All maps of Queensland are deceptive. They show inland plains crossed by rivers, always colored blue. It\xe2\x80\x99s tempting to imagine riverboats hauling freight, green fields stretching out from either bank, industrial towns and cities drawing water for their factories.'b'What the maps don\xe2\x80\x99t reveal is that the rivers are often only possibilities. Many are dry for years, their waters long since soaked up by the parched ground and left as a chain of water holes.'b'The maps also don\xe2\x80\x99t say that, every few years, the rivers flood. Once in a generation, they cover the land. And sometimes, like now, they tear the state apart.'b'To the north and west of Brisbane, the state capital and my hometown, Queensland faces a flood affecting an area the size of Texas and Oklahoma combined. The mines that supply one-third of the world\xe2\x80\x99s coking coal are shut down. Crops have been destroyed and the soil that grew them has been carried away. Mercifully few lives have been lost so far, but the economic impact has been estimated at $5 billion. Some 200,000 people have been affected, many of them forced from their homes by water and mud.'b'Nevertheless, there is none of the clamor of disaster, none of the chaos one might expect. Crisis management plans have been activated. Townships, towns and cities are hard at work, not only as governments but as communities. Neighbors are helping neighbors, and then helping people they have never met. When the hard-hit coastal city of Rockhampton put a call out over the radio for people to fill sandbags, 70 volunteers turned up within minutes.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a calm resilience too. Rockhampton\xe2\x80\x99s Fitzroy Hotel, surrounded by floodwaters that have risen to an inch or so below its floorboards, has rebranded itself as the Fitzroy Float-El. Its customers now arrive by boat. Inside, on the widescreen TVs normally tuned to sports, the Fitzroy is showing footage of the last inundation, 19 years ago. Veterans of that flood are turning up to watch themselves filling sandbags, back when they were thinner and had more hair.'b'Even after the rain stops, we\xe2\x80\x99re told, it will be weeks before all the water is gone. As the less-fortunate evacuees return home, they will find mud everywhere: in their filing cabinets, their kitchen cupboards, their photo albums. As I learned in the aftermath of the Brisbane flood of 1974, the smell will remain for years \xe2\x80\x94 a swampy stench that comes out of the walls and down from the ceiling on hot days.'b'Those people will need room for grief and anger. Most of them, though, when interviewed standing in the wreckage, talk about how life goes on.'b'Events like this flood not only show our stoicism, but create it. It\xe2\x80\x99s important to Queenslanders, like all Australians, that we see ourselves as people who look adversity in the eye, stare it down and band together to overcome it.'b'Houses will be repaired, and new ones will be built. Businesses will get back to work. In ground that was baked dry but is now soaked deep, eggs will hatch, seeds will germinate and hidden species will reveal themselves and make the most of this change in their luck before the next drought sets in. Life will go on and, for farmers and those dependent on the land, the next crop should be a good one, if the weather holds.'b'In 2009, Gabrielle Giffords was holding a \xe2\x80\x9cCongress on Your Corner\xe2\x80\x9d meeting at a Safeway supermarket in her district when a protester, who was waving a sign that said \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Tread on Me,\xe2\x80\x9d waved a little too strenuously. The pistol he was carrying under his armpit fell out of his holster.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt bounced. That concerned me,\xe2\x80\x9d Rudy Ruiz, the father of one of Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s college interns at the time, told me then. He had been at the event and had gotten a larger vision than he had anticipated of what a career in politics entailed. \xe2\x80\x9cI just thought, \xe2\x80\x98What would happen if it had gone off? Could my daughter have gotten hurt?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'Giffords brushed off the incident. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you represent a district  \xe2\x80\x94  the home of the O.K. Corral and Tombstone, the town too tough to die \xe2\x80\x94  nothing\xe2\x80\x99s a surprise,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. At the time, it struck me as an interesting attempt to meld crisis control with a promotion of local tourist attractions.'b'Now, of course, the district has lost more people in a shooting in a shopping center parking lot than died at the gunfight of the O.K. Corral, and the story  of the dropped pistol has a tragically different cast.'b'In soft-pedaling that  2009  encounter, Giffords was doing a balancing act that she\xe2\x80\x99d perfected during her political career as a rather progressive Democrat in a increasingly conservative state. She was the spunky Western girl with a populist agenda mixed with down-home values, one of which was opposition to gun control. But those protesters had been following her around for a while. Her staff members were clearly scared for her, and they put me in touch with Ruiz, who told me the story.'b'Back then, the amazing thing about the incident in the supermarket parking lot was that the guy with a handgun in his armpit was not arrested. Since then, Arizona has completely eliminated the whole concept of requiring a concealed weapon permit. Last year, it got 2 points out of a possible 100 in the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence state score card, avoiding a zero only because its Legislature has not \xe2\x80\x94  so far \xe2\x80\x94  voted to force colleges to let people bring their guns on campuses.'b'Today, the amazing thing about the reaction to the Giffords shooting is that virtually all the discussion about how to prevent a recurrence has been focusing on improving the tone of our political discourse. That would certainly be great. But you do not hear much about the fact that Jared Loughner came to Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s sweet gathering with a semiautomatic weapon that he was able to buy legally because the law restricting their sale expired in 2004 and Congress did not have the guts to face up to the National Rifle Association and extend it.'b'If Loughner had gone to the Safeway carrying a regular pistol, the kind most Americans think of when they think of the right to bear arms, Giffords would probably still have been shot and we would still be having that conversation about whether it was a sane idea to put her Congressional district in the cross hairs of a rifle on the Internet.'b'But we might not have lost a federal judge, a 76-year-old church volunteer, two elderly women, Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s 30-year-old constituent services director and a 9-year-old girl who had recently been elected to the student council at her school and went to the event because she wanted to see how democracy worked.'b'Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s gun, a 9-millimeter Glock, is extremely easy to fire over and over, and it can carry a 30-bullet clip. It is \xe2\x80\x9cnot suited for hunting or personal protection,\xe2\x80\x9d said Paul Helmke, the president of the Brady Campaign. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat it\xe2\x80\x99s good for is killing and injuring a lot of people quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'America has a long, terrible history of political assassinations and attempts at political assassination. What we did not have until now is a history of attempted political assassination that took the lives of a large number of innocent bystanders. The difference is not about the Second Amendment. It\xe2\x80\x99s about a technology the founding fathers could never have imagined.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf this was the modern equivalent of what Sirhan Sirhan used to shoot Robert Kennedy or Arthur Bremer used to shoot George Wallace, you\xe2\x80\x99d be talking about one or two victims,\xe2\x80\x9d said Helmke.'b'Giffords represents a pragmatic, interest-balancing form of politics that\xe2\x80\x99s out of fashion. But, in that spirit, we should be able to find a way to accommodate the strong desire in many parts of the country for easy access to firearms with sane regulation of the kinds of weapons that make it easiest for crazy people to create mass slaughter. Most politicians won\xe2\x80\x99t talk about it because they\xe2\x80\x99re afraid of the N.R.A., whose agenda is driven by the people who sell guns and want the right to sell as many as possible.'b'Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it seem like the least we can do?'b'As Mayor Michael Bloomberg went to red alert for the small snowstorm that swept into New York City on Friday, it was fairly evident that the fuss over snow removal wasn\xe2\x80\x99t only, or even mostly, about snow. It was about the mayor.'b'One year into his third term, Mr. Bloomberg has a dismal 37 percent approval rating, according to the Marist poll released on Thursday. Every New Yorker knows that Mr. Bloomberg has had better economic news to peddle, and has been making quite a name for himself on the national scene promoting big solutions to big issues.'b'The unease is about how he is doing back home, a concern that has been boiling for some time and spilled over after the post-Christmas blizzard, which overwhelmed the city and city government alike.'b'It did not help that the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s first advice to New Yorkers was essentially to quit whining, get out and go to a Broadway show. And, as Comptroller John Liu has been saying for over a year, the project is years behind schedule and 10 times over its original budget of about $68 million.'b'Here we have a technology mix-up overseen by the mayor who made several sizable fortunes in technology, a management glitch for the mayor known as a management guru. Even his fuming about misplaced trust and \xe2\x80\x9cno tolerance for this whatsoever\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explain enough about how so much of this slipshod work slipped past his desk unnoticed. Last week  Mr. Liu canceled a $286 million contract for emergency communications \xe2\x80\x9cto prevent CityTime 2.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It is far too soon to write off the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s third term. We assume these are blemishes not full-fledged failures and that they give him an opportunity to do things better, just like in the weekend\xe2\x80\x99s baby snowstorm.'b'Advocates of federal action to address climate change had little to cheer about in 2010. The prospects may be even grimmer this year, with nearly every important committee chair in the now Republican-controlled House dismissing the threat of global warming or the human contribution to it.'b'As Congress dawdles and denies, some states are moving forward. Massachusetts recently  announced a plan to curb emissions from homes, cars and factories by one-fourth below 1990 levels over 10 years \xe2\x80\x94 considerably more aggressive than President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s commitment in Copenhagen to reduce emissions 17 percent below 2005 levels. The plan relies on existing technologies to produce more power from renewable sources like wind, tougher energy-efficiency standards for buildings and more investments in mass transit.'b'Massachusetts will also benefit from its participation in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a 2008 agreement among 10 Eastern states, including New York, to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from power plants. These emissions have already dropped dramatically in the region, in part because utilities have been switching from coal to cleaner-burning natural gas.'b'The Massachusetts announcement follows California\xe2\x80\x99s approval of a cap-and-trade program requiring 360 large enterprises, including refineries and power plants, to gradually reduce emissions to help achieve a statewide reduction of 15 percent from current levels by 2020 \xe2\x80\x94 just under Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s target.'b'As in other cap-and-trade programs \xe2\x80\x94 including proposals that stalled in Congress \xe2\x80\x94 the plan will require each facility to reduce emissions or buy allowances to pollute. This should encourage industry to invest in cleaner technologies while raising money for the state and local communities to improve energy efficiency.'b'The trading program was the last missing piece of a broad initiative signed into law by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger in 2006. Among other things, it requires that an increasing percentage of California\xe2\x80\x99s energy be generated by wind and solar power. It also meshes neatly with the state\xe2\x80\x99s strict greenhouse gas limits on vehicles, which paved the way for the national standards adopted by the Obama administration.'b'Other states and cities, including New York City, have embraced one or more aggressive strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. None of this is enough; a national policy would be much better. One hopes that Washington will get the message \xe2\x80\x94 before it\xe2\x80\x99s too late.'b'To the Editor:'b'The federal court decision to reject the regulation requiring all New York City businesses selling tobacco products to post tobacco health warnings is a huge disappointment (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Judge Rejects City Law on Antismoking Posters'b',\xe2\x80\x9d news article, Dec. 30).'b'The city\xe2\x80\x99s warning signs serve as a reminder for consumers about the harm caused by tobacco products. Health warnings that convey the adverse health effects of tobacco use are shown to be highly effective in motivating smokers to quit and discouraging nonsmokers from starting.'b'If we do not continue to expand and intensify tobacco control efforts, many will continue to suffer from preventable tobacco-related illness. Elected officials need to step up and fully carry out proven interventions that we know work to reduce tobacco use, decrease exposure to dangerous secondhand smoke and prevent future generations from ever starting.'b'One way the city can take immediate action is to swiftly pass the proposed legislation that will create smoke-free parks, beaches and pedestrian plazas. Santarella'b'\nPresident and Chief Executive'b'\nAmerican Lung Association'b'\nin New York'b'\nNew York, Jan. 5, 2011'b''b''b''b''b'When you heard the terrible news from Arizona, were you completely surprised? Or were you, at some level, expecting something like this atrocity to happen?'b'Put me in the latter category. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a sick feeling in the pit of my stomach ever 'b'since the final stages of the 2008'b' campaign. I remembered the upsurge in political hatred after Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s election in 1992 \xe2\x80\x94 an upsurge that culminated in the Oklahoma City bombing. And you could see, just by watching the crowds at McCain-Palin rallies, that it was ready to happen again. The Department of Homeland Security reached the same conclusion: in April 2009 an internal 'b'report'b' warned that right-wing extremism was on the rise, with a growing potential for violence.'b'Conservatives denounced that report. But there has, in fact, been a rising tide of threats and vandalism aimed at elected officials, including both Judge John Roll, who was killed Saturday, and Representative Gabrielle Giffords. One of these days, someone was bound to take it to the next level. And now someone has.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s true that the shooter in Arizona appears to have been mentally troubled. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that his act can or should be treated as an isolated event, having nothing to do with the national climate.'b'Last spring Politico.com reported on a surge in threats against members of Congress, which were already up by 300 percent. A number of the people making those threats had a history of mental illness \xe2\x80\x94 but something about the current state of America has been causing far more disturbed people than before to act out their illness by threatening, or actually engaging in, political violence.'b'And there\xe2\x80\x99s not much question what has changed. As Clarence Dupnik, the sheriff responsible for dealing with the Arizona shootings, put it, it\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cthe vitriolic rhetoric that we hear day in and day out from people in the radio business and some people in the TV business.\xe2\x80\x9d The vast majority of those who listen to that toxic rhetoric stop short of actual violence, but some, inevitably, cross that line.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s important to be clear here about the nature of our sickness. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a general lack of \xe2\x80\x9ccivility,\xe2\x80\x9d the favorite term of pundits who want to wish away fundamental policy disagreements. Politeness may be a virtue, but there\xe2\x80\x99s a big difference between bad manners and calls, explicit or implicit, for violence; insults aren\xe2\x80\x99t the same as incitement.'b'The point is that there\xe2\x80\x99s room in a democracy for people who ridicule and denounce those who disagree with them; there isn\xe2\x80\x99t any place for eliminationist rhetoric, for suggestions that those on the other side of a debate must be removed from that debate by whatever means necessary.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s the saturation of our political discourse \xe2\x80\x94 and especially our airwaves \xe2\x80\x94 with eliminationist rhetoric that lies behind the rising tide of violence.'b'Where\xe2\x80\x99s that toxic rhetoric coming from? Let\xe2\x80\x99s not make a false pretense of balance: it\xe2\x80\x99s coming, overwhelmingly, from the right. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine a Democratic member of Congress urging constituents to be \xe2\x80\x9carmed and dangerous\xe2\x80\x9d without being ostracized; but Representative Michele Bachmann, who did just that, is a rising star in the G.O.P.'b'And there\xe2\x80\x99s a huge contrast in the media. Listen to Rachel Maddow or Keith Olbermann, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll hear a lot of caustic remarks and mockery aimed at Republicans. But you won\xe2\x80\x99t hear jokes about shooting government officials  or beheading a journalist  at The Washington Post. Listen to Glenn Beck or Bill O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly, and you will.'b'Of course, the likes of Mr. Beck and Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly are responding to popular demand. Citizens of other democracies may marvel at the American psyche, at the way efforts by mildly liberal presidents to expand health coverage are met with cries of tyranny and talk of armed resistance. Still, that\xe2\x80\x99s what happens whenever a Democrat occupies the White House, and there\xe2\x80\x99s a market for anyone willing to stoke that anger.'b'But even if hate is what many want to hear, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t excuse those who pander to that desire. They should be shunned by all decent people.'b'Unfortunately, that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been happening: the purveyors of hate have been treated with respect, even deference, by the G.O.P. establishment. As David Frum, the former Bush speechwriter, has put it, \xe2\x80\x9cRepublicans originally thought that Fox worked for us and now we\xe2\x80\x99re discovering we work for Fox.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So will the Arizona massacre make our discourse less toxic? It\xe2\x80\x99s really up to G.O.P. leaders. Will they accept the reality of what\xe2\x80\x99s happening to America, and take a stand against eliminationist rhetoric? Or will they try to dismiss the massacre as the mere act of a deranged individual, and go on as before?'b'If Arizona promotes some real soul-searching, it could prove a turning point. Some $80 billion was withdrawn in 2010, on top of nearly $240 billion in the three years before that.'b'Why the retreat? One explanation is reasonable doubt about the economy. Spiraling inflation \xe2\x80\x94 exacerbated by the cheap currency policy \xe2\x80\x94 could threaten both.'b'Right now, China is twisting itself into a pretzel as it tries to rein in prices while also holding down the value of the renminbi. The central bank has increased interest rates twice since October, and in recent months it has boosted banks\xe2\x80\x99 reserve requirements three times and introduced price controls on food.'b'Annual inflation still hit 5.1 percent in November, the highest in more than two years, while higher interest rates are pulling in more money from abroad, fueling a housing bubble and further complicating economic management. Price controls and crackdowns on hoarding might temporarily ease the inflation rate, but they cannot provide a lasting solution. They tend to push businesses to the black market and depress production of regulated staples, leading to shortages \xe2\x80\x94 and often more inflation.'b'Allowing the renminbi to rise substantially would be far more effective. It would reduce the domestic price of imports, pressuring local producers to keep prices low. And it would temper money inflows by introducing a dose of uncertainty to the exchange rate. A rising currency could ultimately prove far less damaging, in terms of lost growth and employment, than the raft of conflicting policies that the Chinese government is deploying, so far unsuccessfully, to keep rising prices at bay.'b'So why won\xe2\x80\x99t China let the renminbi rise? The most plausible answer is that powerful interests in the export sector are swaying its decisions. Cheap exports have turbo-charged China\xe2\x80\x99s growth, but these days it is generating very few new jobs. And the policies supporting the export sector are detrimental to many Chinese, who earn little and pay more than they might for imports.'b'A more expensive renminbi would cool inflation. It would bolster Chinese leaders\xe2\x80\x99 stated objective of developing the domestic consumer economy. The government could deploy some of the hundreds of billons of dollars of reserves it has amassed (now parked in American Treasury bonds in order to keep a cheap currency) to pay for pensions and health insurance for ordinary people. Washington imposed sanctions on Belarus after the fraudulent 2006 vote and should consider whether they should be tightened.'b'The European Union has greater leverage and must re-evaluate its effort to encourage reform in Belarus with offers of improved relations, credit and economic aid. When it comes to Mr. Lukashenko, there is nothing to encourage.'b'Poland is trying an alternative approach. It has announced plans to abolish national visa fees for Belarussian citizens, open universities to independent-thinking Belarussians who can no longer study at home and create a center in Warsaw for the Belarussian opposition. Or maybe pink blueberries, a double row of kohlrabi, and a patch of Galeux d\xe2\x80\x99Eysines pumpkins. Anything is possible in January, when the seed catalogues have nearly all arrived. You can practically smell spring coming in their well-thumbed, dog-eared pages, where every cabbage, every cucumber, is perfectly ripe.'b'Every year brings the same hopes and the same mistakes. Seeds seem so inexpensive \xe2\x80\x94 only $3.95 a packet \xe2\x80\x94 and soon your subtotal is as much as a round trip to Reykjavik. Somehow you forget how much arable land you have and the length of your growing season and \xe2\x80\x94 most critical of all \xe2\x80\x94 the labor you will actually expend in the garden. This harvest you promise to put everything up. Not one tomato will go soft on the vine. Nothing will bolt. The basil will never freeze.'b'That is the beauty of reading seed catalogues while the next snowstorm approaches. We seed in an imaginary spring, weed in an imaginary summer, harvest in an imaginary fall. To many gardeners, seed catalogues are the most accurate depiction we have of the Garden from which humans were expelled. We read them with hope and credulity. You must be more than a gardener when the catalogues come. You must be a philosopher.'b'When daydreams are done, you have, on paper, a workable garden made up of the good old reliable varieties, and perhaps an experiment or two. A modesty overcomes you, and you decide to plant some of last year\xe2\x80\x99s leftover seeds. 'b''b'New Haven'b'THE announcement that Representatives Heath Shuler of North Carolina and Jason Chaffetz of Utah 'b'are planning to wear guns in their home districts'b'  has surprised many, but in fact the United States has had armed congressmen before. In the rough-and-tumble Congress of the 1830s, 1840s and 1850s, politicians regularly wore weapons on the House and Senate floors, and sometimes used them.'b'During one 1836 melee in the House, a witness observed representatives with \xe2\x80\x9cpistols in hand.\xe2\x80\x9d In a committee hearing that same year, one House member became so enraged at  the testimony of  a witness that he reached for his gun; when the terrified witness refused to return, he was brought before the House on a charge of contempt.'b'Perhaps most dramatic of all, during a debate in 1850, Senator Henry Foote of Mississippi pulled a pistol on Senator Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri. (Someone eventually took it from his hand.) Foote had decided in advance that if he felt threatened, he would grab his gun and run for the aisle in the hope that stray shots wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hit bystanders.'b'Most famously, in 1856, Representative Preston Brooks of South Carolina caned Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts on the Senate floor so brutally that Sumner  had to be virtually carried from the chamber \xe2\x80\x94 and did not retake his seat for three years. Clearly, wielded with brute force, a cane could be a potent weapon.'b'By the 1850s, violence was common in Washington. Not long after Sumner\xe2\x80\x99s caning, a magazine told the story of a Michigan judge who traveled by train to the nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital: \xe2\x80\x9cAs he entered the main hall of the depot, he saw a man engaged in caning another ferociously, all over the room. \xe2\x80\x98When I saw this,\xe2\x80\x99 says the judge, \xe2\x80\x98I knew I was in Washington.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In Congress, violence was often deployed strategically. Representatives and senators who were willing to back up their words with their weapons had an advantage, particularly in the debate over slavery. Generally speaking, Northerners were least likely to be armed, and thus most likely to back down. Congressional bullies pressed their advantage, using threats and violence to steer debate, silence opposition and influence votes.'b'In 1842, Representative Thomas Arnold of Tennessee, a member of the Whig Party, learned the hard way that these bullies meant business. After he reprimanded a pro-slavery member of his own party, two Southern Democrats stalked toward him, at least one of whom was armed with a bowie knife \xe2\x80\x94 a 6- to 12-inch blade often worn strapped to the back. Calling Arnold a \xe2\x80\x9cdamned coward,\xe2\x80\x9d his angry colleagues threatened to cut his throat \xe2\x80\x9cfrom ear to ear.\xe2\x80\x9d But Arnold wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a man to back down.  Ten years earlier, he had subdued an armed assassin on the Capitol steps.'b'As alarming as these outbursts were, until the 1840s, reporters played them down, in part to avoid becoming embroiled in fights themselves. (A good many reporters received beatings from outraged congressmen; one nearly had his finger bitten off.) So Americans knew relatively little of congressional violence.'b'That changed with the arrival of the telegraph. Congressmen suddenly had to confront the threat \xe2\x80\x94 or temptation \xe2\x80\x94 of \xe2\x80\x9cinstant\xe2\x80\x9d nationwide publicity. As Senator John Parker Hale of New Hampshire reminded his colleagues within minutes of the Foote-Benton clash, reports were \xe2\x80\x9calready traveling with lightning speed over the telegraph wires to the remotest borders of the Republic.\xe2\x80\x9d He added,  \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not impossible that even now it may have been rumored in the city of St. Louis that several senators are dead and weltering in their blood on the floor of the Senate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Violence was news, and news could spawn violence. Something had to be done, but what? To many, the answer was obvious: watch your words. As one onlooker wrote to the speaker of the House shortly after Sumner\xe2\x80\x99s caning, \xe2\x80\x9cgentlemen\xe2\x80\x9d who took part in the  debate over slavery should \xe2\x80\x9cscrupulously avoid the utterance of unnecessarily harsh language.\xe2\x80\x9d There was no other way to prevent the \xe2\x80\x9calmost murderous feeling\xe2\x80\x9d that could lead to \xe2\x80\x9cdemonstrations upon the floor, which in the present state of excitement, would almost certainly lead to a general melee and perhaps a dozen deaths in the twinkling of an eye.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Unfortunately, such admonitions had little effect. The violence in Congress continued to build until the outbreak of the Civil War.'b'Today, in the wake of an episode of violence against a member of Congress, we\xe2\x80\x99re again lamenting  the state of political rhetoric, now spread faster than ever via Twitter, Web sites, text messaging and e-mail. Once again, politicians are considering bearing arms \xe2\x80\x94  not to use against one another, but potentially against an angry public.'b'And once again we\xe2\x80\x99re reminded that words matter. Communication is the heart and soul of American democratic governance, but there hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been much fruitful discourse of late \xe2\x80\x94 among members of Congress, between the people and their representatives or in the public sphere. We need to get better at communicating not only quickly, but civilly.'b'After a strong and well-financed campaign by socially conservative groups, voters in Iowa in November removed three sitting State Supreme Court justices who had participated in 2009\xe2\x80\x99s unanimous ruling permitting same-sex marriage. Now several freshman Republican members of the Iowa House are readying a bill calling for the impeachment of the court\xe2\x80\x99s four other justices whose terms were not up for renewal.'b'For more than 200 years, no state or federal judge has been impeached to punish a judicial opinion \xe2\x80\x94 a record that has helped preserve the fair functioning of the courts. That isn\xe2\x80\x99t stopping these politicians, nor is the fact that issuing a controversial ruling does not amount to the \xe2\x80\x9cmisdemeanor or malfeasance in office\xe2\x80\x9d required for impeachment under the Iowa Constitution.'b'Iowa\xe2\x80\x99s new Republican governor, Terry Branstad, has voiced opposition to the impeachment effort. Although he disagrees with the court\xe2\x80\x99s marriage decision, he says the appropriate remedy is to defeat the justices in a retention vote. The Republican leader of the Iowa House, Kraig Paulsen, is bobbing and weaving, suggesting that impeachment is not one of his priorities, but that he will not stand in the way. The Democratic minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, has made clear his determination to tie up the chamber with dozens of amendments if necessary to block a vote on impeachment.'b'Meantime, a leader of the November ouster campaign, Bob Vander Plaats, plans to travel throughout Iowa in coming weeks to rally support for his call for the resignation of the four remaining justices. His group, the Family Leader, has already begun raising money to carry on the fight.'b'It is unlikely that Iowa\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic-controlled Senate would go along with removing the judges, but an impeachment trial would be disruptive and intentionally intimidating. The nation\xe2\x80\x99s democracy and cherished rights rely on keeping court decision-making above the fickle tugs of ordinary politics. Ousting judges to register disagreement with a particular court decision is a dangerous road to go down.'b'We welcome the announcement of a permanent cease-fire by the Basque separatist group ETA. After taking more than 800 lives since the late-1960s, ETA\xe2\x80\x99s senseless violence cannot end one day too soon. But what should have been an unequivocal renunciation of terrorism fell far short of what the Spanish, and Basque, people were entitled to expect.'b'The announcement was implicitly linked to political concessions, and it contained no commitment to dispose of ETA\xe2\x80\x99s lethal arsenal. The government of Prime Minister Jos\xc3\xa9 Luis Rodr\xc3\xadguez Zapatero of Spain rightly declared the announcement inadequate and demanded an unconditional cease-fire and disarmament.'b'ETA has announced \xe2\x80\x9cpermanent\xe2\x80\x9d cease-fires before, notably in March 2006. Mr. Zapatero opened peace talks, but nine months later ETA claimed that political progress had been too slow and returned to its murderous violence. Mr. Zapatero\xe2\x80\x99s tougher stand this time means that, for now, there will be no easing of the legal ban that prevents ETA\xe2\x80\x99s political allies from running for office and no slackening of the police pressure that has put top ETA leaders in jail or on the run.'b'During the Franco dictatorship, ETA\xe2\x80\x99s separatist goals, though not its terrorist methods, enjoyed support among Basques who had suffered decades of oppression. Those days are long past. The Basque region is now one of Spain\xe2\x80\x99s most affluent and enjoys substantial autonomy. ETA\xe2\x80\x99s killing sprees have turned former sympathizers into bitter enemies.'b'Spanish leaders have to wrestle with wrenching economic problems and cannot afford to tie themselves in knots over equivocally worded cease-fire declarations. If ETA is serious about peace, it must prove it by dropping all political conditions and verifiably disarming.'b'Washington'b'AS millions of us try to lose the weight we gained over the holidays, the Food and Drug Administration is due to make a decision with implications for those tipping the scales into obesity: whether to approve gastric lap bands for people who are just slightly obese. These devices are now approved only for dangerously obese adults, with a body mass index of at least 35.'b'Like gastric bypass surgery, a lap band reduces the size of the stomach so that eating a large meal is impossible. As a result, patients sometimes lose 100 pounds or more within a year, and that weight often stays off at least another year.'b'The surgery is more effective for most people than diet, exercise or diet pills. And since lap bands are less invasive, expensive and risky than gastric bypass, it is reasonable to ask whether the F.D.A. should approve the product for people seeking less drastic weight loss. Last month,'b' an advisory panel said it should'b'.'b'If the agency bases its decision on science rather than sympathy, however, it will reject the recommendation \xe2\x80\x94 because there is no research proving that a lap band provides slightly obese patients with long-term health benefits that are greater than its risks.'b'Some experts, including most bariatric surgeons, say the benefits are obvious even if the research is skimpy. And although most of them have financial ties to the lap-band industry, they also have an important fact on their side: weight loss during the first year after the procedure is often impressive.'b'But what matters for most patients is whether a lap band is more effective than diet and exercise for years and years after the surgery \xe2\x80\x94 and unfortunately we don\xe2\x80\x99t know if it is.'b'Under the proposed change, lap bands would be approved, for example, for a 5-foot-6-inch woman weighing 186 pounds (a body mass index of 30) who does not have diabetes or heart disease but does have joint pain that might be relieved by weight loss. Under the current rules, this woman could get a lap band only if she was willing to pay $12,000 to $30,000 for the 30-minute surgery. Because the procedure does not have F.D.A. approval, insurance plans and Medicare usually do not cover it.'b'Theoretically, lap bands could save lives and billions of health care dollars that would otherwise be spent to treat diabetes or heart disease, replace hip or knee joints or pay for often-ineffective weight loss strategies. But potential benefits are not the same as proven ones. And the reality is, we don\xe2\x80\x99t know how safe and effective lap-band surgery is for most people, whether they are 30 or 300 pounds overweight.'b'How could we lack such basic information? The F.D.A. approved Inamed\xe2\x80\x99s Lap-Band for the dangerously obese almost 10 years ago. But it did so based on the company\xe2\x80\x99s study of fewer than 200 very obese patients who had lap bands for three years. As a condition of approval, the agency required a follow-up study, but in 2006 Inamed was bought by Allergan, and the study was not completed. Last year, when Allergan asked the F.D.A. to expand approval to the not-so-obese (essentially doubling the potential patient pool), the request was based on a clinical trial of only 149 patients who had lap bands for one to two years.'b'In this study, the operations were done by carefully selected surgeons on relatively healthy patients, all under the age of 55 \xe2\x80\x94 which gave the study its best chance of producing favorable results. Even so, there were many adverse reactions. The most common were vomiting, difficulty swallowing, pain and gastroesophageal reflux. Five percent of subjects required additional surgery one to nine months after getting their lap bands, and in most cases this meant permanent removal. One of the devices that was removed had already eroded \xe2\x80\x94 raising concern about how long lap bands last. And unlike the initial surgery, often an outpatient procedure, the revisions and removals meant hospitalizations lasting up to a week.'b'The men in the Allergan study had worse outcomes than the women; 20 percent had their devices removed in the first year. This is not surprising, given an earlier report by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality that men were almost three times as likely as women to die from bariatric surgery. But the poor outcome for men needs further investigation, because the Allergan trial included only 14 men.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more, there were only two Asians, 14 African-Americans and 16 Hispanics among all the men and women in the study. Clearly, more research is needed on more people of both sexes and all ages and races.'b'Most important, we need studies of people who have had lap bands for longer than a few years to learn if the weight loss is lasting, if patients will tolerate the devices in the long run and what risks may accrue from living with one inside the body. The earlier three-year study of very obese patients found that one in four had their lap bands removed and not replaced.'b'The F.D.A.\xe2\x80\x99s job is to make sure that the lap band is safe and effective, but it cannot do this without long-term data on a more diverse group of patients. Moreover, if the F.D.A. approves the lap band for people who are only 30 or 40 pounds overweight, taxpayers may soon be paying billions of Medicare dollars for these procedures, and for fixing the potential complications. Health insurance companies would be pressured to follow Medicare\xe2\x80\x99s lead, which could add to the cost of insurance for all of us.'b'Obesity can kill, but when people are not at immediate risk of fatal illness, the F.D.A. does them no favors by giving its approval to an implanted medical device before it has been adequately tested.'b'Representative Peter King, a Republican of Long Island, 'b'has proposed a bill'b' that would prohibit the carrying of a gun within 1,000 feet of a member of Congress or other high-profile government official. That\xe2\x80\x99s a worthy notion, so far as it goes. But how about going a step further and prohibiting the carrying of a semiautomatic weapon around 9-year-old girls? Or 79-year-old women? Or any of the other victims who were shot down in the Tucson parking lot on Saturday?'b'Members of Congress are understandably worried about their own safety in the wake of the shooting rampage that was centered around Representative Gabrielle Giffords. It makes sense for the Capitol Police 'b'to work more closely'b' with local law enforcement agencies to enhance security at lawmakers\xe2\x80\x99 public events. But some of the ideas being proposed would have the effect of further distancing lawmakers from the people they represent \xe2\x80\x94 and elevate their safety above 'b'the 100,000 Americans'b' who are shot or killed with a gun every year.'b'Representative James Clyburn, a Democrat of South Carolina, said that lawmakers should no longer be treated like everyone else at airport security checkpoints, though that inconvenience seems to have nothing to do with the shooting. Representative Robert Brady, a Democrat of Pennsylvania, has proposed making it a federal crime to use language or symbols that could be perceived as threatening violence against all federal officials, an idea dangerously full of potential First Amendment violations. Representative Dan Burton, a Republican of Indiana, even wants to enclose the public gallery above the House chamber in Plexiglas. These ideas are unlikely to make lawmakers or the public any safer. But if members are concerned that some of the 283 million guns now in the hands of American civilians might one day be turned on them \xe2\x80\x94 and they should be \xe2\x80\x94 there are many things they can do.'b'They can follow the advice given on Tuesday by Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City, along with 10 other mayors, and begin restoring the nation\xe2\x80\x99s gun control laws to sanity \xe2\x80\x94  for the protection of everyone. The most obvious first steps are to ban the extended-round magazines used in the Arizona shooting and tighten a nearly useless system of background checks.'b'They also can ensure that federal and state financing for outreach to the mentally ill is increased, not cut, in the budget battles to come. Jared Loughner, the man accused of the Arizona shootings, apparently received no mental health treatment, even though officials at his college were very concerned about his mental state.'b'Instead of hiding, lawmakers must reach out to their constituents and help calm a troubled political environment without fear or self-absorbed overreaction.'b'The most important new message contained in the final report of the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill is aimed squarely at Congress: If lawmakers hope to win popular support for ramped-up oil drilling in America\xe2\x80\x99s coastal waters then they must make sure that every possible precaution is taken to reduce the chances of another catastrophe like the spill.'b'The question is whether the newly constituted Congress is in a mood to listen. What the commission is asking for are tough new rules and money to strengthen federal oversight at a time when the House is controlled by politicians who broadly oppose new spending and seem hostile to regulation of any sort.'b'Yet Congress must act, and President Obama should use some of what leverage he has in this new political alignment to see that it does. As the commission co-chairman, Bob Graham, noted, without dramatic action another deep-water disaster will inevitably occur, leaving the public to \xe2\x80\x9cwonder why Congress, the administration and industry stood by and did nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The commission\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'380-page report'b' is the most exhaustive accounting so far of what happened on the Deepwater Horizon. As it forecast in a preliminary summary, the commission  blames the accident largely on poor decisions  and other \xe2\x80\x9cmanagement failures\xe2\x80\x9d by three companies involved: BP, Transocean and Halliburton.'b'It also strongly reinforces its earlier indictments of industry for failing to prepare adequate response plans and of government regulators for allowing themselves to be captured by an industry they were meant to oversee.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s new are 'b'the recommendations'b'. All are sound, and most will require Congressional help.'b''b'SAFETY'b' The commission recommended much tougher rules governing basic drilling issues like well design and vital equipment like blowout preventers. Some of these have already been put in place by the Interior Department. More broadly, it urged Congress to create an independent safety agency within the department free of any political influence and with enforcement authority to oversee all aspects of offshore drilling.'b''b'FINANCING 'b'Though it did not specify a figure, the commission implored Congress to provide \xe2\x80\x9cadequate and predictable\xe2\x80\x9d financing for regulatory oversight. It noted that money for federal regulators had remained static for 20 years while the risks associated with drilling increased dramatically as rigs moved into deeper and deeper waters.'b''b'LIABILITY 'b'The commission noted that the present $75 million liability cap for individual accidents is hardly enough to deter sloppy behavior. It recommended a much higher figure, without identifying one.'b''b'SCIENCE 'b'The Deepwater Horizon explosion revealed that both industry and federal regulators had given environmental reviews short shrift. The commission recommends that Congress amend the various laws governing offshore drilling to make sure that government scientists and fish and wildlife experts are consulted at every step of the process \xe2\x80\x94  from the leasing of areas for exploration to the actual drilling of individual wells.'b''b'RESTORATION 'b'Congress is urged to dedicate 80 percent of the penalties assessed under the Clean Water Act \xe2\x80\x94 they could be as high as $20 billion \xe2\x80\x94 to restoring the fragile Mississippi Delta ecosystem. The commission\xe2\x80\x99s other co-chairman, William Reilly, noted that the delta  had been badly degraded over the years and \xe2\x80\x9cis likely to continue silently washing away unless decisive action is taken.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This by no means exhausts the commission\xe2\x80\x99s list of useful ideas. The House of Representatives endorsed several of them in an oil bill it passed last year (the Senate did nothing). Representative Edward Markey, a Democrat of Massachusetts, said that he would hold hearings and introduce an even stronger bill this year. We wish him well \xe2\x80\x94 and urge Mr. Obama to support him.'b'To the Editor:'b'As a lifelong Democrat in Pima County, Arizona, I was heartened and touched by Senator John McCain\xe2\x80\x99s and Speaker John A. After all, you chose each other.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Hank Wallace'b'\nWashington, Jan. 7, 2011'b''b'It is a president\xe2\x80\x99s responsibility to salve a national wound. Congress should have an actual debate about Representative Carolyn McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s bill to reduce gun violence.'b'You will notice I just said have a debate. And the bill does not even control guns. It simply bans the sale of the special bullet clip that allowed the Tucson gunman to shoot 20 people without reloading.'b'McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s husband was killed and her son permanently injured when a gunman using a pistol with a similar  \xe2\x80\x94  but less powerful  \xe2\x80\x94  kind of clip opened fire on the Long Island Rail Road in 1993. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why I came to Congress,\xe2\x80\x9d she said on Wednesday. But so far she has collected co-sponsors only from the same small band of members who always support this kind of legislation.'b'Members of Congress are so terrified of the political power of the National Rifle Association that the Democrats, when they were in power, declined even to give McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s bill a hearing. And it certainly would also have to involve a conversation over a technology that can turn a pistol into the equivalent of a somewhat slow-moving machine gun.'b'McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s bill might not have saved Representative Gabrielle Giffords from being shot. But it has to be worth talking about whether it could have saved some of her constituents.'b'So far, most of the proposals from members of Congress for practical action to reduce gun violence have been directed at protecting themselves. Representative Peter King of New York introduced a bill to ban anyone from carrying a gun in the vicinity of a federal official. Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. of Illinois suggested reversing a recent cut in members\xe2\x80\x99 office budgets and tacking on another 10 percent increase to pay for improved security.
