And two members vowed to carry their pistols with them when they go about the people\xe2\x80\x99s business back in their districts.'b'Following the president\xe2\x80\x99s lead, I would argue that Congress has the capacity for higher purpose.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI believe we can be better,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThose who died here \xe2\x80\x94  those who saved lives here \xe2\x80\x94  they help me believe. We may not be able to stop all evil in the world, but I know that how we treat one another is entirely up to us.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In that light, I believe members of Congress can have a hearing and a civilized debate on a bill that is modest and relevant but that is opposed by a hyperpowerful lobbying group that scares the daylight out of them.'b'Maybe they could do it just to prove it to themselves that they can.'b'Just a thought.'b'Arlington, Va.'b'A  NATO oil tanker truck 'b'was blown up'b' by insurgents at the Pakistan-Afghanistan border last week, and while no one was injured, the incident temporarily closed the Khyber Pass, the main supply artery for Western troops in the Afghan theater. This has become an all-too-routine occurrence; in the last nine years some 1,000 Americans have been killed on fuel-related missions in Iraq and Afghanistan.'b'Until the Defense Department develops battlefield policies recognizing that energy efficiency contributes to military effectiveness, more blood will be shed, billions of dollars will be wasted, our enemies will have thousands of vulnerable fuel trucks for targets and our commanders will continue to be distracted by the task of overseeing fuel convoys.'b'As the military\xe2\x80\x99s senior logistician in Iraq for 15 months in 2006 and 2007, I tracked the tremendous amounts of fuel needed to power the generators providing electricity for air-conditioning and other essential uses in shelters hastily constructed of canvas, plywood and sheet metal. Today our troops in Afghanistan are furiously building more of the same. Nine years into that war, they are living more or less as Alexander the Great\xe2\x80\x99s men did 23 centuries ago \xe2\x80\x94 in often dangerous and always inefficient tents and shacks.'b'For many in the military, improving the situation isn\xe2\x80\x99t a priority. \xe2\x80\x9cTo hell with efficiency, effectiveness is all I care about,\xe2\x80\x9d a finger-wagging superior once told me in Iraq. But keeping our bases and units supplied with fuel endangers not just the lives of many soldiers manning the tanker convoys, it also drains $24 billion a year from the Pentagon budget. The solution: a Defense Department policy requiring all structures in the combat zone be energy-efficient.'b'Upgrading the efficiency at our bases and outposts would not require any new technology. Watch almost any home renovation show and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see spray foam being used to cut energy use significantly. Cured spray foam is nontoxic, fire-resistant and waterproof. (Disclosure: until last month, I was the chief operating officer of an energy consulting company, but I have no financial stake in the issue.)'b'In 2007, an Army study found that spraying foam insulation on the exterior of inefficient structures would reduce their energy requirements by over 80 percent and improve the quality of life for the troops living in them. Accordingly, we obtained the necessary safety, fire and disposal certifications and began a $95 million effort in Iraq; a study last year confirmed this initiative was saving about $1 billion a year and taking more than 11,000 fuel trucks off the road.'b'Yet, despite three years of quantitative proof that insulated structures in extreme climates tremendously reduce fuel requirements, there has been little effort to broaden the scope of the initiative.'b'An across-the-board Pentagon efficiency mandate would have many benefits. First, it would save many lives: there are casualties in one out of every 24 fuel supply convoys in Afghanistan; 47 drivers were killed there last year. It would save money; it costs taxpayers about $66 million a day for air-conditioning in the war zones.'b'It would also reduce opportunities for the enemy. Some soldiers jokingly call the fuel trucks \xe2\x80\x9cTaliban targets,\xe2\x80\x9d and for good reason \xe2\x80\x94 they are a high-payoff quarry for insurgents using nothing but homemade bombs. In addition, having fewer fuel shipments would allow NATO to take highly trained troops off convoy duty and use them in combat or, even better, send them home.'b'Why has the Defense Department dragged its feet on energy efficiency? Chalk it up to the impediments to change found in any large organization: passive leadership, lack of accountability, competing priorities. In this case, add skepticism over the data, calls for additional studies and unfounded environmental concerns.'b'But strong leadership can overcome these obstacles, as Secretary of Defense Robert Gates demonstrated in 2008 when he oversaw the acquisition and deployment in Iraq of a new generation of mine-resistant, ambush-protected fighting vehicles, which brought about a decline of up to 90 percent in the deaths of American troops from roadside bombs.'b'A new energy efficiency policy would not only save lives and cut costs, it would make a powerful statement regarding the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s commitment to lowering our dependence on foreign oil. We have the finest troops in history; improving the insulation in their structures would not only keep them more comfortable, it would also go a long way to bringing more of them home safely.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Wilderness Underfoot'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 2):'b'Though there is considerable interest in learning about New York City\xe2\x80\x99s 7,400 miles of sewer lines, entering them is not only illegal, but it is also potentially fatal.'b'Sewers pose a series of life-threatening risks: pockets of poisonous gas can build up; temperature changes can reach extreme levels of hot and cold; infectious bacteria and pathogens can immediately affect one\xe2\x80\x99s immune system; and even a few minutes of hard rain can potentially flood the entire system with little or no warning. On average, there are 92 deaths a year from improper entries into confined spaces in the United States.'b'Only the most highly trained and authorized individuals, with emergency escape air packs, communication and air monitoring equipment and work to do in connection with their jobs, should ever enter sewers.'b'Instead of breaking the law and placing yourself in extreme danger, stop by and visit the Department of Environmental Protection\xe2\x80\x99s Newtown Creek Visitor Center in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, which includes information and displays about the city\xe2\x80\x99s wastewater system. It\xe2\x80\x99s safe, fun and free.'b'Cas Holloway'b' Commissioner, New York City'b' Dept. of Environmental Protection'b' Flushing, Queens, Jan. 4, 2011'b''b''b''b'THE 'b'collapse of Lebanon\xe2\x80\x99s government'b' on Tuesday signaled the final stage in Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s rise from resistance group to ruling power. While Hezbollah technically remains the head of the political opposition in Beirut, make no mistake: the Party of God has fully consolidated its control in Lebanon, and will stop at nothing \xe2\x80\x94 including civil war \xe2\x80\x94 to protect its position.'b'The crisis was precipitated by Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s opposition to a United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the 'b'2005 assassination of a former prime minister'b', Rafik Hariri. Some analysts speculate that the current Lebanese government \xe2\x80\x94 led by Prime Minister Saad Hariri, the assassinated man\xe2\x80\x99s son \xe2\x80\x94 could stabilize the political situation by rejecting the legitimacy of the tribunal.'b'Mr. Hariri really has no choice but to stand firm in Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s game of chicken: even if he could stymie Hezbollah in the short term by giving in, he would eventually have no authority at all were he to abandon the rule of law. He will have to insist on accountability for his father\xe2\x80\x99s assassins, even if he loses his position in the process. His coalition remains a viable alternative to Hezbollah only as long as it sticks to the pluralistic and law-based values that distinguish it from its theocratic and belligerent enemies.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s predicament in Lebanon mirrors that of much of the Arab world, where stability often comes at the price of justice. Furthermore, it highlights America\xe2\x80\x99s limited influence. Washington lent strong rhetorical support to the Hariri coalition when it came first to power in 2005, but was unable to stop Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s troops and their supporters from taking over the streets of Beirut and forcibly acquiring veto power over the government by gaining \xe2\x80\x9cthe blocking third\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 10 of the cabinet\xe2\x80\x99s 30 ministerial seats.'b'It was Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s exercising of that power, with the resignation of the 10 opposition ministers along with one independent, that toppled the government this week just when Prime Minister Hariri was meeting with President Obama in Washington.'b'To an outsider, the crisis might appear baffling. More than five years after the car-bomb murder of Rafik Hariri, the international tribunal is still meandering its way toward indicting suspects. Hezbollah, re-armed and resurgent after the war with Israel in the summer of 2006, has had a string of political and popular victories. The influence of its sponsors, Syria and Iran, has only grown. And talks between Syria and Saudi Arabia that might have stabilized the government fell apart this week.'b'Why, then, would Hezbollah change the political dynamic now?'b'Simply put, Hezbollah cannot afford the blow to its popular legitimacy that would occur if it is pinned with the Hariri killing. The group\xe2\x80\x99s power depends on the unconditional backing of its roughly 1 million supporters. Its constituents are the only audience that matters to Hezbollah, which styles itself as sole protector of Arab dignity from humiliation by Israel and the United States.'b'These supporters will be hard-pressed to understand, much less forgive, their party if it is proved to have killed a leader who was loved by the nation\xe2\x80\x99s Sunni Muslims and also respected by Christians, Druze and even many Shiites,  who form Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s core support. That is why Hezbollah denies any role in the assassination even though it has unabashedly taken responsibility for destabilizing moves like setting off the 2006 war with Israel or pushing Lebanon to the brink of civil war in 2008.'b'But its excuses are wearing thin. 'b'Leaked evidence based on cellphone records'b' has placed a Hezbollah team at the scene of the assassination. Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s leaders insist that its men were trying to protect Rafik Hariri, and that Israel was behind the killing. But if it is proved to have taken part in the Hariri hit and assassination campaigns against other moderate Lebanese figures, Hezbollah will look to many civilians like just another power-drunk militant movement.'b'What options remain for the younger Mr. Hariri? 'b'The authors of Freakonomics noted'b' that a home with a swimming pool is considerably more dangerous for small children than a home with a gun. I asked Professor Hemenway how he would oversee a public health approach to reducing gun deaths and injuries. He suggested:'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 Limit gun purchases to one per month per person, to reduce gun trafficking. Most recently, two condemned men convicted on the basis of confessions were exonerated by DNA evidence.'b'Governor Quinn said last fall that he supported the moratorium as well as capital punishment \xe2\x80\x9capplied carefully and fairly.\xe2\x80\x9d Illinois\xe2\x80\x99s own experience has shown why that is not possible. Most modern nations, and 15 states in this country, have rightly abandoned the barbarism of state executions. The sanctity of human life and the honor of the state require Governor Quinn to lead Illinois beyond its wrenching history of wrongful death-row convictions.'b'After the financial meltdown, is it really possible a company argued at the Supreme Court that too much information for investors is as bad as too little?'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s what Matrixx Initiatives did on Monday 'b'in a case'b' about whether it should have disclosed complaints regarding Zicam, its homeopathic cold remedy. Twenty-three people claimed that they took Zicam and lost their sense of smell, a condition known as anosmia.'b'The case arose after ABC\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGood Morning America\xe2\x80\x9d aired a piece questioning Zicam\xe2\x80\x99s safety. The price of Matrixx\xe2\x80\x99s stock fell 24 percent. Shareholders sued in a class action, saying Matrixx should have warned investors about the problems and related lawsuits.'b'The company claimed that it didn\xe2\x80\x99t have to, arguing that the complaints had no scientific basis, that any loss of smell should be blamed on illness and that the number of complaints was not statistically significant.'b'Justice Stephen Breyer seemed to surprise himself when he dismissed the \xe2\x80\x9cstatistical\xe2\x80\x9d claim: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be. I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to take a position yet. But, look, Albert Einstein had the theory of relativity without any empirical evidence, O.K.?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled in favor of the shareholders, saying the case should go back to the trial court. The Supreme Court should do the same. The appeals court said a jury should answer these legal questions: Was the information at issue \xe2\x80\x9cmaterial\xe2\x80\x9d? Would a reasonable shareholder \xe2\x80\x9cconsider it important\xe2\x80\x9d?'b'In a friend of the court filing, the government argued that the court has long held that if an investor would have viewed a new piece of information as \xe2\x80\x9cmeaningfully\xe2\x80\x9d altering \xe2\x80\x9cthe total mix\xe2\x80\x9d of information available, it has been considered material. Instead, Matrixx is proposing an isolated yes-or-no rule: unless a claim about a product is shown to be statistically significant, there is no reason to tell investors about it.'b'As some professors put it in a brief supporting the shareholders, requiring that high a standard to shield investors from unproven allegations would treat them as \xe2\x80\x9cnitwits\xe2\x80\x9d unable to make their own judgments about good and bad information. The information in this case was spot on. Matrixx recalled Zicam in 2009, after the Food and Drug Administration warned consumers not to use it.'b'On Monday, Justice Elena Kagan posed this hypothetical: 10 users of a new contact lens solution go blind. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no way that anybody would tell you that these 10 cases are statistically significant,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Would Matrixx\xe2\x80\x99s counsel stop using the product? Would a reasonable investor want to know about the 10 cases?'b'Matrixx\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer, predictably, said he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want the information. A show of hands in the packed courtroom would likely have yielded enough yeses to feel statistically significant.'b'For a moment, it seemed as if the new year might just deliver us from spam. Last summer, spam volumes started declining around the world, from about 250 billion messages a day in July \xe2\x80\x94 almost 40 for each woman, man and child in the world \xe2\x80\x94 to about 100 billion a day in November. Then, on Dec. 25, the Rustock botnet, the biggest spam generator, vanished from the Internet. (Two other smaller ones dropped off, too, a few days later.) Volume plummeted to fewer than 30 billion a day.'b'We are sorry to shatter your hopes. Rustock kicked back into operation on Monday, bombarding the world with 14 billion pieces of spam, mostly about pharmaceuticals, through a vast network of infected computers that generate spam without their owners knowing.'b'Internet safety experts caution that the rebound will probably continue. In 2008, spam plunged by three-quarters when McColo, a hosting company in California, was shut down. But the hosting was simply moved to other servers and spam levels recovered quickly. This time security experts don\xe2\x80\x99t understand quite what was driving the decline. Some suggested the controllers of Rustock might have just gone on vacation.'b'Governments are struggling against this nuisance. In December, Canada was the last of the wealthy nations in the Group of 8 to pass legislation that would penalize businesses that distributed unsolicited commercial e-mail in Canada. The problem is that products pitched with spam are often as shady as the networks, and everyone involved is unlikely to fear such fines.'b'Spam is hard to stamp out because it is so cheap to send. In 2008, researchers estimated that it cost $80 for each million messages. The trick is how to make it more expensive. In April 2002, the South Korean Internet portal Daum created an online stamp system to charge bulk e-mailers up to 0.8 cents per message to send e-mail to its subscribers. Inbound bulk e-mail fell by more than half in the first few months of the fee. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t try to explain the rampage that occurred there. Instead, he used the occasion as a national Sabbath \xe2\x80\x94 as a chance to step out of the torrent of events and reflect. He did it with an uplifting spirit. He not only expressed the country\xe2\x80\x99s sense of loss but also celebrated the lives of the victims and the possibility for renewal.'b'Of course, even a great speech won\xe2\x80\x99t usher in a period of civility. Speeches about civility will be taken to heart most by those people whose good character renders them unnecessary. Meanwhile, those who are inclined to intellectual thuggery and partisan one-sidedness will temporarily resolve to do better but then slip back to old habits the next time their pride feels threatened.'b'Civility is a tree with deep roots, and without the roots, it can\xe2\x80\x99t last. So what are those roots? They are failure, sin, weakness and ignorance.'b'Every sensible person involved in politics and public life knows that their work is laced with failure. Every column, every speech, every piece of legislation and every executive decision has its own humiliating shortcomings. There are always arguments you should have made better, implications you should have anticipated, other points of view you should have taken on board.'b'Moreover, even if you are at your best, your efforts will still be laced with failure. The truth is fragmentary and it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to capture all of it. There are competing goods that can never be fully reconciled. The world is more complicated than any human intelligence can comprehend.'b'But every sensible person in public life also feels redeemed by others. You may write a mediocre column or make a mediocre speech or propose a mediocre piece of legislation, but others argue with you, correct you and introduce elements you never thought of. Each of these efforts may also be flawed, but together, if the system is working well, they move things gradually forward.'b'Each individual step may be imbalanced, but in succession they make the social organism better.'b'As a result, every sensible person feels a sense of gratitude for this process. We all get to live lives better than we deserve because our individual shortcomings are transmuted into communal improvement. We find meaning \xe2\x80\x94 and can only find meaning \xe2\x80\x94 in the role we play in that larger social enterprise.'b'So this is where civility comes from \xe2\x80\x94 from a sense of personal modesty and from the ensuing gratitude for the political process. Civility is the natural state for people who know how limited their own individual powers are and know, too, that they need the conversation. They are useless without the conversation.'b'The problem is that over the past 40 years or so we have gone from a culture that reminds people of their own limitations to a culture that encourages people to think highly of themselves. The nation\xe2\x80\x99s founders had a modest but realistic opinion of themselves and of the voters. They erected all sorts of institutional and social restraints to protect Americans from themselves. They admired George Washington because of the way he kept himself in check.'b'But over the past few decades, people have lost a sense of their own sinfulness. Children are raised amid a chorus of applause. Politics has become less about institutional restraint and more about giving voters whatever they want at that second. Joe DiMaggio didn\xe2\x80\x99t ostentatiously admire his own home runs, but now athletes routinely celebrate themselves as part of the self-branding process.'b'So, of course, you get narcissists who believe they or members of their party possess direct access to the truth. Of course you get people who prefer monologue to dialogue. Of course you get people who detest politics because it frustrates their ability to get 100 percent of what they want. Of course you get people who gravitate toward the like-minded and loathe their political opponents. They feel no need for balance and correction.'b'Beneath all the other things that have contributed to polarization and the loss of civility, the most important is this: The roots of modesty have been carved away.'b'President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s speech in Tucson was a good step, but there will have to be a bipartisan project like comprehensive tax reform to get people conversing again. Most of all, there will have to be a return to modesty.'b'In a famous passage, Reinhold Niebuhr put it best: \xe2\x80\x9cNothing that is worth doing can be achieved in our lifetime; therefore, we must be saved by hope. ... Nothing we do, however virtuous, can be accomplished alone; therefore, we are saved by love. No virtuous act is quite as virtuous from the standpoint of our friend or foe as it is from our standpoint. Therefore, we must be saved by the final form of love, which is forgiveness.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'THE new Congress is less than two weeks old, but pundits from across the political spectrum are already urging the newly empowered Republicans to take on Medicare and Social Security.'b'Conservatives argue it\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to make good on the party\xe2\x80\x99s limited-government rhetoric. Centrists say it\xe2\x80\x99s the only plausible way to bring the budget into sustainable balance. Even some liberals are telling the Republicans to demonstrate the courage of their anti-spending convictions.'b'Reforming these programs is vital to our nation\xe2\x80\x99s long-term fiscal health \xe2\x80\x94 which is why Republicans should resist this advice and leave the issue alone. Reform is impossible this year or next unless President Obama takes the lead on it. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, Republicans have no mandate for reform, and a failed attempt will only set back the cause.'b'Some Republicans are understandably eager to take on these entitlements. \xe2\x80\x9cThe third rail is not the third rail anymore,\xe2\x80\x9d Representative Paul Ryan, a Republican from Wisconsin,'b' said in December.'b''b'Maybe he\xe2\x80\x99s right. Newt Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s 1995 Republican revolution fizzled when President Bill Clinton fought him over Medicare cuts. President George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s effort to reform Social Security in 2005 ended any political momentum he brought to his second term.'b'Would-be reformers should draw two lessons from this history. The first is that reform can\xe2\x80\x99t be sprung on the electorate. Reagan hadn\xe2\x80\x99t campaigned on cutting Social Security in 1980, nor did the Gingrich Republicans promise to reduce the growth of Medicare.'b'Today is no different: while some Republican candidates in the last election spoke forthrightly about the need to rein in these programs \xe2\x80\x94 notably Representative Ryan himself, but also new Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Rand Paul of Kentucky \xe2\x80\x94 most of them didn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'As a result, if Republicans spend much of the next two years fighting over these programs, voters who depend on them are going to be unpleasantly surprised. Keep in mind that most voters oppose cuts to Social Security and Medicare, so they are likely to be very nervous about any proposals to restrain their growth, especially if opponents portray such cuts as excessive. Even worse, most members of Congress are not well informed about these programs, so they\xe2\x80\x99ll have a hard time soothing public anxieties.'b'The second lesson is that presidential support for reform is a necessary, though not a sufficient, condition for success. As John Boehner, the new speaker of the House, said himself on election night, governing from Capitol Hill doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work \xe2\x80\x94 the president has to set the agenda.'b'If Mr. Obama delivers a good-faith proposal for Social Security, for example in this month\xe2\x80\x99s State of the Union address, then by all means Republicans should offer a serious counterproposal and, depending on their differences, negotiate. If he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t, then Republicans should wait on a new president in 2013.'b'But they should do more than wait: in the event of presidential inaction, reformers should blame Mr. Obama for the lack of progress and work to make entitlements a litmus-test issue in the Republican presidential primaries. The goal should be to nominate someone willing to make a strong case for reducing entitlement growth as part of a larger strategy to restore American prosperity.'b'True, reform won\xe2\x80\x99t generate the near-term budget savings the federal government needs to avoid a fiscal crisis this decade. Even the boldest plans phase their cuts in gradually, and they exempt people who are at or near retirement.'b'But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that all action on entitlements can be deferred. Medicaid is wrecking state budgets and is set to expand thanks to the Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 new health care law. It is also more politically vulnerable than Social Security or Medicare, which offer benefits to everyone who reaches old age. As they try to undo the health care law, Republicans might also consider capping Medicaid\xe2\x80\x99s growth and sending the savings back to the states. It would be a mistake, however, for Republicans to take the same approach to Social Security or Medicare.'b'Instead, they should show their budget-hawk bona fides by making spending cuts elsewhere.'b'They should begin by freezing or cutting government payrolls, including in the legislative branch \xe2\x80\x94 something Republicans have already started doing. Message: the federal government is not just imposing sacrifices but sharing them. Then they should get control of the discretionary, or non-entitlement, portions of the budget, which are small only in comparison with entitlements. Only after winning those fights, and probably electing a new president, should the old-age entitlements be up for reform.'b'There are times when it is admirable for a politician to support legislation for the public good even if it will cost him his own re-election. Some of the Democrats who voted for the new health care law and then lost in November probably feel that way. But that tradeoff made sense only because they knew they could actually pass the law.'b'There is no point to Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 endangering their seats for legislation, however worthy, unless they have a good shot at getting a presidential signature on it. They will get their answer in the next State of the Union address.'b'Dhaka, Bangladesh'b'IN the 1970s, when I began working here on what would eventually be called \xe2\x80\x9cmicrocredit,\xe2\x80\x9d one of my goals was to eliminate the presence of loan sharks who grow rich by preying on the poor. In 1983, I founded Grameen Bank to provide small loans that people, especially poor women, could use to bring themselves out of poverty. At that time, I never imagined that one day microcredit would give rise to its own breed of loan sharks.'b'But it has. And as a result, 'b'many borrowers in India have been defaulting on their 'b'microloans'b','b' which could then result in lenders being driven out of business.  India\xe2\x80\x99s crisis points to a clear need to get microcredit back on track.'b'Troubles with microcredit began around 2005, when many lenders started looking for ways to make a profit on the loans by shifting from their status as nonprofit organizations to commercial enterprises. In 2007, Compartamos, a Mexican bank, became Latin America\xe2\x80\x99s first microcredit bank to go public. And this past August, SKS Microfinance, the largest bank of its kind in India,   raised $358 million in an initial public offering.'b'To ensure that the small loans would be profitable for their shareholders, such banks needed to raise interest rates  and engage in aggressive marketing and loan collection. The kind of empathy that had once been shown toward borrowers when the lenders were nonprofits disappeared. The people whom microcredit was supposed to help were being harmed. In India, borrowers came to believe lenders were taking advantage of them, and stopped repaying their loans.'b'Commercialization has been a terrible wrong turn for microfinance, and it indicates a worrying \xe2\x80\x9cmission drift\xe2\x80\x9d in the motivation of those lending to the poor. Poverty should be eradicated, not seen as a money-making opportunity.'b'There are serious practical problems with treating microcredit as an ordinary profit-maximizing business. Instead of creating wholesale funds dedicated to lending money to microfinance institutions, as Bangladesh has done,  these commercial organizations raise larger sums in volatile international financial markets, and then transmit financial risks to the poor.'b'Furthermore, it means commercial microcredit institutions are subject to demands for ever-increasing profits, which can only come in the form of higher interest rates charged to the poor, defeating the very purpose of the loans.'b'Some advocates of commercialization say it\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to attract the money that\xe2\x80\x99s needed to expand the availability of microcredit and to \xe2\x80\x9cliberate\xe2\x80\x9d the system from dependence on foundations and other charitable donors. But it is possible to harness investment in microcredit \xe2\x80\x94 and even make a profit \xe2\x80\x94 without working through either charities or global financial markets.'b'Grameen Bank, where I am managing director, has 2,500 branches in Bangladesh. It lends out more than $100 million a month, from loans of less than $10 for beggars in our \xe2\x80\x9cStruggling Members\xe2\x80\x9d program, to micro-enterprise loans of about $1,000.  Most branches are financially self-reliant, dependent only on deposits from ordinary Bangladeshis.   When borrowers join the bank, they open a savings account. All borrowers have savings accounts at the bank, many with balances larger than their loans. And every year, the bank\xe2\x80\x99s profits are returned to the borrowers \xe2\x80\x94 97 percent of them poor women \xe2\x80\x94 in the form of dividends.'b'More microcredit institutions should adopt this model. The community needs to reaffirm the original definition of microcredit, abandon commercialization and turn back to serving the poor.'b'Stricter government regulation could help. The maximum interest rate should not exceed the cost of the fund \xe2\x80\x94 meaning the cost that is incurred by the bank to procure the money to lend \xe2\x80\x94 plus 15 percent of the fund. That 15 percent goes to cover operational costs and contribute to profit. In the case of Grameen Bank, the cost of fund is 10 percent. So, the maximum interest rate could be 25 percent. However, we charge 20 percent to the borrowers. The ideal \xe2\x80\x9cspread\xe2\x80\x9d between the cost of the fund and the lending rate should be close to 10 percent.'b'To enforce such a cap, every country where microloans are made needs a microcredit regulatory authority. Bangladesh, which has the most microcredit borrowers per square mile in the world, 'b'has had such an authority'b' for several years,  and it is devoted to ensuring transparency in lending and prevented excessive interest rates and collection practices. In the future, it may be able to accredit microfinance banks. India, with its burgeoning microcredit sector, is most in need of a similar agency.'b'There are always people eager to take advantage of the vulnerable. But credit programs that seek to profit from the suffering of the poor should not be described as \xe2\x80\x9cmicrocredit,\xe2\x80\x9d and investors who own such programs should not be allowed to benefit from the trust and respect that microcredit banks have rightly earned.'b'Governments are responsible for preventing such abuse. In 1997, then First Lady Hillary Clinton and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh met with other world leaders to commit to providing 100 million poor people with microloans and other financial services by 2005. At the time, it looked like an utterly impossible task, but by 2006 we had achieved it. World leaders should come together again to provide the powerful and visionary leadership to help steer microcredit back on course.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Organize This!'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 9):'b'I like to think I keep an organized home, but the home-organizing philosophy of Barbara Reich deserves an argument. The project includes improvements in the port of Cap Haitien and in water supply, sewage treatment and electrification.'b'Haiti obviously needs more than one showcase project. And that as the economy is rebuilt, it must also be relocated out of badly crowded Port-au-Prince.'b'While Haiti remains traumatized by the worst urban disaster in history, it has a lot going for it: new structures to promote sustainable development and investment, large pledges of money and the enduring patience and energy of its people. But impunity for assassination is too high a price to pay for its support.'b'Hezbollah depends on Syrian money and arms and responds to pressure from Damascus. A troubling increase in prison suicides suggests that all of the problems have not been solved.'b'State records show that there were 20 suicides in 2010, double the number in 2009 and the highest since 1978, the first year for which records were released. In addition, the Department of Corrections has improved conditions for the mentally ill, creating new therapeutic programs and retraining staff. Most important, entering inmates are screened by mental health professionals.'b'Advocates for the mentally ill say that suicide prevention programs are being poorly implemented. The fact that some who had committed suicide were not even listed on the mental health caseload as needing close attention is certainly worrying.'b'The rising suicide rate must be investigated and remedies quickly found. There is no vaccine and no curative treatment.'b'With 95 percent of all  cases in the world, southern Sudan is now the key to completing the global campaign by 2012, and most cases of Guinea worm are now focused in only six of its 80 counties.
