'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Your  editorial \xe2\x80\x9cSouthern Sudan Votes\xe2\x80\x9d noted the importance of oil in the independence referendum in southern Sudan. Oil is not the only natural resource whose management will be critical to the fate of the new nation.'b'Southern Sudan boasts vast tracts of savannas, wetlands and woodlands that play host to some of the most spectacular and important wildlife populations in Africa and the world\xe2\x80\x99s second-largest wildlife migration \xe2\x80\x94 of some 1.3 million antelope. These resources could become one of the greatest tourism attractions in Africa and a key component of South Sudan\xe2\x80\x99s growth and economic security.'b'There is an unprecedented opportunity now for wildlife conservation, sustainable natural resource management and environmentally friendly ecotourism to be integrated into one nation-building process.'b'Steven Sanderson'b'\nPresident and Chief Executive'b'\nWildlife Conservation Society'b'\nBronx, Jan. 8, 2011'b''b''b''b'AFRICA has endured a tortured history of political instability and religious, racial and ethnic strife. In order to understand this bewildering, beautiful continent \xe2\x80\x94 and to grasp the complexity that is my home country, Nigeria, Africa\xe2\x80\x99s most populous nation \xe2\x80\x94 I think it is absolutely important that we examine the story of African people.'b'In my mind, there are two parts to the story of the African peoples ... the rain beating us obviously goes back at least half a millennium. And what is happening in Africa today is a result of what has been going on for 400 or 500 years, from the \xe2\x80\x9cdiscovery\xe2\x80\x9d of Africa by Europe, through the period of darkness that engulfed the continent during the trans-Atlantic slave trade and through the Berlin Conference of 1885. That controversial gathering of the leading European powers, which precipitated the \xe2\x80\x9cscramble for Africa,\xe2\x80\x9d we all know took place without African consultation or representation. It created new boundaries in ancient kingdoms, and nation-states resulting in disjointed, inexplicable, tension-prone countries today.'b'During the colonial period, struggles were fought, exhaustingly, on so many fronts \xe2\x80\x94 for equality, for justice, for freedom \xe2\x80\x94 by politicians, intellectuals and common folk alike. At the end of the day, when the liberty was won, we found that we had not sufficiently reckoned with one incredibly important fact: If you take someone who has not really been in charge of himself for 300 years and tell him, \xe2\x80\x9cO.K., you are now free,\xe2\x80\x9d he will not know where to begin.'b'This is how I see the chaos in Africa today and the absence of logic in what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing. Africa\xe2\x80\x99s postcolonial disposition is the result of a people who have lost the habit of ruling themselves, forgotten their traditional way of thinking, embracing and engaging the world without sufficient preparation. We have also had difficulty running the systems foisted upon us at the dawn of independence by our colonial masters. We are like the man in the Igbo proverb who does not know where the rain began to beat him and so cannot say where he dried his body.'b'People don\xe2\x80\x99t like this particular analysis, because it looks as if we want to place the blame on someone else. Let me be clear, because I have inadvertently developed a reputation (some of my friends say one I relish) as a provocateur: because the West has had a long but uneven engagement with Africa, it is imperative that it also play an important role in forging solutions to Africa\xe2\x80\x99s myriad problems. This will require good will and concerted effort on the part of all those who share the weight of Africa\xe2\x80\x99s historical albatross.'b'In Nigeria, in the years before we finally gained independence in 1960, we had no doubt about where we were going: we were going to inherit freedom; that was all that mattered. The possibilities for us were endless, or so it seemed. Nigeria was enveloped by a certain assurance of an unbridled destiny, by an overwhelming excitement about life\xe2\x80\x99s promise, without any knowledge of providence\xe2\x80\x99s intended destination.'b'While the much-vaunted day of independence arrived to much fanfare, it rapidly became a faded memory. The years flew past. By 1966, Nigeria was called a cesspool of corruption and misrule. Public servants helped themselves freely to the nation\xe2\x80\x99s wealth. Elections were blatantly rigged. The national census was outrageously stage-managed to give certain ethnic groups more power; judges and magistrates were manipulated by the politicians in power. The politicians themselves were corrupted by foreign business interests.'b'The political situation deteriorated rapidly and Nigeria was quickly consumed by civil war. The belligerents were an aggrieved people in the southeast of the nation, the Biafrans, who found themselves fleeing pogroms and persecution at the hands of the determined government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, which had been armed to the teeth by some of the major international powers. My fellow Biafrans spent nearly three years fighting for a cause, fighting for freedom. But all that collapsed and Biafra stood defeated.'b'It had been a very bitter experience that led to the hostilities in the first place. And the big powers got involved in prolonging it. You see, we, the little people of the world, are constantly expendable. The big powers can play their games, even if millions perish in the process. And perish they did. In the end, more than a million people (and possibly as many as three million), mainly children, died either in the fighting or from starvation because of the Nigerian government\xe2\x80\x99s economic blockade.'b'After the civil war, we saw a \xe2\x80\x9cunified\xe2\x80\x9d Nigeria saddled with an even more insidious reality. We were plagued by a home-grown enemy: the political ineptitude, mediocrity, indiscipline, ethnic bigotry and corruption of the ruling class. Compounding the situation was the fact that Nigeria was now awash in oil boom petrodollars. The country\xe2\x80\x99s young, affable head of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon, ever so cocksure following his civil war victory, was proclaiming to the entire planet that Nigeria had more money than it knew what to do with. A new era of great decadence and decline was born. It continues to this day.'b'What can Nigeria do to live up the promise of its postcolonial dream? First, we will have to find a way to do away with the present system of political godfatherism. This archaic practice allows a relative handful of wealthy men \xe2\x80\x94 many of them half-baked, poorly educated thugs \xe2\x80\x94 to sponsor their chosen candidates and push them right through to the desired political position, bribing, threatening and, on occasion, murdering any opposition in the process. We will have to make sure that the electoral body overseeing elections is run by widely respected and competent officials, chosen by a nonpartisan group free of governmental influence or interference.'b'And we have to find a way to open up the political process to every Nigerian. Today, we have a system where only those individuals who can pay an exorbitant application fee and finance a political campaign can vie for the presidency. It would not surprise any close observer to discover that in this inane system, the same unsavory characters who have destroyed the country and looted the treasury are the ones able to run for the presidency.'b'But we must also remember that restoring democratic systems alone will not, overnight, make the country a success. Let me borrow from the history of the Igbo ethnic group. The Igbo have long been a very democratic people. They express a strong anti-monarchy sentiment with the common name Ezebuilo, which translates to \xe2\x80\x9ca king is an enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is no doubt that they experienced the highhandedness of kings, so they decided that a king cannot be a trusted friend of the people without checks and balances. And they tried all kinds of arrangements to whittle down the menace of those with the will to power, because such people exist in large numbers in every society. So the Igbo created all kinds of titles which cost very much to acquire. In the end, the aspirant to titles becomes impoverished in the process and ends up with very little. So that individual begins again, and by the time his life is over, he has a lot of prestige, but very little power.'b'This is not a time to bemoan all the challenges ahead. It is a time to work at developing, nurturing and sustaining democracy. But we also must realize that we need patience and cannot expect instant miracles. Building a nation is not something a people do in one regime, in a few years, even. The Chinese had their chance to emerge as the leading nation in the world in the Middle Ages, but were consumed by interethnic political posturing and wars, and had to wait another 500 years for another chance. America did not arrive at its much admired democracy overnight. When President Abraham Lincoln famously defined democracy as \xe2\x80\x9cthe government of the people, by the people, for the people\xe2\x80\x9d he was drawing upon classical thought and at least 100 years of American rigorous intellectual reflection on the matter.'b'Sustaining democracy in Nigeria will require more than just free elections. It will also mean ending a system in which corruption is not just tolerated, but widely encouraged and hugely profitable. It is estimated that about $400 billion has been pilfered from Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s treasury since independence. One needs to stop for a moment to wrap one\xe2\x80\x99s mind around that incredible figure. It is larger than the annual gross domestic products of Norway and Sweden. This theft of national funds is one of the factors essentially making it impossible for Nigeria to succeed. Nigerians alone are not responsible. We all know that the corrupt cabal of Nigerians has friends abroad who not only help it move the billions abroad but also shield the perpetrators from persecution.'b'Many analysts see a direct link between crude oil and the corruption in Nigeria, that creating a system to prevent politicians from having access to petrodollars is needed to reduce large-scale corruption. For most people, the solution is straightforward: if you commit a crime, you should be brought to book. But in a country like Nigeria, where there are no easy fixes, one must examine the issue of accountability, which has to be a strong component of the fight against corruption.'b'Some feel that a strong executive should be the one to hold people accountable. But if the president has all the power and resources of the country in his control, and he is also the one who selects who should be probed or not, clearly we will have an uneven system where those who are favored by the emperor have free rein to loot the treasury.'b'Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s story has not been, entirely, one long, unrelieved history of despair. At the midcentury mark of the state\xe2\x80\x99s existence, Nigerians have begun to ask themselves the hard questions. How does the state of anarchy become reversed? What measures can be taken to prevent corrupt candidates from recycling themselves into positions of leadership? Young Nigerians have often come to me desperately seeking solutions to several conundrums: How do we begin to solve these problems in Nigeria where the structures are present but there is no accountability?'b'ONE initial step is to change the nation\xe2\x80\x99s Official Secrets Act. Incredible as it may seem, it is illegal in Nigeria to publish official government data and statistics \xe2\x80\x94 including accounts spent by or accruing to the government. This, simply, is inconsistent with the spirit and practice of democracy. There is now a freedom of information bill before the National Assembly that would end this unacceptable state of affairs. It should be passed, free from any modifications that would render it ineffectual, and assented to by President Goodluck Jonathan. This can and should be achieved before the presidential election in April.'b'In the end, I foresee that the Nigerian solution will come in stages. First we have to nurture and strengthen our democratic institutions \xe2\x80\x94 and strive for the freest and fairest elections possible. That will place the true candidates of the people in office. Within the fabric of a democracy, a free press can thrive and a strong justice system can flourish. The checks and balances we have spoken about and the laws needed to curb corruption will then naturally find a footing.'b'And there has to be the development of a new patriotic consciousness, not one simply based on the well-worn notions of the \xe2\x80\x9cUnity of Nigeria\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cFaith in Nigeria\xe2\x80\x9d often touted by our corrupt leaders; but one based on an awareness of the responsibility of leaders to the led and disseminated by civil society, schools and intellectuals. It is from this kind of environment that a leader, humbled by the trust placed upon him by the people, will emerge, willing to use the power given to him for the good of the people.'b'Madison, Wis.'b'EVER since NewSouth Books 'b'announced it would publish a version'b' of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Adventures of Huckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d with the \xe2\x80\x9cn-word\xe2\x80\x9d removed, reaction has split between traditionalists outraged at censorship and those who feel this might be a way to get teenagers, especially African-American boys, comfortable reading a literary classic. From a mother\xe2\x80\x99s perspective, I think both sides are mistaken.'b'No parent who is raising a black teenager and trying to get him to read serious fiction for his high school English class would ever argue that \xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d is not a greatly problematic work. But the remedy is not to replace \xe2\x80\x9cnigger\xe2\x80\x9d with alternative terms like \xe2\x80\x9cslave\xe2\x80\x9d (the latter word is already in the novel and has a different meaning from \xe2\x80\x9cnigger,\xe2\x80\x9d so that substitution just mucks up the prose \xe2\x80\x94 its meaning, its voice, its verisimilitude). The remedy is to refuse to teach this novel in high school and to wait until college \xe2\x80\x94 or even graduate school \xe2\x80\x94 where it can be put in proper context.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d is not an appropriate introduction to serious literature, and anyone who cannot see that has never tried putting an audio version of it on during a long car trip while an African-American teenager sits beside her and slowly, slowly slips on his noise-canceling earphones in order to listen to hip-hop.'b'The derogatory word is part of the problem, but not the entirety of it \xe2\x80\x94 hip-hop music uses the same word. Of course, the speakers are different in each case, and the worlds they are speaking of and from are very distant from one another. The listener can tell the difference in a second. The listener knows which voice is speaking to him and which is not getting remotely close.'b'No novel with the word \xe2\x80\x9ckike\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbitch\xe2\x80\x9d spelled out 200 times could or should be separated \xe2\x80\x94  for purposes of irony or pedagogy \xe2\x80\x94 from the attitudes that produced those words. It\xe2\x80\x99s also impossible that such a novel would be taught in a high school classroom. And if it were taught, student alienation might very well contribute to another breed of achievement gap.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHuckleberry Finn\xe2\x80\x9d is suited to a college course in which Twain\xe2\x80\x99s obsession with the 19th-century theater of American hucksterism \xe2\x80\x94 the wastrel West, the rapscallion South, the economic strays and escapees of a harsh new country \xe2\x80\x94 can be discussed in the context of Jim\xe2\x80\x99s particular story (and Huck\xe2\x80\x99s).'b'An African-American 10th grader, in someone\xe2\x80\x99s near-sighted attempt to get him newly appreciative of novels, does not benefit by being taken back right then to a time when a young white boy slowly realizes, sort of, the humanity of a black man, realizes that that black man is more than chattel even if that black man is also full of illogic and stereotypical superstitions.'b'Huck Finn refers to himself as an idiot and still finds Jim more foolish than himself. Although Twain has compassion for the affectionate Jim, he has an interest in burlesque; although he is sensitive to Jim\xe2\x80\x99s heartbreaking losses, he is always looking for comedy and repeatedly holds Jim up as a figure of howling fun, ridicule that is specific to his condition as a black man.'b'The young black American male of today, whose dignity in our public schools is not always preserved or made a priority, does not need at the start of his literary life to be immersed in an even more racist era by reading a celebrated text that exuberantly expresses everything crazy and wicked about that time \xe2\x80\x94 not if one\xe2\x80\x99s goal is to get that teenager to like books. Huck\xe2\x80\x99s voice is a complicated amalgam of idioms and perspectives and is not for the inexperienced contemporary reader.'b'There are other books more appropriate for an introduction to serious reading. (\xe2\x80\x9cTo Kill a Mockingbird,\xe2\x80\x9d with its social-class caricatures and racially na\xc3\xafve narrator, is not one of them.) Sherman Alexie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian,\xe2\x80\x9d which vibrantly speaks to every teenager\xe2\x80\x99s predicament when achievement in life is at odds with the demoralized condition of his peer group, is a welcoming book for boys. There must certainly be others and their titles should be shared. Teachers I meet everywhere are always asking, How can we get boys to read? And the answer is, simply, book by book.'b'One reader\xe2\x80\x99s sensitivity always sets off someone else\xe2\x80\x99s defensiveness. But what would be helpful are school administrators who will break with tradition and bring more flexibility, imagination and social purpose to our high school curriculums. College, where the students have more experience with racial attitudes and literature, can do as it pleases.'b'IN a great many fields, researchers would give their eyeteeth to have a direct glimpse of the past. Instead, they generally have to piece together remote conditions using remnants like weathered fossils, decaying parchments or mummified remains. Cosmology, the study of the origin and evolution of the universe, is different. It is the one arena in which we can actually witness history.'b'The pinpoints of starlight we see with the naked eye are photons that have been streaming toward us for a few years or a few thousand. The light from more distant objects, captured by powerful telescopes, has been traveling toward us far longer than that, sometimes for billions of years. When we look at such ancient light, we are seeing \xe2\x80\x94 literally \xe2\x80\x94 ancient times.'b'During the past decade, as observations of such ancient starlight have provided deep insight into  the universe\xe2\x80\x99s past,  they have also, surprisingly,  provided deep insight into the nature of the future. And the future that the data suggest is particularly disquieting \xe2\x80\x94 because of something called 'b'dark energy'b'.'b'This story of discovery begins a century ago with 'b'Albert Einstein'b', who realized that space is not an immutable stage on which events play out, as 'b'Isaac Newton'b' had envisioned. Instead, through his general theory of relativity, Einstein found that space, and time too, can bend, twist and warp, responding much as a trampoline does to a jumping child. In fact, so malleable is space that, according to the math, the size of the universe necessarily changes over  time: the fabric of space must expand or contract \xe2\x80\x94 it can\xe2\x80\x99t stay put.'b'For Einstein, this was an unacceptable conclusion. He\xe2\x80\x99d spent 10 grueling years developing the general theory of relativity, seeking a better understanding of gravity, but to him the notion of an expanding or contracting cosmos seemed blatantly erroneous. It flew in the face of the prevailing wisdom that, over the largest of scales, the universe was fixed and unchanging.'b'Einstein responded swiftly. He modified the equations of general relativity so that the mathematics 'b'would 'b'yield an unchanging cosmos. A static situation, like a stalemate in a tug of war, requires equal but opposite forces that cancel  each other. Across large distances, the force that shapes the cosmos is the attractive pull of gravity. And so, Einstein reasoned, a counterbalancing force would need to provide a repulsive push. But what force could that be?'b'Remarkably, he found that a simple modification of general relativity\xe2\x80\x99s equations entailed something that would have, well, blown Newton\xe2\x80\x99s mind: antigravity \xe2\x80\x94 a gravitational force that pushes instead of pulls. Ordinary matter, like the 'b'Earth'b' or Sun, can generate only attractive gravity, but the math revealed that a more exotic source \xe2\x80\x94 an energy that uniformly fills space, much as steam fills a sauna, only invisibly \xe2\x80\x94 would generate gravity\xe2\x80\x99s repulsive version. Einstein called this space-filling energy the cosmological constant, and he found that by finely adjusting its value, the repulsive gravity it produced would precisely cancel the usual attractive gravity coming from stars and galaxies, yielding a static cosmos. He breathed a sigh of relief.'b'A dozen years later, however, Einstein rued the day he introduced the cosmological constant. In 1929, the American astronomer Edwin Hubble discovered that distant galaxies are all rushing away from us. And the best explanation for this cosmic exodus came directly from general relativity: much as poppy seeds in a muffin that\xe2\x80\x99s baking move apart as the dough swells, galaxies move apart as the space in which they\xe2\x80\x99re embedded expands. Hubble\xe2\x80\x99s observations thus established that there was no need for a cosmological constant; the universe is not static.'b'Had Einstein only trusted the original mathematics of general relativity, he would have made one of the most spectacular predictions of all time \xe2\x80\x94 that the universe is expanding \xe2\x80\x94 more than a decade before it was discovered. Instead, he was left to lick his wounds, summarily removing the cosmological constant from the equations of general relativity and, according to one of his trusted colleagues, calling it his greatest blunder.'b'But the story of the cosmological constant was far from over.'b'Fast forward to the 1990s, when we find two teams of astronomers undertaking painstakingly precise observations of distant supernovae \xe2\x80\x94 exploding stars so brilliant they can be seen clear across the cosmos \xe2\x80\x94 to determine how the expansion rate of space has changed over the history of the universe. These researchers anticipated that the gravitational attraction of matter dotting the night\xe2\x80\x99s sky would slow the expansion, much as Earth\xe2\x80\x99s gravity slows the speed of a ball tossed upward. By bearing witness to distant supernovae, cosmic beacons that trace the universe\xe2\x80\x99s expansion rate at various moments in the past, the teams sought to make this quantitative. Shockingly, however, when the data were analyzed, the teams found that the expansion rate has not been slowing down. It\xe2\x80\x99s been speeding up.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s as if that tossed ball shot away from your hand, racing upward faster and faster. You\xe2\x80\x99d conclude that something must be driving the ball away. Similarly, the astronomers concluded that something in space must be pushing galaxies apart ever more quickly. And after scrutinizing the situation, they have found that the push is most likely the repulsive gravity produced by a cosmological constant.'b'When Einstein introduced the cosmological constant, he envisioned its value being finely adjusted to exactly balance ordinary attractive gravity. But for other values the cosmological constant\xe2\x80\x99s repulsive gravity can beat out attractive gravity, and yield the observed accelerated spatial expansion, spot on. Were Einstein still with us, his discovery that repulsive gravity lies within nature\xe2\x80\x99s repertoire would have likely garnered him another 'b'Nobel prize'b'.'b'As remarkable as it is that even one of Einstein\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cbad\xe2\x80\x9d ideas has proven prophetic, many puzzles still surround the cosmological constant: If there is a diffuse, invisible energy permeating space, where did it come from? Is this dark energy (to use modern parlance) a permanent fixture of space, or might its strength change over time? Perhaps most perplexing of all is a question of quantitative detail. The most refined attempts to calculate the amount of dark energy suffusing space miss the measured value by a gargantuan factor of 10'b'123'b'  (that is, a 1 followed by 123 zeroes) \xe2\x80\x94 the single greatest mismatch between theory and observation in the history of science.'b'THESE are vital questions that rank among today\xe2\x80\x99s deepest mysteries. But standing beside them is an unassailable conclusion, one that\xe2\x80\x99s particularly unnerving. If the dark energy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t degrade over time, then the accelerated expansion of space will continue unabated, dragging away distant galaxies ever farther and ever faster. A hundred billion years from now, any galaxy that\xe2\x80\x99s not resident in our neighborhood will have been swept away by swelling space for so long that it will be racing from us at faster than the speed of light. (Although nothing can move 'b'through'b' space faster than the speed of light, there\xe2\x80\x99s no limit on how fast space itself can expand.)'b'Light emitted by such galaxies will therefore fight a losing battle to traverse the rapidly widening gulf that separates us. The light will never reach Earth and so the galaxies will slip permanently beyond our capacity to see, regardless of how powerful our telescopes may become.'b'Because of this, when future astronomers look to the sky, they will no longer witness the past. The past will have drifted beyond the cliffs of space. Observations will reveal nothing but an endless stretch of inky black stillness.'b'If astronomers in the far future have records handed down from our era, attesting to an expanding cosmos filled with galaxies, they will face a  peculiar choice: Should they believe \xe2\x80\x9cprimitive\xe2\x80\x9d knowledge that speaks of a cosmos very much at odds with what anyone has seen for billions and billions of years? Or should they focus on their own observations and valiantly seek explanations for an island universe containing a small cluster of galaxies floating within an unchanging sea of darkness \xe2\x80\x94 a conception of the cosmos that we know definitively to be wrong?'b'And what if future astronomers have no such records, perhaps because on their planet scientific acumen developed long after the deep night sky faded to black? For them, the notion of an expanding universe teeming with galaxies would be a wholly theoretical construct, bereft of empirical evidence.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve grown accustomed to the idea that with sufficient hard work and dedication, there\xe2\x80\x99s no barrier to how fully we can both grasp reality and confirm our understanding. But by gazing far into space we\xe2\x80\x99ve captured a handful of starkly informative photons, a cosmic telegram billions of years in transit. And the message, echoing across the ages, is clear. Sometimes nature guards her secrets with the unbreakable grip of physical law. Sometimes the true nature of reality beckons from just beyond the horizon.'b'BEIJING'b'An international study published last month looked at how students in 65 countries performed in math, science and reading. The winner was: Confucianism!'b'At 'b'the very top of the charts'b', in all three fields and by a wide margin, was Shanghai. Three of the next top four performers were also societies with a Confucian legacy of reverence for education: Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea. The only non-Confucian country in the mix was Finland.'b'The United States? We came in 15th in reading, 23rd in science and 31st in math.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve been visiting schools in China and Asia for more than 20 years (and we sent our own kids briefly to schools in Japan, which also bears a Confucian imprint), and I\xe2\x80\x99ve spent much of that time either envious or dumbfounded. I\xe2\x80\x99ll never forget pulling our 2-year-old son out of his Tokyo nursery school so we could visit the States and being handed a form in which we had to list: \xe2\x80\x9creason for proposed vacation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Education thrives in China and the rest of Asia because it is a top priority  \xe2\x80\x94  and we\xe2\x80\x99ve plenty to learn from that.'b'Granted, 'b'Shanghai\xe2\x80\x99s rise to the top of the global charts'b' is not representative of all China, for Shanghai has the country\xe2\x80\x99s best schools. Yet it\xe2\x80\x99s also true that China has made remarkable improvements in the once-awful schools in peasant areas.'b'Just 20 years ago, children often dropped out of elementary school in rural areas. Teachers sometimes could barely speak standard Mandarin,  which, in theory, is the language of instruction.'b'These days, even in backward rural areas, most girls and boys alike attend high school. College isn\xe2\x80\x99t unusual. And the teachers are vastly improved. In my Chinese-American wife\xe2\x80\x99s ancestral village  \xe2\x80\x94  a poor community in southern China  \xe2\x80\x94  the peasant children are a grade ahead in math compared with my children at an excellent public school in the New York area. That seems broadly true of math around the country.'b'For a socialist system that hesitates to fire people, China has also been surprisingly adept  \xe2\x80\x94  more so than America  \xe2\x80\x94  at dealing with ineffective teachers. Chinese principals can\xe2\x80\x99t easily dismiss teachers, but they can get extra training for less effective teachers, or if that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work, push them into other jobs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBad teachers can always be made gym teachers,\xe2\x80\x9d a principal in the city of Xian explained to me as she showed me around her kindergarten. In China, school sports and gym just don\xe2\x80\x99t matter.'b'(That kindergarten exemplified another of China\xe2\x80\x99s strengths: excellent early childhood education, typically beginning at age 2. Indeed, the only element of China\xe2\x80\x99s education system that really falters badly is the university system. Colleges are third-rate and should be a national disgrace.)'b'But this is the paradox: Chinese themselves are far less impressed by their school system. Almost every time I try to interview a Chinese about the system here, I hear grousing rather than praise. Many Chinese complain scathingly that their system kills independent thought and creativity, and they envy the American system for nurturing self-reliance  \xe2\x80\x94  and for trying to make learning exciting and not just a chore.'b'In Xian, I visited Gaoxin Yizhong, perhaps the city\xe2\x80\x99s best high school,  and the students and teachers spoke wistfully of the American emphasis on clubs, arts and independent thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWe need to encourage more creativity,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Hua Guohong, a chemistry teacher. \xe2\x80\x9cWe should learn from American schools.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One friend in Guangdong Province says he will send his children to the United States to study because the local schools are a \xe2\x80\x9ccreativity-killer.\xe2\x80\x9d Another sent his son to an international school to escape what he likens to \xe2\x80\x9cprograms for trained seals.\xe2\x80\x9d Private schools are sprouting everywhere, and many boast of a focus on creativity.'b'For my part, I think the self-criticisms are exactly right, but I also deeply admire the passion for education and the commitment to making the system better. And while William Butler Yeats was right that \xe2\x80\x9ceducation is not filling a bucket but lighting a fire,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s also true that it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to ignite a bonfire if there\xe2\x80\x99s fuel in the bucket.'b'The larger issue is that the greatest strength of the Chinese system is the Confucian reverence for education that is steeped into the culture. In Chinese schools, teachers are much respected, and the most admired kid is often the brain rather than the jock or class clown.'b'Americans think of China\xe2\x80\x99s strategic challenge in terms of, say, the new Chinese stealth fighter aircraft. But the real challenge is the rise of China\xe2\x80\x99s education system and the passion for learning that underlies it. We\xe2\x80\x99re not going to become Confucians, but we can elevate education on our list of priorities without relinquishing creativity and independent thought.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s what we did in 1957 after the Soviet Union launched Sputnik. These latest test results should be our 21st-century Sputnik.'b'Get ready for more theater on Capitol Hill. House Republicans plan to push through legislation this week to repeal the health care reform law.'b'In deference to the new vows of civility, the tone of the debate may be a bit more restrained. But Republicans have already said that they will not strip the word \xe2\x80\x9ckilling\xe2\x80\x9d from the bill \xe2\x80\x94 which is titled, \xe2\x80\x9cRepealing the Job-Killing Health Care Law Act.\xe2\x80\x9d  Civility apparently goes only so far.'b'While repeal will certainly pass the House, it has no chance in the Senate. So House Republicans are already planning other ways to undermine the reforms, like denying agencies enough money to hire personnel to carry out the program.'b'Americans will pay a high price if opponents get their way. Reform means that tens of millions of uninsured people will get a chance at security; and many millions more who have coverage can be sure they can keep or replace it, even if they get sick or lose their jobs.'b'Repeal would also take away the best chance for reining in rising health care costs \xe2\x80\x94 and the government\xe2\x80\x99s relentlessly rising Medicare burden.'b'The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated that repealing the reform law would drive up the deficit by $230 billion over the first decade and much more in later years.'b'For all his claims of fiscal rectitude, John Boehner, the House speaker, immediately dismissed the budget experts\xe2\x80\x99 report as \xe2\x80\x9ctheir opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d In a particularly cynical move, Mr. Boehner and his new team have exempted the repeal bill from their own rule that any increase in spending be offset by cuts in other programs.'b'Many individuals and businesses are already benefiting from reform, and they will benefit even more once it goes into full effect in 2014.'b'Thanks to reform, it is now illegal for insurance companies to deny children coverage because they have pre-existing medical conditions, or to rescind a policy after a person becomes sick, or to cap the amount that insurers will pay for medical care over a lifetime. After 2014, it will be illegal for insurers to set annual limits on the amount they will pay for medical care or deny coverage to adults with pre-existing conditions.'b'Young people are now allowed to remain on their parents\xe2\x80\x99 policies until age 26. And insurers are now required to cover preventive care in new policies without cost-sharing, and to spend at least 80 percent of their premium income on medical care and quality improvements, not profits or administrative costs. Repeal would eliminate all of these new protections.'b'Repeal would also eliminate federal tax credits that are helping small businesses provide coverage to employees as well as a reinsurance program that is helping more than 4,700 employers, large and small, provide health coverage to early retirees.'b'Republicans are getting considerable traction with their claims that the reform law will drive up the price of insurance, and some are blaming the law for recent premium increases primarily caused by medical inflation. Once again, the official analysts and other experts disagree.'b'In fact, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that repeal would cause premiums for coverage obtained through large employers to rise by a bit in future years, while premiums at small employers, on average, would be little affected. Projected premiums for people who buy their own policies would come down somewhat with repeal, mostly because the policies would provide skimpier coverage than required under reform. Many people in this group would end up paying more out of their own pockets for health insurance, because they would not get the subsidies provided under the reform law.'b'Until now, the Republicans have dominated this debate with scare tactics and posturing. Democratic political leaders say they are finally ready to mount a vigorous campaign arguing the case for reform. They should be prepared for a long fight.'b'In December, the Obama administration signaled a welcome new resolve to block the torrent of illegal guns moving into Mexico and the hands of the drug cartels.'b'The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives announced it was seeking emergency authority to require 8,000 gun dealers near the border to report multiple purchases by any individual of high-firepower semiautomatic rifles that use a detachable magazine.'b'The bureau  asked the Office of Management and Budget, which must sign off on the plan, to do so by Jan. 5. That date has come and gone without a decision.'b'The death toll in Mexico\xe2\x80\x99s drug wars is staggering \xe2\x80\x94 more than 30,000 people killed as of last year. The role of American-purchased guns in that carnage is also undeniable. In the past four years, more than 60,000 guns connected to crimes in Mexico have been tracked back to American gun dealers. About three-quarters of those weapons originated from gun shops in Texas, Arizona, New Mexico and California, the four states covered by the A.T.F. plan.'b'Administration officials insist that approval will be coming soon, and we hope that is the case. But the delay is worrying. (Before the A.T.F. spoke up, the idea had languished at the Justice Department for months.)'b'The gun lobby and some vocal allies on Capitol Hill have denounced the proposal, claiming that this reasonable effort to track down gun traffickers threatens Americans\xe2\x80\x99 gun rights and exceeds the A.T.F.\xe2\x80\x99s mandate. The bureau\xe2\x80\x99s authority to demand information from a limited group of dealers shown to present elevated risks of crime has been upheld by courts in other cases.'b'The budget office needs to approve the A.T.F. initiative. And the White House needs to press Congress to provide the bureau with funding for more inspectors, as well as more authority to identify and shut down see-no-evil gun dealers. Not just at the border, but everywhere.'b''b'JIM ROBERTS'b', the assistant managing editor who has helped create today\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'NYTimes.com'b', likes to call it the 1440/7 news cycle \xe2\x80\x94 1,440 minutes every day, seven days a week, each one of those minutes demanding news for delivery to a networked world.'b'Unfortunately, during a few of those minutes on Jan. 8, The Times had the story wrong. In that brief window of time, NYTimes.com was reporting that Representative Gabrielle Giffords was dead of gunshot wounds. The error and some other aspects of the coverage of the Tucson shootings illustrate how difficult it is in the current environment to be both timely and authoritative.'b'The circumstances were these: A major breaking news event, occurring on a Saturday afternoon with a small staff on duty, with print deadlines to worry about and a Web site that needed to be fed as fast and as frequently as possible.'b'The Times\xe2\x80\x99s first online posting came at 1:47 p.m., followed by two quick updates \xe2\x80\x94 at 1:53 and 2:16. These stories, pieced together from other news organizations that were on the ground in Tucson, reported the shootings and other basic facts, attributing word of the shooting to the congresswoman\xe2\x80\x99s spokesman, C. J. Karamargin. At this point, her condition was described as \xe2\x80\x9cunclear.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'At 2:27, though, the story was revised to say Ms. Giffords had been shot and killed, attributing the information to Mr. Karamargin and \xe2\x80\x9cnews reports.\xe2\x80\x9d Lower in the story, those news reports were identified as coming from NPR and CNN. As it turned out, the information was incorrect. The Times compounded the error by appearing to attribute it in part to Ms. Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s own spokesman, who was not the source of the error.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s how the error was made. It was hectic in the newsroom with many news reports flowing in as Kathleen McElroy, the day Web news editor, was trying to decide whether The Times was ready to report Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s death. She decided against it and was telling Web producers to hold off reporting it in a news alert when J. David Goodman, who was writing the story, told her he had a few changes he wanted to make.'b'Ms. McElroy said, \xe2\x80\x9cI should have looked at every change,\xe2\x80\x9d but she thought Mr. Goodman was referring to small stuff. Mr. Goodman told me he then erred by reporting Representative Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s death in the lead as though The Times itself were standing behind the information. In any event, Ms. McElroy had said O.K. without seeing that change, so Mr. Goodman pushed the button.'b'The result was a news story with changes that were not edited. Less than 10 minutes later, a new story appeared with the words \xe2\x80\x9cand killed\xe2\x80\x9d stricken.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNobody should self-publish,\xe2\x80\x9d said 'b'Philip B. Corbett'b', standards editor for The Times. \xe2\x80\x9cEverything should go through an editor. Ideally, it should go through two editors.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I agree with him, but that takes time. In the 1440/7 news cycle, and in the environment of the newsroom on Jan. 8, time seemed unavailable. On this particular day, things were happening quickly and simultaneously, and a mistake was made.'b''b'The Tucson shootings'b' afforded another, quite different illustration of the pressure of time in news coverage \xe2\x80\x94 not pressure measured in seconds and minutes, but pressure that news organizations feel to define the context of a story, to set up a frame for it, sometimes before the facts can be fully understood.'b'The Times\xe2\x80\x99s day-one coverage in some of its Sunday print editions included a strong focus on the political climate in Arizona and the nation. For some readers \xe2\x80\x94 and I share this view to an extent \xe2\x80\x94 placing the violence in the broader political context was problematic.'b'C. Wenk, a reader in Alexandria, Va., criticized \xe2\x80\x9can egregious rush to judgment in the Times coverage of the Arizona shooting, specifically aimed at linking the shooting to various conservative or Republican political rhetoric.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A second reader, Kevin O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell of Greenbrae, Calif., saw it as a case of The Times jumping too quickly: \xe2\x80\x9cI understand the larger point about coarse speech raising the potential for violence. By offering that debate within hours of events, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t The Times risk starting at the conclusion end of the argument?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Times had a lot of company, as news organizations, commentators and political figures shouldered into an unruly scrum battling over whether the political environment was to blame. Meanwhile, opportunities were missed to pick up on evidence \xe2\x80\x94 quite apparent as early as that first day \xe2\x80\x94 that 'b'Jared Lee Loughner'b', who is charged with the shootings, had a mental disorder and might not have been motivated by politics at all.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were a reporter on this story, my very first call would have been to a mental health professional willing to consider the nature of Mr. Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s illness,\xe2\x80\x9d Max Etchemendy of East Palo Alto, Calif., wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98political\xe2\x80\x99 angle has been beaten to death, and \xe2\x80\x98medical\xe2\x80\x99 angle has been ignored completely.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So why does a story get framed this way? Journalism educators characterize this kind of framing as a storytelling habit \xe2\x80\x94 one of relating new facts to an existing storyline \xe2\x80\x94 and also as a reflex of news organizations that are built to handle some topics well, and others less well.'b''b'Jerry Ceppos'b', dean of 'b'the journalism school'b' at the University of Nevada, Reno, said journalists\xe2\x80\x99 impulse to quickly impose a frame on a story is \xe2\x80\x9cgenetic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJournalists developed automatic framing protocols generations ago because of the need to report quickly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cToday\xe2\x80\x99s hyper-deadlines, requiring journalists to report all day long and all night long, made that genetic disposition even more dominant.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To be fair, there were some good reasons to steer the coverage initially in this direction. As 'b'Rick Berke'b', the national editor, said: \xe2\x80\x9cOur coverage early on was broad and touched everything from the possible shooter to the victims to the reaction to, yes, the political climate in Arizona. By our count, there were 49 stories in the paper the first six days after the tragedy, of which only 14 were political in nature. But it would be ridiculous for us to neglect that. After all, a politician was shot in the head while meeting with constituents. That same lawmaker had her office vandalized during an especially rancorous campaign. And after the shooting the sheriff called his state the capital of hatred and bigotry.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Still, I think the intense focus on political conflict \xe2\x80\x94 not just by The Times \xe2\x80\x94 detracted from what has emerged as the salient story line, that of a mentally ill individual with lawful access to a gun.'b'Whether covering the basic facts of a breaking story or identifying more complex themes, the takeaway is that time is often the enemy. Sometimes the best weapon against it is to ignore it, and use a moment to consider the alternatives.'b'OF the many truths in President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'powerful Tucson speech'b', none was more indisputable than his statement that no one can know what is in a killer\xe2\x80\x99s mind. So why have we spent so much time debating exactly that?'b'The answer is classic American denial. It was easier to endlessly parse Jared Lee Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s lunatic library  \xe2\x80\x94  did he favor \xe2\x80\x9cThe Communist Manifesto\xe2\x80\x9d or Ayn Rand?  \xe2\x80\x94  than confront the larger and harsher snapshot of our current landscape that emerged after his massacre. A week on, that denial is becoming even more entrenched. As soon as the president left the podium Wednesday night, we started shifting into our familiar spin-dry post-tragedy cycle of the modern era  \xe2\x80\x94  speedy \xe2\x80\x9cclosure,\xe2\x80\x9d followed by a return to business as usual, followed by national amnesia.'b'If we learn nothing from this tragedy, we are back where we started. And where we started was with two years of accelerating political violence  \xe2\x80\x94  actual violence, not to be confused with violent language  \xe2\x80\x94  that struck fear into many, not the least of whom was Gabrielle Giffords.'b'For the sake of this discussion, let\xe2\x80\x99s stipulate that Loughner was a \xe2\x80\x9clone nutjob\xe2\x80\x9d who had never listened to Glenn Beck or been a card-carrying member of either the Tea or Communist parties. Let\xe2\x80\x99s also face another tragedy: The only two civic reforms that might have actually stopped him  \xe2\x80\x94  tighter gun control and an effective mental health safety net  \xe2\x80\x94  won\xe2\x80\x99t materialize even now.'b'Gun and ammunition sales 'b'spiked last week'b', especially for the specific  varieties given the Loughner imprimatur. No editorial  \xe2\x80\x94  or bloodbath  \xe2\x80\x94  will move Congress 'b'to enact serious gun control'b' (which Giffords herself 'b'never advocated'b' and Obama has rarely pushed since 2008). In Arizona, cutbacks are already so severe that terminally ill patients are 'b'being denied life-saving organ transplants'b'.'b'The other inescapable reality was articulated by Sarah Palin, believe it or not, 'b'in her \xe2\x80\x9cblood libel\xe2\x80\x9d video'b'. Speaking of acrimonious partisan debate, she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen was it less heated  \xe2\x80\x94  back in those calm days when political figures literally settled their differences with dueling pistols?\xe2\x80\x9d She\xe2\x80\x99s right. Calls for civility will have no more lasting impact on the \xe2\x80\x9ctone\xe2\x80\x9d of American discourse now than they did after the J.F.K. assassination or Oklahoma City. Especially not in an era when technology allows all 300 million Americans a cost-free megaphone for unmediated rants.'b'Did Loughner see Palin\xe2\x80\x99s own most notorious contribution to the rancorous tone  \xe2\x80\x94  'b'her March 2010 Web graphic'b' targeting Congressional districts? Her reaction to it  \xe2\x80\x94  captured in 'b'an interview she did back then with Chuck Todd of MSNBC'b'  \xe2\x80\x94  was the most recycled, if least understood, video of last week.'b'The  week of that interview began  with 'b'the House passing the health care bill'b' on Sunday. But Todd moved on, and so did the Beltway. What\xe2\x80\x99s the big deal about a little broken glass? Few wanted to see what Giffords saw \xe2\x80\x94 that the vandalism and death threats were  the latest consequences of a tide of ugly insurrectionism that had been rising since the final weeks of the 2008 campaign and that had threatened to turn violent from the start.'b'Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s first brush with that reality had occurred some seven months before her office was vandalized  \xe2\x80\x94  in the red-hot health care fever of August 2009. 'b'A Palin aide claimed'b' that her target map was only invoking a \xe2\x80\x9csurveyor\xe2\x80\x99s symbol,\xe2\x80\x9d not gun sights. On \xe2\x80\x9cMeet the Press\xe2\x80\x9d last Sunday 'b'he implored us'b' to \xe2\x80\x9ctreat each other as fellow children of God\xe2\x80\x9d without acknowledging (or being questioned about) 'b'his 2009 diatribe'b' branding Obama as \xe2\x80\x9can enemy of humanity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the president said in Tucson, we lack not just civil discourse, but honest discourse. Much of last week\xe2\x80\x99s televised bloviation was dishonest, dedicated to the pious, feel-good sentiment that both sides are equally culpable for the rage of the past two years. To construct this false equivalency, every left-leaning Web site and Democratic politician\xe2\x80\x99s record was dutifully culled for incendiary invective. If that\xe2\x80\x99s the standard, then both sides are equally at fault  \xe2\x80\x94  rhetoric can indeed be as violent on the left as on the right.'b'But that sidesteps the issue. This isn\xe2\x80\x99t about angry blog posts or verbal fisticuffs. Since Obama\xe2\x80\x99s ascension, we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen  'b'repeated incidents of political violence'b'. Just a short list would include 'b'the 2009 killing of three Pittsburgh police officers'b' by a neo-Nazi Obama-hater; last year\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'murder-suicide kamikaze attack'b' on an I.R.S. office in Austin, Tex.; and t'b'he California police shootout'b' with an assailant plotting to attack  'b'an obscure liberal foundation obsessively vilified by Beck'b'.'b'Obama said, correctly, on Wednesday that 'b'\xe2\x80\x9ca simple lack of civility\xe2\x80\x9d'b' didn\xe2\x80\x99t cause the Tucson tragedy. What did inform the earlier violence  \xe2\x80\x94  including the vandalism at Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s office  \xe2\x80\x94  was 'b'an antigovernment radicalism as rabid on the right now'b' as it was on the left in the late 1960s. That\xe2\x80\x99s why so many  \xe2\x80\x94 on both the finger-pointing left and the hyper-defensive right  \xe2\x80\x94  automatically assumed he must be another of them.'b'Have politicians stoked the pre-Loughner violence by advocating that citizens pursue 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSecond Amendment remedies\xe2\x80\x9d'b' or be 'b'\xe2\x80\x9carmed and dangerous\xe2\x80\x9d'b'? Unless and until they can match her courage and speak out too, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see what will change.'b'The house is laden with icicles. Looking out my office window, I feel as though I\xe2\x80\x99m living in the maw of some fabulous fanged beast readying to devour the rest of the day.'b'This is the day that is unimaginable in July \xe2\x80\x94 14 degrees and more than two feet of snow on the ground, a female cardinal resting among the magnolia buds, her feet tucked into her under-down. The horses think nothing of the weather, though I have trouble persuading myself of that. Yesterday, they ran bucking and kicking into a level patch of sunshine, and when Remedy lay down for a rest \xe2\x80\x94 flat-out \xe2\x80\x94 he almost disappeared beneath the snow-line. Ida curls up in the snow as cat-like as a horse can be. Nell looks like a four-legged Yeti.'b'I wade knee-deep to the chicken house. I shovel. I plow. I defy the elements, and they defy me, and when we\xe2\x80\x99re done, I crawl inside a sleeping bag to get the heat back in my body.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m in no rush for things to change. It\xe2\x80\x99s also the glacial blue when light pierces the snow in the tractor-bucket raised against the sky, the berg-ish way the snow breaks off as I shovel, the avalanche that falls when I rake the roof.'b'I like the endurance this weather demands. Alvarez'b'\nNew York, Jan. 4, 2011'b''b''b'The writer teaches labor relations in the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell, Extension Division.'b''b'San Francisco'b'TODAY, millions of people on another continent are observing the 50th anniversary of an event few Americans remember, the assassination of Patrice Lumumba. A slight, goateed man with black, half-framed glasses, the 35-year-old Lumumba was the first democratically chosen leader of the vast country, nearly as large as the United States east of the Mississippi, now known as the Democratic Republic of Congo.'b'This treasure house of natural resources had been a colony of Belgium, which for decades had made no plans for independence. But after clashes with Congolese nationalists, the Belgians hastily arranged the first national election in 1960, and in June of that year King Baudouin arrived to formally give the territory its freedom.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is now up to you, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he arrogantly told Congolese dignitaries, \xe2\x80\x9cto show that you are worthy of our confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Belgians, and their European and American fellow investors, expected to continue collecting profits from Congo\xe2\x80\x99s factories, plantations and lucrative mines, which produced diamonds, gold, uranium, copper and more. But they had not planned on Lumumba.'b'A dramatic, angry speech he gave in reply to Baudouin 'b'brought Congolese legislators to their feet cheering,'b' left the king startled and frowning and caught the world\xe2\x80\x99s attention. Lumumba spoke forcefully of the violence and humiliations of colonialism, from the ruthless theft of African land to the way that French-speaking colonists talked to Africans as adults do to children, using the familiar \xe2\x80\x9ctu\xe2\x80\x9d instead of the formal \xe2\x80\x9cvous.\xe2\x80\x9d Political independence was not enough, he said; Africans had to also benefit from the great wealth in their soil.'b'With no experience of self-rule and an empty treasury, his huge country was soon in turmoil. After failing to get aid from the United States, Lumumba declared he would turn to the Soviet Union. Thousands of Belgian officials who lingered on did their best to sabotage things: their code word for Lumumba in military radio transmissions was \xe2\x80\x9cSatan.\xe2\x80\x9d  Shortly after he took office as prime minister, the C.I.A., with White House approval, ordered his assassination and dispatched an undercover agent with poison.'b'The would-be poisoners could not get close enough to Lumumba to do the job, so instead the United States and Belgium covertly funneled cash and aid to rival politicians who seized power and arrested the prime minister. Fearful of revolt by Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s supporters if he died in their hands, the new Congolese leaders ordered him flown to the copper-rich Katanga region in the country\xe2\x80\x99s south, whose secession Belgium had just helped orchestrate. There, on Jan. 17, 1961, after being beaten and tortured, he was shot. It was a chilling moment that set off street demonstrations in many countries.'b'As a college student traveling through Africa on summer break, I was in L\xc3\xa9opoldville (today\xe2\x80\x99s Kinshasa), Congo\xe2\x80\x99s capital, for a few days some six months after Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s murder. There was an air of tension and gloom in the city, jeeps full of soldiers were on patrol, and the streets quickly emptied at night. Above all, I remember the triumphant, macho satisfaction with which two young American Embassy officials \xe2\x80\x94 much later identified as C.I.A. men \xe2\x80\x94 talked with me over drinks about the death of someone they regarded not as an elected leader but as an upstart enemy of the United States.'b'Some weeks before his death, Lumumba had briefly escaped from house arrest and, with a small group of supporters,  tried to flee to the eastern Congo, where a counter-government of his sympathizers had formed. The travelers had to traverse the Sankuru River, after which friendly territory began. Lumumba and several companions crossed the river in a dugout canoe to commandeer a ferry to go back and fetch the rest of the group, including his wife and son.'b'But by the time they returned to the other bank, government troops pursuing them had arrived. According to one survivor, Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s famous eloquence almost persuaded the soldiers to let them go. Events like this are often burnished in retrospect, but however the encounter happened, Lumumba seems to have risked his life to try to rescue the others, and the episode has found its way into film and fiction.'b'His legend has only become deeper because there is painful newsreel footage of him in captivity, soon after this moment, bound tightly with rope and trying to retain his dignity while being roughed up by his guards.'b'Patrice Lumumba had only a few short months in office and we have no way of knowing what would have happened had he lived. Would he have stuck to his ideals or, like too many African independence leaders, abandoned them for the temptations of wealth and power? In any event, leading his nation to the full economic autonomy  he dreamed of would have been an almost impossible task. The Western governments and corporations arrayed against him were too powerful, and the resources in his control too weak: at independence his new country had fewer than three dozen university graduates among a black population of more than 15 million, and only three of some 5,000 senior positions in the civil service were filled by Congolese.'b'A half-century later, we should surely  look back on the death of Lumumba  with shame, for we helped install the men who deposed and killed him. In the scholarly journal Intelligence and National Security, Stephen R. Weissman, a former staff director of the House Subcommittee on Africa, 'b'recently pointed out'b' that Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s violent end foreshadowed today\xe2\x80\x99s American practice of \xe2\x80\x9cextraordinary rendition.\xe2\x80\x9d The Congolese politicians who planned Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s murder checked all their major moves with their Belgian and American backers, and the local C.I.A. station chief made no objection when they told him they were going to turn Lumumba over \xe2\x80\x94 render him, in today\xe2\x80\x99s parlance \xe2\x80\x94 to the breakaway government of Katanga, which, everyone knew, could be counted on to kill him.'b'Still more fateful was what was to come. Four years later, one of Lumumba\xe2\x80\x99s captors, an army officer named Joseph Mobutu, again with enthusiastic American support, staged a coup and began a disastrous, 32-year dictatorship. Just as geopolitics and a thirst for oil have today brought us unsavory allies like Saudi Arabia, so the cold war and a similar lust for natural resources did then. Mobutu was showered with more than $1 billion in American aid  and enthusiastically welcomed to the White House by a succession of presidents; George H. W. Bush called him \xe2\x80\x9cone of our most valued friends.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This valued friend bled his country dry, amassed a fortune estimated at $4 billion, jetted the world by rented Concorde and bought himself an array of grand villas in Europe and multiple palaces and a yacht at home. He let public services shrivel to nothing and roads and railways be swallowed by the rain forest. By 1997, when he was overthrown and died, his country was in a state of wreckage from which it has not yet recovered.'b'Since that time the fatal combination of enormous natural riches and the dysfunctional government Mobutu left has ignited a long, multisided war that has killed huge numbers of Congolese or forced them from their homes. Many factors cause a war, of course, especially one as bewilderingly complex as this one. But when visiting eastern Congo some months ago, I could not help but think that one thread leading to the human suffering I saw begins with the assassination of Lumumba.'b'We will never know the full death toll of the current conflict, but many believe it to be in the millions. Some of that blood is on our hands. Both ordering the murders of apparent enemies and then embracing their enemies as \xe2\x80\x9cvalued friends\xe2\x80\x9d come with profound, long-term consequences \xe2\x80\x94 a lesson worth pondering on this anniversary.'b'To the Editor:'b'Trevor Packer of the College Board sees no immediate need to revise the Advanced Placement mathematics programs (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Rethinking A.P.'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Education Life, Jan. 9). As someone who deals daily with the effects of those programs, I disagree.'b'More and more of my students who have scored well on calculus A.P. exams have not seen, much less contemplated, the precise mathematical definition of a limit upon which calculus stands, for just one example. The \xe2\x80\x9crushing through important topics\xe2\x80\x9d mentioned at the beginning of the article is very much a part of the calculus program.'b'More problematic, however, is the rushing through high school mathematics to get to A.P. calculus, while simultaneously accumulating A.P. courses in other areas. Students hoping to attend colleges like Middlebury are told by guidance counselors and, yes, our own admissions officers to take the most challenging courses at their schools. Consequently, their high school years are geared toward getting through the College Board\xe2\x80\x99s version of college-level material in three or four or sometimes six areas.'b'At the end of all this, a number of bright, hard-working students have shockingly weak algebra skills. At some point along the way the A.P. program has shifted from a way to meet the needs of a few students who are ready for a challenge to a de facto admissions requirement for many who may not be.'b'Having used their A.P. credits to get into Middlebury, a number of our students try to take calculus again, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI know I got a 5 on the exam, but I didn\xe2\x80\x99t really understand it.\xe2\x80\x9d I know this genie is out of the bottle, but I would rather teach calculus to a student with solid algebra skills and no A.P. experience than to one who took calculus too soon.'b'Priscilla Bremser'b'\nMiddlebury, Vt., Jan. 11, 2011'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of mathematics at Middlebury College.'b''b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Good Place to Start Cutting'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 7):'b'New York\xe2\x80\x99s broken juvenile justice system fails youth, does nothing to improve public safety and is draining state and local budgets. We support the proposals to close underused placement facilities and end the 12-month notification rule, and we urge the governor and the State Legislature to reinvest the savings into cost-effective alternatives to detention and incarceration.'b'These programmatic alternatives cost a fraction of incarceration, serve children close to their homes and communities, and produce good outcomes.'b'Furthermore, it is essential that the state protect investments in proven programs that place and keep children on the right path \xe2\x80\x94 home visiting, early education, and afterschool and summer youth employment programs.'b'The time is now, not only to fix a broken juvenile justice system, but also to do everything in our power to prevent children\xe2\x80\x99s entrance into this system in the first place. Bashner'b'\nNew York, Jan. 7, 2011'b''b''b'The writer, a lawyer, is chairman of community development for Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s Community Board 6.'b''b'My wife and I were thinking of going out for an inexpensive dinner tonight. But John Boehner, the speaker of the House, says that no matter how cheap the meal may seem, it will cost thousands of dollars once you take our monthly mortgage payments into account.'b'Wait a minute, you may say. How can our mortgage payments be a cost of going out to eat, when we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to make the same payments even if we stay home? But Mr. Boehner is adamant: our mortgage is part of the cost of our meal, and to say otherwise is just a budget gimmick.'b'O.K., the speaker hasn\xe2\x80\x99t actually weighed in on our plans for the evening. But he and his G.O.P. colleagues have lately been making exactly the nonsensical argument I\xe2\x80\x99ve just described \xe2\x80\x94 not about tonight\xe2\x80\x99s dinner, but about health care reform. And the nonsense wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a slip of the tongue; it\xe2\x80\x99s the official party position, laid out in charts and figures.'b'We are, I believe, witnessing something new in American politics. Last year, looking at claims that we can cut taxes, avoid cuts to any popular program and still balance the budget, I observed that Republicans seemed to have lost interest in the war on terror and shifted focus to the war on arithmetic. But now the G.O.P. has moved on to an even bigger project: the war on logic.'b'So, about that nonsense: this week the House is expected to pass H.R. 2, the 'b'Repealing the Job-Killing Health Care Law Act'b'   \xe2\x80\x94 its actual name.  But Republicans have a small problem: they claim to care about budget deficits, yet the Congressional Budget Office says that repealing last year\xe2\x80\x99s health reform would increase the deficit. So what, other than dismissing the nonpartisan budget office\xe2\x80\x99s verdict as \xe2\x80\x9ctheir opinion\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94  as Mr. Boehner has  \xe2\x80\x94  can the G.O.P. do?'b'The answer is contained in an 'b'analysis'b'  \xe2\x80\x94 or maybe that should be \xe2\x80\x9canalysis\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94 released by the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s office, which purports to show that health care reform actually increases the deficit. Why? That\xe2\x80\x99s where the war on logic comes in.'b'First of all, says the analysis, the true cost of reform includes the cost of the \xe2\x80\x9cdoc fix.\xe2\x80\x9d What\xe2\x80\x99s that?'b'Well, in 1997 Congress enacted a formula to determine Medicare payments to physicians. The formula was, however, flawed; it would lead to payments so low that doctors would stop accepting Medicare patients. Instead of changing the formula, however, Congress has consistently enacted one-year fixes. And Republicans claim that the estimated cost of future fixes, $208 billion over the next 10 years, should be considered a cost of health care reform.'b'But the same spending would still be necessary if we were to undo reform. So the G.O.P. argument here is exactly like claiming that my mortgage payments, which I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to make no matter what we do tonight, are a cost of going out for dinner.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s more like that: the G.O.P. also claims that $115 billion of other health care spending should be charged to health reform, even though the budget office has tried to explain that most of this spending would have taken place even without reform.'b'To be sure, the Republican analysis doesn\xe2\x80\x99t rely entirely on spurious attributions of cost  \xe2\x80\x94 it also relies on using three-card monte tricks to make money disappear. Health reform, says the budget office, will increase Social Security revenues and reduce Medicare costs. But the G.O.P. analysis says that these sums don\xe2\x80\x99t count, because some people have said that these savings would also extend the life of these programs\xe2\x80\x99 trust funds, so counting these savings as deficit reduction would be \xe2\x80\x9cdouble-counting,\xe2\x80\x9d because  \xe2\x80\x94  well, actually it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make any sense, but it sounds impressive.'b'So, is the Republican leadership unable to see through childish logical fallacies? No.'b'The key to understanding the G.O.P. analysis of health reform is that the party\xe2\x80\x99s leaders are not, in fact, opposed to reform because they believe it will increase the deficit. Nor are they opposed because they seriously believe that it will be \xe2\x80\x9cjob-killing\xe2\x80\x9d (which it won\xe2\x80\x99t be). They\xe2\x80\x99re against reform because it would cover the uninsured  \xe2\x80\x94 and that\xe2\x80\x99s something they just don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s not about the money. As I tried to explain in my last column, the modern G.O.P. has been taken over by an ideology in which the suffering of the unfortunate isn\xe2\x80\x99t a proper concern of government, and alleviating that suffering at taxpayer expense is immoral, never mind how little it costs.'b'Given that their minds were made up from the beginning, top Republicans weren\xe2\x80\x99t interested in and didn\xe2\x80\x99t need any real policy analysis  \xe2\x80\x94  in fact, they\xe2\x80\x99re basically contemptuous of such analysis, something that shines through in their health care report. All they ever needed or wanted were some numbers and charts to wave at the press, fooling some people into believing that we\xe2\x80\x99re having some kind of rational discussion. We aren\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'In every twisted, wretched, ruinous relationship, there are moments so grim, flare-ups so appalling, that they offer both parties a chance to step back, take inventory, and realize that it\xe2\x80\x99s time  \xe2\x80\x94  far past time, in fact  \xe2\x80\x94  to go their separate ways.'b'For the American media and Sarah Palin, that kind of a  moment arrived last week.'b'It began just hours after the tragedy in Tucson, with a tweet from Markos \xe2\x80\x9cDaily Kos\xe2\x80\x9d Moulitsas, the \xc3\xa9minence grise of the liberal blogosphere. \xe2\x80\x9cMission Accomplished, Sarah Palin,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, linking to a map that Palin\xe2\x80\x99s PAC had put up last fall, placing targets on various Democratic districts, Gabrielle Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s included. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t take long for the media to seize on his  attack and run with it. Forget a nation\xe2\x80\x99s grief and Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s struggle to survive: What America 'b'really'b' needed, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s pundits and TV producers decided, was a noisy debate about the possible link between Jared Lee Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s crime and Palin\xe2\x80\x99s martial campaign rhetoric.'b'Given how little connection Loughner seems to have to any kind of right-wing politics, this conversation looked increasingly ridiculous by midweek, and even a little bit obscene. But instead of letting the frenzy die away, Palin decided that what the country really needed was for her to use the day set aside for mourning Loughner\xe2\x80\x99s victims to make a speech complaining about her own victimization. (Or as she put it, rather more pungently, the \xe2\x80\x9cblood libel\xe2\x80\x9d being leveled by her critics.) (MSNBC, in particular, should just change its name to \xe2\x80\x9cPalin 24/7\xe2\x80\x9d and get it over with.) When commentators aren\xe2\x80\x99t denouncing her, they\xe2\x80\x99re busy building up her legend  \xe2\x80\x94  exaggerating her political acumen, overpraising her communications strategy, covering her every tweet as if she were the Viceroy of Red America, and spinning out outlandish scenarios in which she captures the White House in 2012.'b'Palin, meanwhile, officially despises the \xe2\x80\x9clamestream\xe2\x80\x9d media. But press coverage \xe2\x80\x94  good, bad, whatever  \xe2\x80\x94  is clearly the oxygen she craves. She supposedly hates having her privacy invaded, yet her family keeps showing up on reality TV. She thinks the political class is clueless and out-of-touch, but she can\xe2\x80\x99t resist responding to its every provocation. Her public rhetoric, from \xe2\x80\x9cdeath panels\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cblood libel,\xe2\x80\x9d is obviously crafted to maximize coverage and controversy, and generate more heat than light. And her Twitter account reads like a constant plea for the most superficial sort of media attention.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a grim spectacle on both sides, and last week\xe2\x80\x99s pointless controversy was a particularly low point. So let me play the relationship counselor. To the media: Cover Sarah Palin if you want, but stop acting as if she\xe2\x80\x99s the most important conservative politician in America. And every time you\xe2\x80\x99re tempted to parse her tweets for some secret code or crucial dog whistle, stop and think, 'b'this woman has fewer Twitter followers than Ben Stiller'b', and then go write about something else instead.'b'To Palin: You were an actual politician once (remember that?), but you\xe2\x80\x99re becoming the kind of caricature that your enemies have always tried to make of you. So maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s time to turn off your iPad for a while, and take a break from Facebook and Fox News. The world won\xe2\x80\x99t end if you don\xe2\x80\x99t respond to every criticism, and you might even win a few more admirers if you cultivated a lighter touch and a more above-the-fray persona. But for the majority of Americans who are neither Palinoiacs nor Palinistas, here\xe2\x80\x99s the good news: If the press (including this columnist!)  and Sarah Palin can\xe2\x80\x99t quit each other, you can still quit us.'b'For years, Illinois, like so many states, pretended that it had not fallen off a budgetary cliff. It was spending too much and taking in too little revenue, but every year it would kick its problems into the next. Unable to pay its bills, it finally accepted reality last week and raised taxes on incomes and businesses \xe2\x80\x94 a first step toward getting its house in order.'b'The action was immediately ridiculed by several governors around the nation who are still pretending that they can cut their way out of the enormous shortfalls they face, without raising taxes. Wisconsin and Indiana predicted a windfall of angry corporations and residents would head their way from Illinois. Even Gov. But businesses and voters in Illinois, and around the country, should take a closer look at the facts and figures, including their own.'b'After 22 years of not raising income taxes, Illinois saw its budget shortfall  grow to $15 billion. It had the lowest state credit rating in the nation, and it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t paying its bills to hospitals and schools.'b'The Illinois tax rate was low before and remains low for big states. The income tax will rise from a flat 3 percent to a flat 5 percent. That will cause pain at the lower and middle levels of the economic scale, but the state\xe2\x80\x99s millionaires will probably stay put. (The top rate is 10.55 percent in California, 8.97 percent in New Jersey and New York, and 7.75 percent in Wisconsin.)'b'Illinois\xe2\x80\x99s corporate tax is going up to 9.5 percent from 7.3 percent, but that by itself is unlikely to send businesses packing. What businesses crave most is a stable environment in which to make profits, and Illinois was anything but stable. Businesses tend not to like it when health and education systems break down.'b'By taking this step, which will raise about $6.5 billion, the Illinois Legislature has begun to show residents and corporate leaders that it is serious about fixing the budget. It still has a lot more to do. It must brave union opposition and bring down the cost of excessive health and retirement benefits for state employees, and examine all state salaries to make sure they are in line with the private sector. It must adhere to a new system to rebuild the budget each year, based on available revenues.'b'Almost every state is in deep fiscal trouble this year, but only a few others have admitted that cutting spending will not be enough.'b'Gov. Illinois is figuring that out, finally. Too many other states are still in denial.'b'Last week\xe2\x80\x99s memorial service in Tucson, which began with a blessing by a professor of Yaqui Indian and Mexican heritage, showcased Arizona\xe2\x80\x99s rich diversity as well as the love and tolerance of many of its citizens.'b'Unfortunately there is another Arizona, one where its state government all too often promotes discord and intolerance. This  was painfully clear in the state\xe2\x80\x99s immigration law, which empowers the police to demand the papers of suspected illegal immigrants. And it is painfully clear in a new education law that injects nativist fears directly into the public school classroom.'b'The law, which took effect Dec. 31, bans any courses or classes that \xe2\x80\x9cpromote resentment toward a race or class of people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cadvocate ethnic solidarity instead of the treatment of pupils as individuals.\xe2\x80\x9d Arizona\xe2\x80\x99s new attorney general, Tom Horne, immediately used it to declare illegal a Mexican-American ethnic-studies program in the Tucson Unified School District.'b'Mr. Horne, who wrote the law when he was superintendent of public instruction, accused the program of \xe2\x80\x9cbrainwashing\xe2\x80\x9d Latino students, of teaching \xe2\x80\x9cethnic chauvinism\xe2\x80\x9d because it uses works by authors critical of the United States\xe2\x80\x99 historical relationship with Latin America and its past treatment of Latinos. He has not gone after similar programs for black, Asian or American Indian students.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to object to the portions of the law that discourage the overthrow of the government.
