The lines into the A.P. offices, recalled A.P.\xe2\x80\x99s executive editor, 'b'Kathleen Carroll,'b' were buzzing with complaints: where was The A.P. on this story? How could it let NPR beat it?'b'Meanwhile, the lines into the New York Times offices were hot as well, said Greg Brock, senior editor/standards: where was The Times on this story?'b'No doubt, the pressure to report the latest news was intense immediately after 'b'the shootings in Tucson on Jan. 8.'b' The difference between The A.P. and The Times on this occasion, though, was that The A.P. held off and was right, while The Times eventually jumped in with an online report of Ms. Giffords\xe2\x80\x99s death, and was wrong.'b'The mistake, quickly corrected, happened because of a breach in The Times\xe2\x80\x99s editing defenses as it worked to cover the story quickly from a distance. The episode dramatizes an important philosophical choice that editors face in an era that has transformed the way formerly old-media organizations like The Times handle and deliver the news.'b'While it\xe2\x80\x99s true that in the bygone era of print-only newspapers, editors sometimes had to make tough on-deadline calls about the accuracy of their reporting ('b'\xe2\x80\x9cDewey Defeats Truman\xe2\x80\x9d comes to mind'b'), the reality is that digital news delivery on a continuous cycle drastically increases the volume and the difficulty of these decisions.'b'Organizations, like The Times, that have built their reputations on authoritativeness now must ask themselves: How much of our reputation should we lay on the line in the name of being first in breaking news, or at least not being a laggard?'b'This decision \xe2\x80\x94 whether to be first or most authoritative \xe2\x80\x94 is a portentous one, some believe, and is likely to define the future reputations of news organizations. Others, including 'b'Bill Keller'b', The Times\xe2\x80\x99s executive editor, say this is a false dichotomy: it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to do both.'b''b'Tim McGuire'b', an academic and a former president of the 'b'American Society of Newspaper Editors,'b' is doubtful about having it both ways. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is becoming a choice: Am I going to be first? Is that going to be my brand, or am I going to be the credible one?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not sure you can do both,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. McGuire, who teaches at Arizona State University\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cI am pretty sure you cannot. I am convinced that in this day you are not going to be able to be all things to all people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to be both. Take it from The A.P., which has its own people in 300 locations globally and therefore is better positioned than any other news organization to have boots on the ground when news breaks. Ms. Carroll, its executive editor, warns that when you get something wrong, typically in a breaking news situation, \xe2\x80\x9cpeople remember for 130,000 years. Everybody remembers that we killed Bob Hope before he was dead.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That said, news organizations cannot bring themselves, it seems, to eschew the twin goals \xe2\x80\x94 arguably incompatible goals \xe2\x80\x94 of being first and most credible. Even Ms. Carroll said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe have to be able to do both.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s in the blood, it seems. I sought out television journalists to get perspective on this journalistic credo, in part because television has been dealing with the challenge of immediate news much longer than its print counterparts, which, thanks to the Internet, are now in the always-on news-breaking mode as well.'b''b'Brian Bracco,'b' a veteran news director who is now 'b'Hearst Television\xe2\x80\x99s'b' vice president for news, put it this way: \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s our nature \xe2\x80\x94 to be there first, to report it first, to let our audience know what\xe2\x80\x99s going on.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Journalists are competitive; their nerve endings burn with a compulsion to beat rivals to a story. They operate on a belief that audiences flock to whoever can move first with breaking news. Yet everyone I talked to \xe2\x80\x94 including Mr. Bracco and others who place value on being first \xe2\x80\x94 cautioned that it\xe2\x80\x99s always better to be second and right than first and wrong.'b'One who takes the thought further is 'b'Aaron Brown,'b' the CNN anchor who rode herd over coverage of the 9/11 attacks and is now a professor at the Cronkite School.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy first reaction to my print brethren these days is, welcome to my world,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Mr. Brown said experience had taught him that, in the early moments, sources are often wrong. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the chaos of a breaking story,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9call of us who have dealt with it, if we are honest with ourselves, have to ask ourselves: Are we sure? Because we all have been burnt, every one of us.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In Mr. Brown\xe2\x80\x99s view, the rush to publish is misplaced. \xe2\x80\x9cWe mistake our own urgency for the urgency viewers feel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t think they feel that. I think they would say to us, we would rather you took another minute and got it right.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To bring this back around to The Times, Mr. Keller, the executive editor, weighs in with the view that the tension between speed and accuracy is \xe2\x80\x9creal but exaggerated.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvery mistake is a mistake too many,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote me in an e-mail message, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we do not make many serious mistakes because a) reporters are told that while delivering the news in a timely fashion is valuable, getting it right is more important than getting it first, and b) editors are told to filter out information that we don\xe2\x80\x99t think is sufficiently backed up.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Dan Gillmor,'b' an influential writer on digital news and the author of 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMediactive,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' agreed that The Times should \xe2\x80\x9cnot shy away\xe2\x80\x9d from competing hard in the breaking news arena. His formula for sustaining credibility is to carefully label what is known and what is not certain, an approach that Mr. Keller subscribes to.'b'Put me down as a skeptic. It\xe2\x80\x99s understandable, given the gung-ho mentality that journalists adopt, to want to blow right by the choice \xe2\x80\x94 to try to be both first and most credible. November\xe2\x80\x99s elections made the outlook even bleaker.'b'Twenty-nine governors are considered solidly anti-abortion, up from 21 before the election. This math greatly increases the prospect of extreme efforts to undermine abortion access with Big Brother measures that require physicians to read scripts about fetal development and provide ultrasound images, and that impose mandatory waiting periods or create other unnecessary regulations.'b'Such restrictions, combined with a persistent atmosphere of intimidation and violence, have taken a grievous toll on the fundamental right protected by Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that recognized a woman\xe2\x80\x99s constitutional right to make her own child-bearing decisions. Eighty-seven percent of counties have no abortion provider, according to the Guttmacher Institute.'b'For the moment, most state legislatures are preoccupied with budget crises, so the next abortion battles are still taking shape. However, there are at least two areas where anti-abortion forces will be active in 2011.'b'The first is the fight over health insurance. The second is the expanding effort to ban later abortions.'b'Reigning Supreme Court precedent restricts the government\xe2\x80\x99s ability to bar abortions prior to the point considered to be the earliest a fetus could survive outside the womb, around 22 to 26 weeks after conception.'b'Nebraska enacted a law last year directly challenging the viability standard. The statute, which went into effect in October, bans abortions 20 weeks after conception. It includes a very narrow exception for a woman\xe2\x80\x99s life and physical health, and lacks any exception for the discovery of severe fetal anomalies. Copycat laws are now pending in other states.'b'About 90 percent of abortions take place in the first trimester, but that does not excuse some states\xe2\x80\x99 efforts to require women to continue pregnancies after a tragic fetal diagnosis or pregnancies that result from rape or incest. The objective is to provide the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s conservative majority with a new vehicle for further tampering with Roe v. Friends and I participated in a peaceful demonstration that started at the Amr Ibn al-As Mosque in Old Cairo near the Church of St. George. We set off chanting, \xe2\x80\x9cThe people want the regime to fall!\xe2\x80\x9d and we were greeted with a torrent of tear gas fired by the police. We began to shout, \xe2\x80\x9cPeaceful, Peaceful,\xe2\x80\x9d trying to show the police that we were not hostile, we were demanding nothing but our liberty. That only increased their brutality. Fighting began to spread to the side streets in the ancient, largely Coptic neighborhood.'b'A friend and I took shelter in a small alleyway, where we were warmly welcomed. The locals warned us not to try to escape to the metro station, and pointed us toward a different escape route; many of them even joined the protests. Eventually, a man drove us in his own car to safety.'b'Clearly, the scent of Tunisia\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cjasmine revolution\xe2\x80\x9d has quickly reached Egypt. Following the successful expulsion in Tunis of the dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, the call arose on Facebook for an Egyptian revolution, to begin on Jan. 25. Yet the public here mocked those young people who had taken to Twitter and Facebook to post calls for protest: Since when was the spark of revolution ignited on a pre-planned date? Had revolution become like a romantic rendezvous?'b'Such questions abounded on social networking sites; but even cynics \xe2\x80\x94 myself included \xe2\x80\x94 became hopeful as the calls continued to circulate. In the blink of an eye, the Twitter and Facebook generation had successfully rallied hundreds of thousands to its cause, across the nation. Most of them were young people who had not been politically active, and did not belong to the traditional circles of the political opposition. The Muslim Brotherhood is not behind this popular revolution, as the regime claims. Those who began it and organized it are seething in anger at police cruelty and the repression and torture meted out by the 'b'Hosni Mubarak'b' regime.'b'And, from the outset, the government decided to deal with the people with the utmost violence and brutality in the hope that the Tunisian experience would not be repeated. For days now, tear gas has been the oxygen Egyptians have inhaled. So much was in the air that there are reports of small children and the elderly having suffocated on the fumes in their homes. The security forces in Cairo started by shooting rubber bullets at the protesters, before progressing onto live ammunition, ending dozens of lives.'b'In Suez, where the demonstrations have been tremendously violent, live ammunition was used against civilians from the first day. A friend of mine who lives there sent me a message saying  that, Thursday morning, the city looked as if it had emerged from a particularly brutal war: its streets were burned and destroyed, dead bodies were strewn everywhere; we would never know how many victims had fallen to the police bullets in Suez, my friend solemnly concluded.'b'After having escaped from Old Cairo on Friday, my friends and I headed for Tahrir Square, the focal point of the modern city and site of the largest protests. We joined another demonstration making its way through downtown, consisting  mostly of young people. From a distance, we could hear the rumble of the protest in Tahrir Square, punctuated by the sounds of bullets and screams. Minute by painstaking minute, we protesters were gaining ground, and our numbers were growing. People shared Coca-Cola bottles, moistening their faces with soda to avoid the effects of tear gas. Some people wore masks, while others had sprinkled vinegar into their kaffiyehs.'b'Shopkeepers handed out bottles of mineral water to the protesters, and civilians distributed food periodically. Women and children leaned from windows and balconies, chanting with the dissidents. I will never forget the sight of an aristocratic woman driving through the narrow side streets in her luxurious car, urging the protesters to keep up their spirits, telling them that they would soon be joined by tens of thousands of other citizens arriving from different parts of the city.'b'After several failed attempts to break through the security checkpoints and get to Tahrir Square, we sat in a cafe to rest. Three officers from the regime\xe2\x80\x99s Central Security Forces, all in civilian clothing, sat down next to us. They appeared to be completely relaxed, as though they were impervious to the sounds of bullets and shouting, or to the numbers of wounded and dead Egyptians being reported on Al Jazeera, which was being broadcast on the coffee shop\xe2\x80\x99s television. They and their colleagues were all over the city, spying on their countrymen.'b'Hour by hour on Friday evening, the chaos increased. Police stations and offices of the ruling National Democratic Party were on fire across the country. I wept when news came that 3,000 volunteers had formed a human chain around the national museum to protect it from looting and vandalism. Those who do such things are certainly highly educated, cultivated people, neither vandals nor looters, as they are accused of being by those who have vandalized and looted 'b'Egypt'b' for generations.'b'The curfew meant that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t return home, so I spent the night at a friend\xe2\x80\x99s house near the Parliament building and Interior Ministry, one of the most turbulent parts of the city. That night, the sound of bullets was unceasing. We watched from the window as police  shot with impunity at the protesters and at a nearby gas station, hoping, perhaps, for an explosion. Despite all of this and despite the curfew, the demonstrations did not stop, fueled by popular fury at President Mubarak\xe2\x80\x99s slowness to address the people and, a few hours later, indignation at the deplorable speech he finally gave.'b'On Saturday morning, I left my friend\xe2\x80\x99s house and headed home. I walked across broken glass strewn in the streets, and I could smell the aftermath of the fires that had raged the night before. The army, called in by the regime to put down the protests, was everywhere. I tried first to cross over to Tahrir Square, in order to see for myself whether the museum was safe. A passer-by told me that the army was forbidding people from entering the square, and that shots were being fired. I asked him, anxiously, \xe2\x80\x9cIs the army shooting at the demonstrators?\xe2\x80\x9d He answered, confidently: \xe2\x80\x9cOf course not. The Egyptian army has never fired a shot against an Egyptian citizen, and will not do so now.\xe2\x80\x9d We both openly expressed our wish for that to be true, for the army to side with the people.'b'NOW that army troops were monitoring the demonstrations, the police force had completely disappeared from the streets, as if to taunt people with the choice between their presence and chaos. Armed gangs have mushroomed across the city, seeking to loot shops and terrorize civilians in their homes. (Saturday night, a gang tried to rob the building where I have been staying, but was unable to break in.) Local volunteers have formed committees to stand up to the criminals, amidst an overwhelming feeling that the ruling regime is deliberately stoking chaos.'b'Late Saturday, as I headed toward Corniche Street on the Nile River, I walked through a side street in the affluent Garden City neighborhood, where I found a woman crying. I asked her what was wrong, and she told me that her son, a worker at a luxury hotel, had been shot in the throat by a police bullet, despite not being a part of the demonstrations. He was now lying paralyzed in a hospital bed, and she was on her way to the hotel to request medical leave for him. I embraced her, trying to console her, and she said through her tears, \xe2\x80\x9cWe cannot be silent about what has happened. Silence is a crime. The blood of those who fell cannot be wasted.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I agree. Silence is a crime. Even if the regime continues to bombard us with bullets and tear gas, continues to block Internet access and cut off our mobile phones, we will find ways to get our voices across to the world, to demand freedom and justice.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'No Sign They Get It'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 22):'b'The good news is that \xe2\x80\x9cbusiness as usual\xe2\x80\x9d for the United States oil and natural gas industry means that we are building on nearly a century of commitment to safe and reliable operations. He proposes an alternative approach, with limited enrollment periods.'b'What seems to be lost in the discussion is that this is not fundamentally a question of economics, interstate commerce or freedom of choice. It is at its root a moral issue.'b'If there is no mandate to buy coverage, what do we do when people who make the choice to opt out of insurance coverage do get sick or have terrible accidents? Do we let them die because they took a calculated risk?'b'Fortunately, we have sensible laws that require hospitals to treat the sick and injured whether they are insured or not. 'b'Andrew Cuomo'b' and the Legislature will have to make very difficult decisions about how to close a $10 billion budget deficit \xe2\x80\x94 which state offices to shutter, which services and aid to cut, which employees to lay off and which taxes to raise. There are no easy fixes left.'b'Mr. Cuomo has vowed to balance the budget without borrowing or using any of the accounting gimmicks that helped dig New York into this hole. That\xe2\x80\x99s good news.'b'But we are skeptical of his no-new-taxes pledge and his promise to let a surcharge on high earners expire. Extending that one tax until the end of 2012 would add an estimated $2 billion to the budget in the coming fiscal year and $4 billion the following year.'b'Without additional revenue, all of the $10 billion will have to come from spending cuts \xe2\x80\x94 a reduction of more than 10 percent  for  the state\xe2\x80\x99s projected $92.3 billion operating 'b'budget'b'. Half of that goes to schools and 'b'Medicaid'b' and other health care. So the state\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable citizens \xe2\x80\x94 the poor, the sick, the elderly and schoolchildren \xe2\x80\x94 will inevitably bear the largest burden.'b'Is there room to cut? Yes. New York spends more per pupil on education and more per enrollee on Medicaid than nearly any other state. Salaries and benefits for state employees outstrip the private sector.'b'In some cases, such as parts of the Medicaid program, the services are better and would be worth the investment in easier times. In too many cases, those higher costs are the result of Albany\xe2\x80\x99s profligacy and its eagerness to reward unions and other special interests.'b'New York also ranks at or near the top of various surveys of tax burdens. The tax system needs to be reviewed, but there is no way to deal with the budget crises \xe2\x80\x94 near-term and long-term \xe2\x80\x94 without higher taxes.'b'\xc2\x95'b'We need to live within our means. The challenge is to find ways to cut spending equitably and limit the disruption to essential services and the damage to the state\xe2\x80\x99s future. Living within our means also requires finding equitable sources of additional revenue.'b'Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s budget for fiscal year 2011-12 is due Tuesday. The Legislature must approve a final budget by April 1. That is not a lot of time. Politicians and voters need to use it well, carefully reviewing and debating policy decisions. Here are some of the issues to consider:'b''b'THE NUMBERS'b' New York State has a frustratingly opaque budgeting process, but as of November, the state  budget office was predicting a breakdown that includes: $24 billion for health care, mainly Medicaid; $23 billion for K-12 education; $17 billion for state employee salaries and benefits; $6.5 billion for local government grants; and $3.4 billion for welfare and other social services.'b'Mr. Cuomo wants to streamline government and we will certainly hear a lot more about reducing waste, fraud and abuse. These are admirable goals, but there is no way to find $10 billion in savings without making significant cuts from the biggest-ticket items.'b''b'MEDICAID 'b'New York\xe2\x80\x99s Medicaid program\xe2\x80\x94 the joint state-federal health insurance for the poor \xe2\x80\x94 is expected to spend far more than any other state\xe2\x80\x99s, including the programs in California and Texas, which have much larger populations.'b'In part that is due to the high cost of medical care around New York City. But New York\xe2\x80\x99s eligibility terms and benefits are some of the most generous in the nation. It ranks near the top in providing \xe2\x80\x9coptional benefits,\xe2\x80\x9d such as dental coverage and long-term care. And it spends more than any other state per enrollee on care for the elderly and disabled.'b'Any cuts must try to minimize harm to patients and communities. Unfortunately, cuts in Medicaid could be almost three times as painful as other cuts: if Albany cuts $2 billion, local governments automatically cut at least $750 million and New York  will lose $2.75 billion in federal funds, for a total reduction of $5.5 billion.'b'The best place to look for savings is  in programs for the elderly and the disabled; as a quarter of the enrollees, they receive almost three-quarters of total Medicaid spending. Some is acute care in hospitals, but a lot is long-term care in nursing homes, clinics and at home, where spending is rising rapidly.'b'The state may need to restrict allowed home visits, placing an even greater burden on families. More long-term care patients must be moved into managed care plans. To save money right now, Albany will likely have to cut the reimbursement rates to hospitals and other institutions. It will need to focus on well-paid providers, without endangering safety-net hospitals.'b'New York could get some additional help next year from Washington if it is aggressive about applying for demonstration grants to test cost-saving approaches under the 'b'health care reform'b' law. If they work, they could also bring lasting improvements to the program.'b''b'EDUCATION 'b'New York\xe2\x80\x99s average per pupil cost of more than $15,000 is well above the national average of about $11,000. In student achievement, the state trails Massachusetts and Maryland, which spend significantly less. That means New York has two challenges: it must address the quality of instruction and the high costs.'b'Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature must first acknowledge the historical inequity of education financing \xe2\x80\x94 and guarantee that the poorest districts will feel the least pain. For decades, Albany has starved poor school districts while lavishing money on wealthy districts.'b'Under a court ruling, Albany in 2007 adopted a new, needs-based funding formula intended to distribute an additional $7 billion over several years to poor and chronically underfinanced districts. The money was distributed for two years, frozen in the third year and cut significantly last year.'b'This year, the wealthiest school districts should bear much of the burden,  and poor districts should  be protected as much as possible.'b'Last year\xe2\x80\x99s cuts cost New York City about $440 million in education funds. The Ilion school district, in upstate Herkimer County, is another that has been long neglected, and last year\xe2\x80\x99s loss of about $450,000 in state aid hit particularly hard. The district had to lay off 3 of its 145 teachers and did not replace two others who retired. The superintendent worries that he might have to lay off as many as 10 additional teachers this year.'b'Ilion is doing many of the right things to cut costs. It buys office and payroll services from a consortium and is exploring a merger with three other districts. Even the most ambitious savings pale when compared with the burden of salaries and benefits, which make up about 75 percent of Ilion\xe2\x80\x99s costs.'b'Ilion\xe2\x80\x99s problems are deeper than those of many other districts, but the underlying choices are the same. Savings can be found through streamlining and other creative reforms. But with 75 percent of all local education budgets going to pay for teachers\xe2\x80\x99 salaries and benefits, that is where much of the money will have to be found.'b'The unions may have to accept a salary freeze, and even then layoffs may be inevitable. (Last year, the state lost 9,000 of its 220,000 teachers due to the budget cuts.) Teachers will have to agree to pay more into their pensions and health insurance plans, and to raise the retirement age to 65.'b'Governor Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s call for a 2 percent cap on property taxes will make a bad situation even worse. It would make it impossible for districts \xe2\x80\x94 unless voters overrode the cap \xe2\x80\x94 to raise more local school aid at the very time that  the state is cutting its contribution. The Legislature should reject the idea.'b''b'PERSONNEL'b' Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s proposed salary freeze for many of the state\xe2\x80\x99s 236,000 workers could save at least $200 million next year. Unions are resisting. Freezes are a painful fact of life across the private sector these days. And, thanks to their powerful unions, state workers have gotten raises worth more than 13 percent since 2007.'b'New York will never get its fiscal house in order unless it deals with employees\xe2\x80\x99 extremely generous benefits. By 2013, the average total compensation \xe2\x80\x94 salary, pension contribution and health insurance contribution \xe2\x80\x94 for a state employee will be $102,000.'b'While private-sector workers pay about 20 percent of the cost of individual health insurance coverage on average, state employees contribute only 10 percent.'b'Pension benefits are even more out of line. Until 2009, most employees contributed 3 percent to their pensions, but only for the first decade of employment. In 2009 lawmakers required new employees to contribute 3 percent every year, but that contribution is still less than half of what most other states require. New York also has lower retirement ages and higher disability rates than most states and is one of only three in the country to count overtime in calculating pension benefits.'b'The state must insist on higher contributions by all its workers to pensions and health insurance, a lower ceiling on the amount of overtime counted in pension calculations and wage increases in line with those in the economy at large.'b''b'REVENUES 'b'In his State of the State address, Governor Cuomo said that New York has \xe2\x80\x9cthe worst business tax climate in the nation, period.\xe2\x80\x9d That was a reference to New York\xe2\x80\x99s last-place position in a tally by one research group, the Tax Foundation. Other tallies yield different results. Even using that ranking, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to prove that businesses in New York are at a huge competitive disadvantage, especially since neighboring New Jersey ranked 48 and Connecticut ranked 47, while South Dakota and Alaska were first and second.'b'More important, taxes generally rank behind education, infrastructure and other criteria when businesses decide where to locate. Trying to balance the budget solely with cuts \xe2\x80\x94 in education and essential services \xe2\x80\x94 will make New York even less attractive.'b'With the economy still struggling this is not the time to impose major new taxes. There are some that can bring in a good chunk of revenue, without doing damage.'b'As we said, New York would get an estimated $2 billion of additional revenue in the upcoming fiscal year if it extended the personal income tax surcharge that applies to couples making more than $300,000 and individuals making over $200,000. (A couple with two school-age children and taxable income of $350,000 would pay $3,500 more. A couple making $1 million, with two children and typical deductions, would pay about $20,500 more.)'b'Wealthy families got a generous break from Washington with the extension of the 'b'Bush-era tax cuts'b'. Mr. Cuomo should extend New York\xe2\x80\x99s surcharge for two more years. Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature should also be looking for other sources of revenue. A penny-per-ounce tax on sugary sodas could raise an estimated $465 million in the first fiscal year. This is a no-brainer.'b'The governor also needs to order a systematic review of nearly $29 billion in state tax credits and other breaks. Some are necessary to encourage investment and development, but others stay on the books year after year without any analysis of their value. Why, for example, do sellers of precious metal bullion and coins get a tax break that cost the state $185 million in 2010? Doing away with about 5 percent of these deals would bring in nearly $1.5 billion.'b'None of these choices will be easy. Governor Cuomo has set up several commissions to recommend ways to cut costs and streamline government. We hope the process will promote an honest, transparent debate. New York can\xe2\x80\x99t go on this way any longer.'b'\xc2\x95'b''b'This is the first in a series of editorials about the fiscal crisis in New York State and in other states around the country. 'b''b'Last Saturday, reported The Financial Times, some of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful financial executives were going to hold  a private meeting with finance ministers in Davos, the site of the World Economic Forum. The principal demand of the executives, the newspaper suggested, would be that governments \xe2\x80\x9cstop banker-bashing.\xe2\x80\x9d Apparently bailing bankers out after they precipitated the worst slump since the Great Depression isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough \xe2\x80\x94 politicians have to stop hurting their feelings, too.'b'But the bankers also had a more substantive demand: they want higher interest rates, despite the persistence of very high unemployment in the United States and Europe, because they say that low rates are feeding inflation. And what worries me is the possibility that policy makers might actually take their advice.'b'To understand the issues, you need to know that we\xe2\x80\x99re in the midst of what the International Monetary Fund calls a \xe2\x80\x9ctwo speed\xe2\x80\x9d recovery, in which some countries are speeding ahead, but others \xe2\x80\x94 including the United States \xe2\x80\x94 have yet to get out of first gear.'b'The U.S. economy fell into recession at the end of 2007; the rest of the world followed a few months later. And advanced nations \xe2\x80\x94 the United States, Europe, Japan \xe2\x80\x94 have barely begun to recover. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that these economies have been growing since the summer of 2009, but the growth has been too slow to produce large numbers of jobs. To raise interest rates under these conditions would be to undermine any chance of doing better; it would mean, in effect, accepting mass unemployment as a permanent fact of life.'b'What about inflation? High unemployment has kept a lid on the measures of inflation that usually guide policy. The Federal Reserve\xe2\x80\x99s preferred measure, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, is now running below half a percent at an annual rate, far below the informal target of 2 percent.'b'But food and energy prices \xe2\x80\x94 and commodity prices in general \xe2\x80\x94 have, of course, been rising lately. Corn and wheat prices rose around 50 percent last year; copper, cotton and rubber prices have been setting new records. What\xe2\x80\x99s that about?'b'The answer, mainly, is growth in emerging markets. While recovery in advanced nations has been sluggish, developing countries \xe2\x80\x94 China in particular \xe2\x80\x94 have come roaring back from the 2008 slump. This has created inflation pressures within many of these countries; it has also led to sharply rising global demand for raw materials. Bad weather \xe2\x80\x94 especially an unprecedented heat wave in the former Soviet Union, which led to a sharp fall in world wheat production \xe2\x80\x94 has also played a role in driving up food prices.'b'The question is, what bearing should all of this have on policy at the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank?'b'First of all, inflation in China is China\xe2\x80\x99s problem, not ours. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that right now China\xe2\x80\x99s currency is pegged to the dollar. But that\xe2\x80\x99s China\xe2\x80\x99s choice; if China doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like U.S. monetary policy, it\xe2\x80\x99s free to let its currency rise. Neither China nor anyone else has the right to demand that America strangle its nascent economic recovery just because Chinese exporters want to keep the renminbi undervalued.'b'What about commodity prices? The Fed normally focuses on \xe2\x80\x9ccore\xe2\x80\x9d inflation, which excludes food and energy, rather than \xe2\x80\x9cheadline\xe2\x80\x9d inflation, because experience shows that while some prices fluctuate widely from month to month, others have a lot of inertia \xe2\x80\x94 and it\xe2\x80\x99s the ones with inertia you want to worry about, because once either inflation or deflation gets built into these prices, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to get rid of.'b'And this focus has served the Fed well in the past. In particular, the Fed was right not to raise rates in 2007-8, when commodity prices soared \xe2\x80\x94 briefly pushing headline inflation above 5 percent \xe2\x80\x94 only to plunge right back to earth. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see why the Fed should behave differently this time, with inflation nowhere near as high as it was during the last commodity boom.'b'So why the demand for higher rates? Well, bankers have a long history of getting fixated on commodity prices. Traditionally, that meant insisting that any rise in the price of gold would mean the end of Western civilization. These days it means demanding that interest rates be raised because the prices of copper, rubber, cotton and tin have gone up, even though underlying inflation is on the decline.'b'Ben Bernanke clearly understands that raising rates now would be a huge mistake. But Jean-Claude Trichet, his European counterpart, is making hawkish noises \xe2\x80\x94 and both the Fed and the European Central Bank are under a lot of external pressure to do the wrong thing.'b'They need to resist this pressure. Yes, commodity prices are up \xe2\x80\x94 but that\xe2\x80\x99s no reason to perpetuate mass unemployment. To paraphrase William Jennings Bryan, we must not crucify our economies upon a cross of rubber.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Thorny Path to a National Black Museum'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 23):'b'I am certain that establishing the National Museum of African American History and Culture will be a continuing challenge for all who are involved. However, I am concerned that much of the emphasis on African-American culture might be placed on music and sports.'b'It is unlikely that any visitors would question the great achievements that black Americans have made in those areas.'b'One hopes that the museum planners will also take this opportunity to display African-American contributions to literature, medicine, science and engineering. These topics receive comparatively little attention but are also critical components of our society and culture.'b'Arnold Henderson Jr.'b'\nMarblehead, Mass., Jan. 24, 2011'b''b'To the Editor:'b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Build a Bigger House'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Jan. 24), Dalton Conley and Jacqueline Stevens are right to call for an increase in the size of the House of Representatives, though they are overly optimistic in their assessment of the effect it would have on representation and campaigns.'b'There is nothing magic about 435 House seats, and every reason to consider an increase when the average population of districts has tripled since 1910, leaving Montana with only a single House member for nearly a million people.'b'Representative Alcee L. Hastings has for years introduced 'b'legislation'b' to study House size, and analyze another potential statutory change: proportional voting in House elections. Given the increasingly bright partisan lines dividing the House because of winner-take-all voting rules, Mr. Hastings\xe2\x80\x99s proposals are all the more timely.'b'Rob Richie'b'\nExecutive Director, FairVote'b'\nTakoma Park, Md., Jan. 24, 2011'b''b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Increasing the size of the House is unlikely to solve the problems Dalton Conley and Jacqueline Stevens identify.'b'Special-interest groups would be able to spend less per race and could, in fact, increase their influence if they were able to build strategic voting blocs among the candidates they supported. There would not necessarily be more citizen-legislators in the House, since in plenty of state and municipal offices the same representatives are elected over and over again for decades.'b'As the writers note, the House would have to seat \xe2\x80\x9c5,000 if we match the ratio the founders awarded themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d A House of this size \xe2\x80\x94 or the 1,500 they seem to suggest \xe2\x80\x94 would make it all but impossible for legislators to get to know one another, especially across party lines. The result would be a House even more dependent on seniority, party affiliation and special-interest groups.'b'Chris DesBarres'b'\nWinston-Salem, N.C., Jan. 24, 2011'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Perhaps we need more representatives, but there are better ways to reform the House. It\xe2\x80\x99s absurd to inflict national elections on Americans every two years.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s unfair to politicians, too. As soon as they\xe2\x80\x99re elected, they\xe2\x80\x99re running for re-election \xe2\x80\x94 that is, raising money. They don\xe2\x80\x99t have time to establish a meaningful track record of legislative activity. And when they do legislate, most simply parrot whatever is prevailing public opinion at the time because they are soon to face election.'b'We might as well have a government of professional pollsters. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not leadership.'b'If we\xe2\x80\x99re going to fix what ails America, we can\xe2\x80\x99t afford short-term politicians with short-term ideas. True leaders tell us what we should be thinking, rather than simply aping today\xe2\x80\x99s popular view, and that requires a House term of at least four years.'b'Michael Northmore'b'\nStaten Island, Jan. 24, 2011'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'We simply cannot afford the salaries of extra members, staff, pensions and Cadillac health care coverage. Not to mention the longer committee sessions to accommodate the increase in pontificating questions and not necessarily better testimony.'b'Murem Sharpe'b'\nSavannah, Ga., Jan. 24, 2011'b''b''b'The writer was on the staff of Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, in 1971-72. 'b''b'As the world ponders the fate of 'b'Egypt'b' after 'b'Hosni Mubarak'b', Americans should ponder this: It\xe2\x80\x99s quite possible that if Mubarak had not ruled Egypt as a dictator for the last 30 years, the World Trade Center would still be standing.'b'This is true even though Mubarak\xe2\x80\x99s regime has been a steadfast U.S. ally, a partner in our counterterrorism efforts and a foe of Islamic radicalism. Or, more aptly, it\xe2\x80\x99s true because his regime has been all of these things.'b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Looming Tower'b',\xe2\x80\x9d his history of 'b'Al Qaeda'b', Lawrence Wright raises the possibility that \xe2\x80\x9cAmerica\xe2\x80\x99s tragedy on September 11 was born in the prisons of Egypt.\xe2\x80\x9d By visiting imprisonment, torture and exile upon Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s Muslim Brotherhood, Mubarak foreclosed any possibility of an Islamic revolution in his own country. But he also helped radicalize and internationalize his country\xe2\x80\x99s Islamists, pushing men like Ayman Al-Zawahiri  \xe2\x80\x94  Osama bin Laden\xe2\x80\x99s chief lieutenant, and arguably the real brains behind Al Qaeda  \xe2\x80\x94  out of Egyptian politics and into the global jihad.'b'At the same time, Mubarak\xe2\x80\x99s relationship with Washington has offered constant vindication for the jihadi worldview. Under his rule, Egypt received more American dollars than any country besides Israel. For many young Egyptians, restless amid political and economic stagnation, it\xe2\x80\x99s been a short leap from hating their dictator to hating his patrons in the United States. One of the men who made this leap was an architecture student named Mohamed Atta, who was at the cockpit when American Airlines Flight 11 hit the World Trade Center.'b'These sound like good reasons to welcome Mubarak\xe2\x80\x99s potential overthrow, and the end to America\xe2\x80\x99s decades-long entanglement with his drab, repressive regime. Unfortunately, Middle Eastern politics is never quite that easy. The United States supported Mubarak for so long because of two interrelated fears: the fear of another Khomeini and the fear of another Nasser. Both anxieties remain entirely legitimate today.'b'The first fear everyone understands, because we\xe2\x80\x99re still living with the religious tyranny that Ayatollah Khomeini   established in Iran in 1979, in the wake of a spontaneous revolution not unlike the one currently sweeping Cairo and Alexandria.'b'The second fear is less immediately resonant, because Gamal Abdel Nasser is now 40   years in the grave. But the last time a popular revolution in the land of the pharaohs overthrew a corrupt regime, the year was 1952, Nasser was the beneficiary  \xe2\x80\x94  and Washington lived to rue the day he came to power.'b'Nasser was not an Islamist: he was a secular pan-Arabist socialist, which in the 1950s seemed to put him on history\xe2\x80\x99s cutting edge. But under his influence, Egypt became an aggressively destabilizing force in Middle Eastern politics. His dream of a unified Arab world helped inspire convulsions and coups from Lebanon to Iraq. He fought two wars with Israel, and intervened disastrously in Yemen. His army was accused of using poison gas in that conflict, a grim foreshadowing of Saddam Hussein\xe2\x80\x99s domestic tactics. And his 'b'pursuit of ballistic missiles'b'  was a kind of dress rehearsal for today\xe2\x80\x99s Iranian nuclear brinkmanship  \xe2\x80\x94  complete with a covert Israeli campaign to undermine his weapons programs.'b'The memory of Nasser is a reminder that even if post-Mubarak Egypt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t descend into religious dictatorship, it\xe2\x80\x99s still likely to lurch in a more anti-American direction. The long-term consequences of a more populist and nationalistic Egypt might be better for the United States than the stasis  of the Mubarak era, and the terrorism that it helped inspire. But then again they might be worse. There are devils behind every door.'b'Americans don\xe2\x80\x99t like to admit this. We take refuge in foreign policy systems: liberal internationalism or realpolitik, neoconservatism or noninterventionism. We have theories, and expect the facts to fall into line behind them. Support democracy, and stability will take care of itself. Don\xe2\x80\x99t meddle, and nobody will meddle with you. International institutions will keep the peace. No, balance-of-power politics will do it.'b'But history makes fools of us all. We make deals with dictators, and reap the whirlwind of terrorism. We promote democracy, and watch Islamists gain power from Iraq to 'b'Palestine'b'. We leap into humanitarian interventions, and get bloodied in Somalia. We stay out, and watch 'b'genocide'b' engulf Rwanda. We intervene in Afghanistan and then depart, and watch the Taliban take over. We intervene in Afghanistan and stay, and end up trapped there, with no end in sight.'b'Sooner or later, the theories always fail. The world is too complicated for them, and too tragic. History has its upward arcs, but most crises require weighing unknowns against unknowns, and choosing between competing evils.'b'The only comfort, as we watch Egyptians struggle for their country\xe2\x80\x99s future, is that some choices aren\xe2\x80\x99t America\xe2\x80\x99s to make.'
